Bracing for a hot alcohol burn I¬ím met with....  a lightly sweet toffee and brown sugar taste.  More raisin flavor and a dry, bitter woodiness mixed with a light cream that provides a unique balance.  Finishes sweet and dry, but still with no strong alcohol burn that most Old Ale¬ís have which makes it much more drinkable to me.  A nice change and a nice beer.    ***Notes from 11/10/2013***:  Looking back at my notes on this as I try this again, I mostly agree with them but would rate this beer higher now (which I just did).  Has a great fresh roasted malt and coffee nose that follows into the taste.  Crystal clear copper/ruby color that I didn¬ít note.   The alcohol is still strangely very much hidden.  It¬ís a bit like an imperial porter with rich roasted malt, coffee and bittersweet chocolate flavors.  Not sure if it¬ís changed at all, but I seem to be enjoying it more this time around!
Pours a dark amber body with a thin white head. Big chocolate flavor. Also coffee, nuts, and dark fruits. Nice lacing. Very well done.

Had this in Denver during their GABF beergarden party.  Well balanced beer, very ESB-esque.  Caramel aroma with just enough citrus hops to bring it to life.  Had it on tap not out of the bottle.  Would drink again.

A: Dark amber/brown... medium bodied offwhite head with decent head retention and mediocre lacing...

S: Bold roasted malt aroma (caramel, chocolate, spices) and some floral hop bitterness towards the beginning of the nose

T: Follows the nose... sweet roasted malts dominate.. caramel takes the forefront... floral hop finish... not much in the way of alcohol on the tongue...

M: Medium bodied.. decent carbonation... smooth from start to finish... crisp hop bitterness at the end...

O: Well hidden alcohol with a nice sweet malt taste is rather pleasant... drink this before the warm weather gets here...

En engelsk vintage ale i amerikansk tappning. B√§rnstensf√§rgad med l√•gt skum. En l√§tt schizofren upplevelse som faktiskt fungerar. Massor av karamells√∂t maltkropp st√§lls mot amerikansk humle p√• t√•rna. Tillsammans uppst√•r om inte ljuv musik s√• i alla fall en fin brytning med ekfatskarakt√§r, fikon, l√§der, kaffearom, aprikoser och aningens drag √•t urin. Inte s√• illa som det l√•ter och fint till lagrad ost. Lite f√∂r r√• f√∂r att f√• toppbetyg. B√∂r lagras ett √•r eller tv√•.

Brown to black body. Magnificent beer, no doubt. Aroma shows huge wood aroma, syrup. Superb taste, velvet mouthfeel, subtle and powerful aromas switch places all the time. Clean bitter with vanilla aftertaste finish. Above all, the fantastic effects of barrel-aging are revealed here: a masterpiece.

This is a real treat during the winter, lots of dried apricot, caramel, figs and almost a coca cola sensation but more viscous. But there are some raisins to and a earthy type of feel. I think this will age very well.

Pours lehigh brown from tap with an inch of brown head. Nice molasses and raisin notes on the nose. The molasses feels bigger on the tongue. Clean finisher which is especially impressive considering how big it is.

On tap at Mekong on 12/14/2010. Slightly hazy reddish amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet bready, earthy, and caramel aroma. Dry earthy flavor with light chocolate and a dry bitter finish. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.
Bottle from Beer Revolution. Pours dark brown with a rich tan head and a chocoatle and toffee aroma. There is a robust treacle flavor with a bit of dark fruit and a dry bitter finish. Very malty.

Very nice color, just what I like. Dark brown with a deepred glow coming through. Maybe I was expecting too much after rating the color. Smell and taste were pretty average to me. Palate ok for 8.7ABV.

Ambrata, tendente all¬íaranciato, schiuma ben presente, ma non molto duratura, color nocciola chiaro, al naso √® speziata, con note di caramello e frutta matura, al palato mi sorprende, molto caramello, note torrefatte, caff√®, sfumature luppolo, tutto per√≤ tende a creare un perfetto assemblaggio che rende bene il senso di birra invernale. da notare che la bottiglia non riportava la data di produzione, ma solo la scadenza, dicembre 2011, presumo possa essere quindi una bottiglia del 2009, inizio 2010, quindi per una old ale anche piuttosto giovane.

Malzig aromatischer Geruch, etwas nach honig. Malziger aber nicht √ºber√§√üig intensiver Antrunk, leicht herb und fruchtig mit w√§rmendem aber sonstnicht erkennbarem Alkoholteil. Etwas harzig im Abgang, trocken herb, nur feinw√ºrzig. Harmonisch. 	 
Test vom 19.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,11,10,9,12,11 - 10,50

Bottle thanks to motortoddhead.  Deep brown with red hues, tan/off-white head.  Aroma is raw, skunky noble-type hops, dark fruit, caramel.  Flavor is toasted/burnt biscuit, complex herbal/dank hops, dark fruit.  Finishes brief burnt toast and hop bitterness.  Very smooth and fairly complex.  Great mouthfeel and presence.  Impressive to say the least.

8.7% ABV Bottle. Sept 2 2010. Ap 3 Opaque, maybe hazed orange amber with nice light tan head and lace. A 7 Dark toffee, choc, light roast, light pine and grass. T 8 med body, Dark toffee, caramel, light hop flavour and bitterness. P 4 lingering sweetness and light bitterness and flavour. o 17

Poured into a snifter. 2006 vintage. 

4.0 A: Pours a deep amber mahogany color. Still plenty of carbonation in this as I got about one finger of creamy beige head. The retention wasn¬ít so great, but there was a decent amount of lacing left.

4.0 S: Lots of caramel and, to a lesser extent, toffee. Dark fruits galore with plum, fig, and raisin. Perhaps a touch of chocolate. Finally, I am picking up some Milkbone (the dog bone brand) aroma and it is unmistakeable.

4.0 T: Taste for the most part follows the nose. There is, however, a lot more chocolate in the taste. Still plenty of caramel, dark fruit, and yes, the Milkbone is there as well.

4.0 M: Heavier medium body. Still plenty of carbonation. In fact, it has a just-right amount. Reasonably creamy and smooth.

4.5 D: Some of the categories were borderline next-best-level, so that¬ís why this is a 4.5. I don¬ít believe I¬íve ever had this fresh, but as it stands now, it¬ís a pretty damn good beer. I¬ím not sure how good it would be in another couple years though. I wish I had another one so I could find out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-26-2011 20:07:56

This is a compilation of 08/09/10 samples at the Tap Room. All three pours look identical honestly. 09 wins the aroma: nice port like the 08 and caramel notes. 08 wins the flavor race followed by the 10; the 09 seemed muted. All 3 were tasty though. Cool flight to try.

Pours a cloudy brown with a small tan head. Aroma and Taste of sweet spices, brown sugar, sweet malt. raisins, light earthy hops. Palate is nice full body, good carbonation, nice smooth mouthfeel. Finish is sweet toasted caramel malt, some brown sugar and raisin, ending in a sweet hoppy biitterness with a nice long slightly dry finish. A very nice holiday brew.

Reviewed from notes.

Served into a snifter. Pours a reddish-brown color with an off-white head. A bit of lacing. The nose is fairly complex with some nice notes of caramel, dark fruits, brown sugar, and some light pine and citrus hops. The taste is a bit of a letdown after the nose, as there are some notes of brown sugar and caramel, but nothing like the nose. The feel is a bit heavy and nice with some really light booze. Drinks well enough, but there¬ís nothing drawing me back for more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010
Sweet malt aroma with some light spice. Cloudy amber brown color with a medium tan head. Sweet malty beginning with a mild dry bitter finish.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of cookie, toasted and milk chocolate, light herbs and rotten orange for the hops, broth for the yeast with background notes of charred wood, maple syrup and fudge. Head is small, frothy, beige with some slippery lacing and is almost fully diminishing.  Color is clear reddish brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet and acidic. Palate is medium, oily with a carbonation between soft and lively and lightly drying finish. This is a nice Old Ale that is both sweet and savory, definitely a beer for a cool night.

0.355l bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a deep caramel brown body with a tanned fingersize head. Nose is sweet with caramel, licorice, thin milk-chocolate, alcohol and brown sugar. The body is really nice and thick with medium carbonation. Tastes caramel, dark malts and has a warming alcohol-stinginess that makes this really interesting and nice! Ends in a mild coffee finish and it¬ís leaving a lasting dark fruity aftertaste. Not sure if this is meant to wake you up after the hibernation or prepare you for it, anyhow, this was a great brew!

Bottle. Brown beer with a tan head. Toffee and pine aroma with earth and malt. Toffee flavor with backing grapefruit and pine. Medium bodied. Toffee and backing PNW hops linger with light cocoa and earth.
09 on tap at the happy gnome.  reddish in color with small brownish head. Kinda hoppy  and caramel, bitter caramel.  Taste is the same is the small, the age has mellowed it out.

D¬íVine¬ís, DC six-pack ($9): Pours a reddish brown color with a tan head. Aroma is not as powerful as I would have expected. Lots of earthiness, as well as sugary malts. The taste has some mild hop bitterness accentuated by the roasted malts. Also somewhat on the sweet side, but not in any way what you would call a sweet beer. Furthermore, the alcohol is superbly covered by the flavors and makes for one of the easiest to drink high alcohol beers you can buy. Pretty damn good. I managed to drink four of these in quick succession.

A-deep ruby-ish color with a nice haze to it. about a 1/4 inch of head, that held much longer than expected.

S- very earthy aromas, which was expected from the style, especially from a seasonal strong ale.

T- WOW!!!! such a unique taste for the palate. this beer tastes like how a winter beer should taste. kind of sweet, very hoppy and malty and it is very hard to describe it. you can taste its bold strong flavors, as well as the high alcohol content.

M-my mouth feels a little dry after drinking it, but that is mostly due to its high alcohol content, in addition to its earthy/piney winter aromas.

D- in my opinion, i think that this beer is amazing. it brought flavors to my palate that i have never tasted before from a beer, and for me it was real easy to drink, but i don¬ít think that it will be for everyone. this beer seems to be for the true fans of strong, winter craft beers

The beer pours a totally flat clear medium amber with a barely a poof of a head and no lacing. 

The aroma is very light and right off the start it smells really weird to me, like old gym socks soaked in urine or just bo. there is a little amount of spice.

The taste is better, stale and has smoke. It tastes like an ale, but not a good one.
Deep dark amber color with a good off-white head. Taste is strong, and very hoppy. Best old ale ever tasted.
Clear dark amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, spicy and alcohol. Flavor is medium sweet and rather bitter. Dry and bitter finish with warming alcohol. Not really my style. 220110

One of the best I¬íve tasted lately.  Strong nice aroma, taste is and palate is full yet sharp with even a hint, small at that, of fruit.  licorice and berry I want to say.  A gentle smokey taste as well
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 I love this style and they do it justice. Great malt profile and complex flavors and aromas. Highly recommended.

bottle at √∏lbaren. Tick 64 of the day, time to go home... clear red with small floaties, smooth light brown head. Hoppy dusty aroma, malts, caramel, bitter caramel. Old beer. Very nice aroma indeed.  flavor is sweet malty, strong hoppy balance, caramelly. Full flavor, very slightly flowery. This one bottled 2007 but still going strong.. Impressive.

Pours red-amber with virtually no head and light lacing. Nose is brown malty with a touch of hops and cinnamon. Flavor is much richer, with notes of roasted barley, brown sugar, cocoa, bittering hops, and alcohol. Finish is long, bittersweet, and somewhat sticky. Excellent brew.
small, light colored head. very creamy mouthfeel, but a little flat. caramel nose that dominates the taste, but not overdone. a little more carbonation would have been better.

Bottle that had been hibernating in my cellar for at least a year, possibly two. 8.1% ABV so it¬ís no more recent than 2008, so certainly some time on it.  Pours a lovely shade of crimson and brown with a medium sized beige head with a ruby hue to it.  Nice spice notes, a good malty backbone, and a touch of oxidization.  A touch sweet, definite age signs here, oxidized a bit with some papery notes starting to hit the big sweet malt.  A touch of chocolate and toast bitterness on the finish.  Touches of warming alcohol.  Held up fairly well.

Pours deep amber to brown with a creamy tan head.  Sweet aroma of coffee, chocolate, and hops.  Has a warm and complex sweetness with perfectly blended hop flavor.  Smooth, creamy and medium to full bodied.  I almost wanna go back and pick up some more.  Delightful way to greet the weekend.
12 oz. from the Brick Store, thanks to GTAgeek. Nice aroma, and even better taste of caramel and sweet dark fruits.  Very impressed.
Nice brown pour with a malty sweet aroma. Medium body and very smooth. Had this beer during a blizzard which makes it extra fitting.

(old notes)  Pours a solid brown with minimal head.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, and slight piney hops.  A malt dominant but very excellent balanced beer with incredible smoothness.  Will get a sixer to cellar!!!!

12 oz. bottle at the Brick Store Pub. The pour is dark brown with a thin and fleeting head. The aroma is rich caramel and dark fruits. The flavor is very sweet and malty, with only a hint of hop bitterness. The palate is thick and sticky, with a significant booze warming. Overall, a powerful and tasty beer.
Aroma of oak... Deep red brown in color... Flavor is caramel malts, oak, scotch finish.. Delicious

Pours a thick dark chestnut color with minimal cream-colored head.  Aroma of pine, hops, with some chocolate.  Chocolate, caramel flavors dominate with a hop bitter ending.  Great lacing!  Really nice beer!

Review from notes, sampled 12/9/2007
Pours a medium to dark copper color with an off white head that laces down the entire glass. Smell is piney hops, and a bit of dark chocolate. Taste has a bit of caramel and chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel moderate carbonation. Not a bad brew. Definitely a sipper. Nice beer for a cold night by the fire.

12oz bottle from BevMo.  Pours a beautiful clear mahogany with a creamy off white head.  Nose holds light grassy hops, cherry wood and some roasted malts.  Flavors were a bit confusing.  Some dark fruits, roasty malts and a strange lingering metallic bitterness in the finish, can¬ít quite tell if its a good or bad thing.

A good English-style Old Ale.  Pours brown.  Not much on the nose but malt.  Tastes of malt and maybe a little caramel.  A little too much "hop magic" to make this something I would want to keep large quantities of.
Lots of rich butterscotch and cookie coupled with fruits in the raisin-prune family.  The palate was creamy and chewy.  I wished the nose was as strong as the flavor and palate was.

12 oz bottle into English pint. Pours a ruby head to brown with a nice beige pillowy head. Leaves patchwork lace. Aroma is some kind of tart fruit, SweeTarts, bread--muted, though. Taste is bittersweet. Alcohol and cinnamon are noticeable. Has a creamy mouthfeel, medium-high carbonation and a medium-full body. Nice beer.
26th December 2007  Deep cherry red-brown clear beer. Sweet malt with a trace of cream and fruit. Floral notes. Leads to a hoppy dry finish with more malt. Not that bitter.
Another excellent brew from Great Divide. This beer is a must every holiday season. Very rich and tasty.

08-01-11 Bottled on 12 nov 2009: Belle couleur rubis rouge, avec une tr√®s l√©g√®re effervescence et une belle mousse √©paisse et cr√©meuse couleur cr√®me. Aromes de biscuit au beurre, de farine avec des notes de cheapit au chocolat, de fruits rouge et une touche houblonn√©e. En bouche, houblon et malt se bagarre pour prendre le dessus. Les saveurs de biscuits et de beurre laisse la place a une petite ametume r√©sineuse et vice-versa. Asser sucr√©e, elle a une asser grande amertume pour une bi√®re port√©e vers le malt de m√™me qu¬íune toute petite note surette. Par contre, la bataille des saveurs ne laisse pas asser de place a une saveur dominante, ce qui fait un l√©ger manque de gout. Corps moyen, avec une texture l√©g√®rement cr√©meuse et une finale amer et astringente.
pours a very dark brown, malty with caramel on the nose. taste has cocoa, maltyness, and caramel. palate is great with a medium mouthfeel. a pretty decent beer.
Pours dark brown.  Very malty aroma with burn sugar notes.  The taste is perfect for the long, cold winters.  One of my favorite beers.

The aroma is supremely earthy, soil-like malt. Dusty mocha chocolate and cocoa powder.Really "dry" aroma. Just the faintest hint of a woody hop. Complex. 

The appearance is shiny ruby red, medium carbonation. Decent slushy head.

The flavor is a base of cured wood hops and fertile soil, with a touch of hazelnut. Very nutty taste, in fact, with a curiously cherry finish.

The palate is chunky but dry and sandpapery. It¬ís a dry, nutty piece of action. Roasted in spots and dryly nutty in the finish.
Boathouse Conshohocken on tap. Pours a dark amber with a lacing head. Nice sweet start with a more than average alcohol taste. Average beer. Solid but not special.

2009 vintage. Deep clear brown, thin light brown rim hugging messy lacing making head. Hoppy, roasty nose, woody, massive malts, caramel, smooth coffee, medium chocolate, walnuts. Good flavor that might set in just above some similar offerings. I¬ím surprised that at 8.7% I can taste some alcohol. Mild hops, odd bitterness and something close to heat, some coffee and lesser chocolate, notable spice and bit of harshness. Mouthfeel and related bitterness and harshness don¬ít work for me. Maybe I held on to this too long. Unimpressed. Too many hops.

Great Divide Hibernation Ale.
Brown color.  Aroma of burnt sugars, toasted grains, roasted barley.  Loads of malts.  Flavor of whoa, alcohol.  Burnt sugar, dates, dark fruits.  Finishes with a wooded earthy hop bite.  

8,4,8,4,16

2006 vintage courtesy of Doodler, never even trade with this guy and he sends me this! as an extra to an even more awesome bottle!  thank you so much! 12oz, 8.1% abv. drinking very well. this is the first i have ever had of this brew, so i cant say whether its better fresh or not. but this has aged very well. it reminds me of anchors osa in the finish and aftertaste. and the fact that there is no oxidation after nearly 5 years.  pours a very deep crimson color, seems murky but is crispy clear if held to the light. the aroma is nice; old, slight musk and dust, past the prime hops, and tons of sweet carmel biscuits! great old ale, awesome vintage, what a treat!

Bottle, poured into pint glass. Aroma is huge and has a wine kinda nearly zinfandel/syrah thing mixed with wood, great nose. Appearance wise, this is gorgeously clear and yet dark red, fantastic color. Taste is hugely malty with a maltball/chocolate overtone. Really big beer, not a chugger but a sipper. Great beer from Great Divide.

Bottle. Happened on a 6-pack of this a while back and I¬ím glad I did. Very nice balance of malts and hops; malts are prominent in the front, but finishes off bitter and smooth. Toffee and caramel flavors complement the malt while still maintaining a hearty bready quality. Great for hiding inside by the fire--a very aptly named beer.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2012 Bottle. Copper with a beige head. A Great Divide aroma of buttery malt; also (dried) pineapple and peaches, toffee and some spices. Taste: toffee, spices, pepper, medium bitter, earthy hops and some (dried) tropical fruits. Quite a long finish with a spicy bitterness. Medium-bodied with noticeable carbonation. A bit odd but nice.

Nose: Weak and yeastish - some nuts.
Taste: Nuts with a dry bitterness.
After taste: Also dry - not really pleasant.
my favorite winter beer. a straight forward beer with no spice or fruit added. i look forward to this beer every winter.

A very tasty dark purplish brew. Sweet malty aromas and flavors. Chocolate notes. Well balanced with the hops too, but still on the sweet side. Very intense and heavy warming body. Perfect for a snowy day like this!

Mahogany pour beige head light lacing .... malty and citrusy hop aroma mostly caramel malt .... taste is of chewy caramel malt and bitter biscuity and sticky/sweet some citrusy hop .... bitter hop and warming boozy finish ... very rich and well put together

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Dark ruby colour with small, off-white head with lots of lacing. Aroma is sweet, roasty and malty with notes of caramel, chocolate, nuts and pine hops (probably Centennial). Taste is also quite sweet with a bitter ending. Sticky mouthfeel, medium bodied and some alcohlic notes, though well hidden. Very nice at this time of the year.
Surprisingly no alcohol flavor. This is light, smoky, and has a nice salty molasses flavor to it. A good slow, part beer.

Great Divide goes for a to-style old ale, pouring a deep clear copper. Capped with a strong off-white head, Hibernation ale shows ample leather molasses, raisin and sharp piny hop notes. Full bodied, this brew shows its heat on the way down and ends in a long malt-forward finish with hop resins lending a balancing bitterness in the fade.

Pours clear dark brown with small shortlived bubbly tanned head. Intense aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, fidges, port wine and caramel. Full bodied malty mouthfeel. Flavor is malty, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, slightly acidy and sweet. Very strong malty and sweet palate. Finishes with a great tart and dry hoppy aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Pours brown with a tiny head. Aroma has alot of chocolate, coffee, nuts and sweet malts. Taste contains all of this along with some Hazelnuts, cocoa and Honey. This was very enjoyable on a cold winter night.

Pours ruby with one finger head; thin soapy lace. Nose of caramel malt, dark fruit, oak, and a hint of soap and booze. Taste similar to nose missing the hop overload that was expected. Maybe an old bottle? Or is this par for the style?
Pours dark brown with an average tan head. Aroma is somewhat roasty with chocolate notes. Taste is of coffee and dark fruit and faint caramel notes.

Bottle. Deep ruby red with a off-white head. Rich sweet aroma with caramel and dried fruit, pine, chocolate, butterscotch and passion fruit. More of thesame in the mouth. The alcohol is there and in the boarder line of taking too much of the stage. Nice oily mouthfeel and a good bitter finish.

355ml Bottle - Copper red with a tan head. Pine, spruce, grapefruit, caramel and malt in the aroma. Hoppy and malty taste with nots of pine, toffee, nuts and dried fruit. Nicely balanced and drinks well for its strength.

Pours out amber with lots of creamy head. Taste is sweet malt and bitter hops. Roasty and sweet toffee flavors upfront with some bitterness from the spicey hops. Great caramel and spice notes. Good balance crisp and complex. One of my favorite holiday brews.
Pours a dark amber with red hues. Aroma of hazelnut, chocolate, roasted grain.  Flavor is dried fruit, nuts, caramel, peat, floral. Many complex flavors. Quite nice on a cold night.

Bottle at Gr√ºnerl√∏kka Brygghus. Dark, dark reddish brown, thin creamy beige head. Aroma of dry, powdery chocolate, cocoa, something very fresh and herbal, spruce twigs, a hint of anise or liquorice, dark fruits. Rum raisin. And it smells floury powdery in a way, if a smell could have texture. A solid chocolate sweetness is ridden by the herbal freshness on the tongue. Burnt malts, light smoke. The more tender fruity and sweet notes can¬ít really cope with the bitterness. The finish feels a bit wine gum like. Would probably be good aged a little, though people have said something about Great Divide beers not aging well. Not sure about that. Anyways. A slight balance problem. A smooth, round mouthfeel. Oddly, there¬ís quite a bit of carbonation here, but it¬ís not fizzy or harsh. Lively but subtle. The bubbles feels very small and pearly. All in all, good but a bit off balance.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel/toffee, & dark fruit; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, molasses, dark fruit (notably plums), hops, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, really good brew.

Pours with a frothy amber-tan colored head that is a finger thick. The beer is a clear deep amber color that shows a deep ruby color when held up to the light. The aroma is quite malty with notes of caramel and toffee up front moving to a dry lightly roasted note. Tastes like a toasty brown ale. Perhaps there is a bit of cherry like fruit character as well, but this is fairly subdued.

The beer has a medium full heft to it, but does not really coat the mouth too much. The beer is lightly sweet with notes of toffee and a light molasses. The finish is a mix of toasted malt notes, a bit of coffee, and a roast grain character. There is a combination of the sweet malt notes and the slight alcohol heat in the finish.

This beer is actually quite nice. The malt character is refreshingly unhoppy, and makes for a great sipping beer.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Created a small layer head while the liquid was a dark shade of mahogany. As for the aroma, there was a sweet balance between caramel and assorted nuts that reminded me a lot of a brown ale style.  The flavor is intensely sweet with a rich thick base of molasses syrup, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, and a nice addition of oily hops. Certainly impressive ale and hits me just right during a chilly day in autumn.

Aroma: Earthy, spicy, caramel, raisins, malty.

Appearance: Dark coppery pour, ruby highlights, dense foamy tan head with really good lacing.

Taste: Flavor is sweet caramel malt, coffee, earth, alcohol (though not hot), dark fruit. Nicely hopped finish that balances well with the maltiness.

Palate: Medium, nicely carbonated.

Overall: Very fine old ale. An extremely well-balanced brew that compares well with others of the type. Very enjoyable.
12 oz bottle. Pours a cola color  with a tan head. The aroma is chocolaty and roasty. The flavor is nice and heavy on the malt with a touch of hops at the end. Thick on the palate. Nice beer.
Might be my new favorite holiday beer. Bold and strong simple taste. British tasting to me. Good alcohol bite to it. Big malty taste. I like the dark Great Divide dark beers.

Bottle. Darkish amber with big tan foam. Aroma is chocolate, butterscotch, citrus and sweet dark dried fruit. Taste is similar to the aroma;chocolate, caramel, butterscotch and piney and citrusy hops. Mainly a sweet beer but with a nice citrusy bitter aftertaste. Full body, creamy and sticky texture, soft carbonation, bitter finish that gets a tad astringent at the end. A little alcoholic is noticable but not disturbing and only adding to flavor complexity. Overall; I like this a lot, malty , citrusy and the way I love my american beers
Bottle:  Nice dark dark amber.  Aroma not too overpowering, pleasantly malty.  Nice heavy sweetness overlaying the alcohol.  Fairly creamy palate.  Excellent with a pork chop.

Pours dark brown with a slight red coloring and a thin off-white head. Aroma is of caramel, molasses, plums. Flavor is quite mellow and transitions nicely from a slight hoppy front to a smooth and sweet finish.
Pours deep amber with beige head and foamy lacing.  Notes of pine and plum.  Taste seems a bit harsh, with a bitter finish and an unexpected tang.

I¬íd put this in about the same category as what American homebrewers call a Scotch ale. It is strong, dark but not roasty like a stout or porter and the malts are pushed up in front of the hops. It¬ís color is a nice, deep read, almost purple. The head fades quickly but does leave a few spots of lace. A rum raisin sweetness dominates the nose, along w/ some toasted biscuity malts. Flavor is rather more dry than you¬íd expect from the nose, which lends drinkability. Still, this beer is hefty and thick w/ very mild carbonation. It¬ís a bit boozy which works in this case. This is definitely a slow sipper and unapologetically so. It drinks even bigger than it¬ís nearly nine percent alcohol content. That is a good thing. Enjoy.

Poured a deep amber with a nice head.  Aroma gives off hints of toffee, roast and prunes.  Tastes toffee up front, with a nice bitterness and ends roasty and toasty with some molasses notes.  This is a nice malty drink and definitely has the old ale feel on the palate.  Great beer.

From the bottle.  Very malty aroma.  Mahogany color.  Tastes of nuts, dried fruit, alcohol, raisins; good balance of malt and hops.  Mouthfeel is medium- bodied, effervescent, and mildly syrupy.  Bitter finish lingers a while. Not your usual spicy holiday ale. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours a deep red, almost purple.  Smells of caramel, plum, some booziness, oak.  Perhaps some faint orange in it.  Medium mouthfeel.  Taste is similar to smell...tastes almost more like a barleywine than an "old ale", but that¬ís more nitpicking than anything.
I like the ABV. Also has a good price point. It is very smoky and yet the alcohol gives it a nice sweetness, like barbeque. The aftertaste is strong but short lived. Kinda bitter, but pleasantly so.

I came up with a Haiku for this beer:
Hibernation beer
Won¬ít you come near my lips
with your stellar suds.

Tap @ Great Divide brewery. Pours dark amber with a small light brown head. Nose is caramel, barley, hints of oak, spices, toffee. Taste is rich roasted malts, toffee, caramel, spices, chocolate, and some dry bitterness in the finish. Full bodied, low carbonation, warming alcohol finish.041210

Appearance:  dark ruby brown with a short creamy head.  Aroma:  lots of sweetness:  maple syrup, nuts, toffee, caramel, chocolate, peanut brittle.  Taste:  dark, rich sweetness of maple, molasses, chocolate, nuts and caramel, with some dry and lightly bitter hops at the end.  Finish:  dry, slightly bitter hops and a lovely belly-warming alcohol.  Notes:  Extremely rich and sweet, yet very well-balanced with the dryness of the hops coming through at the back.  A winter sipper.

12 oz bottle from New Seasons - Dark brown with minimal head (thus knocking down the appearance category).  Makes up for it with a rich, complex flavor.  Sweet and strong at the same time.  Makes you feel very warm and like you need to brush your teeth.

Really a great, full and rich winter warmer.  Dark toast, chewy caramel, a bright hoppiness and really a great all-around palate.  Long and justifiably accelerated by nearly 9 percent alcohol, but so much aggressive flavor on the profile that it¬ís also easy to drink.

Ruby amber with little head. Aroma sweet chocolate, candy, hops. Taste sweet candy, chocolate malt balanced with hops. Full body, text smooth, alcohol notable but welcoming. Finish with long bitterness.
12oz bottled on 13 Oct 10 - Brown/red with small tan head.  Malt nose, abrupt caramel smack, quickly deferring to a bitter finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep amber with a fluffy light tan head. Aroma is a bit nutty, doughy, with plenty of dark fruit and raisins, toffee fairly sweet and bready. Flavor starts sweet with some dark fruit, a touch of sweet candy toffee, molasses, picks up a bit of spice before a slightly herbal and earthy hop finish. Medium creamy body and a sharper carbonation. Very  nice and soft classic english beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark amber with a small, short lived, tanned head.  Aroma is of bready malt, ripe fruit with hints of coffee.  Full, smooth body.  Rich caramel and bready malt, ripe fruit are balanced by earthy hops on the palate, some hints of coffee as well.  Long, dry, earthy finish.  Nice, after dinner brew.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours dark brown with a thin foam. Aroma is sweet with hints of coffee. Taste is somewhat sour with some alcohol on the onset and sweet and coffee in the midtones. Overall it is a great beer, not really my style but still great.
Robust and malty, just as the Hibernation Ale is described. Yet smooth. A really nice X-mas-beer. I had it together with a Camembert-cheese and that was delic.

Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is mostly nutty malt, sweet caramel, and a touch of dark fruit. Also some surprisingly hop presence. Flavor is much the same. Bad rating, but a good beer.

Draft at Coles, Buffalo, NY. pours a rich looking mahogany brown with some reddish maroon hues. Rich malts fill the aroma, chcolate colored cherries. Taste is heavy chocolate malts up front. This pretty much dominates the palate, medium bitterness in the finish. Not too boozy but warming. Nice fireplace sipper

Appearance: burnt rich heavy mahogany hues; old. Small head the color of sawdust and wood. Swirls with no lace while her thin head recedes into oblivion. A thick pour.

Nose: oh how I love English style Barleywines and old ales¬Ö melted chocolate and fudge; like walking into a chocolate shop where the air is thoroughly permeated with all the goodness inside. Vanilla flitters to and fro. Dark fruits are a faint whisper in the back along with some black cherries. Chocolate dominates, joining the dark fruits for some chocolate covered dates and figs, dried please.

Palate: first quaff and I am right back in chocolate heaven. Burnt essence underneath with the dryness of charred wood and burnt black chocolates. Marshmallows roast while the top of my tongue has a light dry chalkiness to it; dry old ash. Wood lingers along the side of my tongue. Raisins, prunes, cherry stones all lurk underneath for a sturdy pedestal upon which all things chocolate stand. Little to no spice, though warmth does slowly curl her fingers around my chest.

Final Thoughts: the more Great Divide beers I taste, the more I fall in love with their brewing prowess. I also believe that as the years pass they have really improved their brewing game as evidence by this luxurious Barleywine. Delicious.

It¬ís a winner in every category-a memorable English farmhouse ale made for aged cheddars and roasts.  My favorite aspect of this one is the balance between the fresh, bitter hops, malty molasses and anise spice flavors.

Aroma of rich malts, coffee.  Med head.  Bottle poured a nice copper color; clear.  lots of lacing.  Med bitterness taste, lite sweet malt tones.  Med to full bodies.   Creamy texture.  Ave to soft carbonation.    Bitter finish.  Can pick up the alcohol in the taste.  Notes of wood finish.   Complex.

aroma is faint roasted malts and scotch. very thin off white head. color is a clear medium dark orange and brown. taste is a woody scotch flavor. also a bit malty.  decently balanced. very drinkable. very pleasurable brew.

Bottle:  Pours a dark reddish brown [SRM 20] with a decent foamy tan head if you pour down the center.  Aroma is burnt grains and subtle hints of malt.  This has a medium body with a sweet smooth finish.  The flavor is dominated by malts with hints of celery root and coffee in the finish.  I wasn¬ít impressed with my first sip but as I let it sit and warm a bit this beer really started to grow on me.  I have to also give them credit for completely hiding the alcohol in this beer.  For as strong as it is, I didn¬ít notice any of that typical alcohol bite.

Bottle from Sam¬ís in Durham.  Pours dark copper, clear without much head.  Nose is rich malts up front with hops showing themselves in the background, and a mild, vague spice profile.  Slight woody notes.  Tastes shows more hops.  I think this might be better after six months, a year or so, but it¬ís quite good 3 weeks old as well.
Bold Flavor.  Starts with a malty sweet taste and ends with a strong slightly hopped finish.  Nice balance great aroma.  Overall a great winter beer
Pours a dark brown with a light brown foam. Smells sweet of roasty malts. Flavors of loccorice, coffee, walnuts and chocolate dominate a sweet and bitter body.
Aroma is sweet, roasted and malty. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, nuts and red fruits, sweet with moderatly hoppy finish.

There is a dark redwood coloring and a solid brown head when the beer is poured. An aroma of coffee  arises from the glass. The flavor consist of a sweet roasted coffee mixed with a syrupy molasses. There is also a bit of toffee/caramel flavoring, also.

Bottle.Pours reddish brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet with some dark berries ,grains, malt ,bread and yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty with a lot of fruitiness. Medium to full body, soft carbonation.Nice fruity ale.

Lucent mahogany, thick dense tan head, creamy full body, medium but soft carbonation.

Aroma: sweet roasted malt, earthy hops, bready yeast, with hints of alcohol and candied fruit.

Taste: loads of chocolaty roasted malt, burnt sugar, with some leafy hops and hints of charred grain and alcohol warmth in the finish.

Very drinkable and balanced, but complex and hefty. Great texture - it sounds weird, but i want to say flannel or velveteen rather than silky or velvety - like it¬ís soft and smooth but not slippery. I would love to clone this and add just a hint of rauch malt. And the wood-aged versions, if not too oaky, must be amazing.

I think Great Divide did a decent job on this usually one-dimensional type. Fairly medium bodied, ruby in color, a well balanced nose without the off-putting cigar sans sweaty socks aroma, and packed in some crisp, cleanliness highland style.
A must for all fans of English style malty goodness.  Not as hoppy as I would like but I am biased with a love of IPAs.  Great color and taste, you have to try if English ales are your go-to brew.
The thing that stands out is a big and I mean big celery root, woody, earthy flavor. I thought it was OK but I don¬ít think I would buy again. Not my cup of tea.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Clear ruby red brown colour. Orangy head. Aroma is malty, caramel, dried fruits, bitter orange and spice but also very hoppy. Taste is brown sugary sweet with a quite sharp bitterness like tobacco. Hops. Quite boozy. Theres also fruits and spice but the tobacco and the alcohol take over a bit for me. Like the hops though.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark garnet with a thin tan head that fizzes away quickly.  Aroma of cocoa, milk chocolate-covered cherries, red berries, and some earthy/piney notes.  Flavor is fresh, bitter pine, earthy dirt and bark, and alcohol.  Dark fruit and cocoa in the finish, with some sweet malt.  Bitter, earthy, medium carbonation, warming, and a dry finish.  Really nicely balanced malty and bitter beer, with a pleasant warming quality; nice for a cool night.

12 oz. bottle, pours hazy dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of maple syrup, brown sugar and molasses. Flavour follows this aroma profile, with intensely sweet molasses, and a thick, syrupy palate. Too cloyingly sweet, I¬íd say, though decently enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 Cool, dark hoppy aroma with a little sweetness from the outset, coming right off a rich,  dark, mostly opaque crimson body. There¬ís a bit of beige head that¬ís a little frothy and sticks to the glass a bit. Well balanced taste  and a little bit of bitterness in the middle that leaves a subtle sweetness on your tongue. Very crisp, cool feel, that is incredibly smooth.  Overall a great beer, very drinkable. Definitely a high alcohol content that leaves you with that warm, hearty feeling in your gut.

Another tasting: really surprised me with how chocolatey it smells and tastes. I don¬ít remember it being like that. Still remarkably smooth throughout with that beautiful warming sensation. I love it just as much now as I did then.

Tasted on tap at the brewery in Denver, Colorado.  Pours a red-brown appearance with a thin disappearing head.  Kind of a wine or grain alcohol aroma which is characteristic of an old ale.  A bit fruity start followed by a fairly intense body that exhibits the higher alcohol.  Finish is dry.  Pretty good old ale.
2009 bottle, dark amber color, slight lacing, a year in the bottle has really mellowed the alcohol. Deep caramel, some tobacco. A year has done Hibernation well, I love it. 5 bottles left.

12 oz. bottle- bottling date oct. 13 2010- Pours clear reddish brown with a off white thin head, lacework is exceptional. Strong caramel malts in the aroma as well as a mild hop presence. The flavor has a mellow caramel chocolate malt and alcohol is present, there is a woody flavor also probably from the aging, a good, very complex beer.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2016 Clear, dark, reddish-amber with a small tan head. Delicious aroma of chocolate and caramel malts and hops. Taste is a load of dark chocolate and roasted malts, wood and hops. Full bodied and smooth, robust, but with the alcohol well disguised.

October 13 2010  bottle, consumed 11/7/2010
Pours deep ruby with a medium tan head.  Nose contains a lot of resiny hops, some dark fruit undertones and a little bit of chocolate and caramel character.  Almost no sweetness, the flavor bursts with roasted notes with some mild bitterness.  Mouthfeel is creamy, well-carbonated, full.  It¬ís a decent enough brew but there¬ís a lot more roast presence and not enough underlying maltiness for my taste.  The nose lacks a bit for an old ale as well.

Bottle. 2010 batch.  Pours a ruby-brown hue, little dusting of faint off-white foam.  Aromas are of citrus peel, dark wood, and caramel.  Up front taste is smoothly dark and bitter, while not at all heavy.  Mid palate is spritely and full of citrus zest, before mellowing to a quiet, brooding woody bitter finish.  Just an excellent example of the style, with very subtle alcohol presence, felt only in the final burn going down the gullet.  Lovely.

Bought this one in a six pack on a wim because it was only $9.99  I think it was mis-labled.  Anyway, Excellent old ale with not much of the tradition "musty" flavor old world beers have in them.  Good smelling yeast, nice amount of carbonation for a winter ale.  Deep cherry, and wood come off of the smell and the taste first.  followed up by a pleasant long lasting hop backbone that lingers for a long time.  Nice drinkability and overall construction.  I believe I had this one last season but just never rated it.  This will always be a great offering in my mind.

This 12 oz bottle of the 2010 vintage (no cellaring) poured a deep red into my snifter, raising a one-finger head that seemed substantial for an old ale. This, along with the lacing that followed, suggested that this was not a typical "drinks like a meal" barleywine-ish ale. The nose bore this out, with distinct hop notes weaving their way among the expected molasses and cigar aromas. The flavor followed suit, leaving an overall effect halfway between an old ale and some of the American Strong Ales such as Red Rocket or Yakima Twilight. Due to its similarity to those ASAs, this is more of a drinker than a sipper. In other words, it is pretty close to the perfect old ale for someone like me who isn¬ít always crazy about the style.

Draught at OT, Stockholm.
Unforunantly no head and only litle CO2.
Dark brandy color. Dark chocolate aroma. Coffey taste with a clean bitterness and small residual sweetness.

12 oz.Bottle: The aroma contains lots of chocolate and caramel along with some roasted nuts and alcohol. It pours a deep reddish-Brown with a quarter inch beige head.  Very thick lacing.The flavor starts with some chocolate and caramel. The finish has some watery roasted nut flavors with some strong citrusy hops and just a hint of alcohol. Overall the flavor is good however, I can get the biter hoppy finish.  I¬ím not a fan of bitter beers. So I deducted a few marks because of it.  It¬ís medium bodied with mild carbonation and a soft mouthfeel. I rally wouldn¬ít buy again... but I¬ím not educated in this style of brew.

Bourgogne red to dark amber color. Off-white head.

Aroma is corn, boiled vegetables, hay and roasted malt.

Taste is sweet but not too sweet with flavours of toast and roasted  malt, cane sugar and bergamot. Some nuttiness.

Smooth but dry mouthfeel. A bit boozy.

It¬¥s ok, but I remembered it as being better.

2010 vintage out of a 12 ounce bottle.

Pours a crystal clear mahogany/deep-ruby liquor with a thin, sandy-colored head that quickly dissipates to lace.  The bouquet is faint, sweet and malty with a hint of yeast and less so of bread.

The body is medium-full.  The attack is a rich, semi-sweet mingling of chocolate, coffee and tobacco, with just a hint of alcohol before the finish.  As it warms the sweetness is balanced with some offsetting bitterness.  The finish isn¬ít long, but adds a sour note to the whole.  This is another Great Divide product that features a mature and complex m√©lange of flavors.  

Quite nice.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a nonic pint int glass. Bottled on Oct 06 2010 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a deep mahogany brown with ruby highlights and a 1-2 finger creamy light tan head. Decent lacing.

Smell: Toasted malt with hints of sweet caramel and some mild bready and nutty notes. 

Taste: Toasted bread up front followed by sweet caramel malt and roasted nuts in the middle and ending with a burnt flavor and mild hops at the finish. Aftertaste is bittersweet chocolate.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Almost chewy in texture. 

Drinkability: Above average drinkability. This is a sipper that would be good on a cold winter night. I wouldn¬ít want another one, however.

Overall: Very solid beer overall. Great Divide keeps making solid beers. Give this one a shot.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2011 Pours a clear, dark red. Light aroma, 1/2" head, smooooooth body. Hmmm, this may very well be my favorite Great Divide beer. Complex taste, solid body, very smooth, warming...this seasonal nails what a winter ale should be.

Best new beer I have had in a while, light and fluffy but also dark and malty at the same time, hints of vanilla, caramel, and coffee as well as other flavors I cannot identify, complex, but also very good, not over the top.  Awesome winter beer.  Slight taste of a barleywine as well.  Very interesting.

poured from 12 oz bottle - Pours one of the most beautiful shades of amber I have ever seen.  Smells of chocolate and fruits?  Malty madness comes through and is tempered with hops.  What we have here is a good beer that is a heavy hitter.
Poured dark brown, roasted malts, molasses, dark chocolate, nutty, little dark fruit.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2010 On tap @ Great Divide.  Brownish ruby in color, ivory bubbly/fluffy head. I was enticed and intrigued at the smell. It was malty chocolatey much like their Yeti. Some brown sugar and a mild hop backbone on the smell. Taste has a nutty flavor, like peanuts. Initially it hits with milk chocolate, transforms into earthy malts, then into straight peanut-buttery aftertaste. Hops play on the palate without being too substancial, yet the beer as a whole remains balanced and smooth. A wonderful winter treat!

A: The pour is a clear, dark mahogany color with a minimal off-white head forming that quickly dies away.

S: Mildly sweet toffee, brown sugar, and molasses come through up front. Some mild hints of dark fruits, namely plums and black cherries. Not really any alcohol, which is good.

T: Not quite as impressive in terms of the flavor. Toffee and molasses, with perhaps a hint of nutty bread. Not really sweet, or bitter, or fruity. Sort of boring.

M: Medium body with a low carbonation that is somewhat smooth.

D: The aroma of this beer got my hopes up, but the flavor was certainly a let down. Maybe a little age would help this one out.
From a bottle,Dark Ruby,white head,chocolate,fruity,amazing winter seasonal,great flavor .

Tap @ Fish Tale Brewpub. Clear, dark amber pour with a tan head leaving a fine, moderate lace. Caramel and brown sugar up front, with burnt caramel entering in the middle and lasting through the finish. Medium body, low carbonation. Smooth with a superb mouth feel, which makes this very drinkable and even sessionable.

12oz bottle pours mohogany with minimal head.  Aroma is oatmeal with  brown sugar upfront with fruity carmel, toffee, and chocolate notes.  Taste is toasted carmel toffee malt with a smokey hoppy taste upfront.  Notes os fruit with a medium sweetness, full body, with a bitter finish.  Very Complex

Bottle thanks to jcwattsrugger. Drank in honor of the Chilean mine rescue. Pours reddish brown. Nose of winter spices, booze and malts. Taste is very malty, toasted chestnuts, roasted malts and winter spices.

Pours a deep golden brown color, nose was heavy on burnt sugars, taste was deep and complex, different levels of caramel ranging from sweet to slightly burnt, hints of fruitiness, and surprisingly drinkable.

This is my kinda old ale. Pours cloudy red brown with a medium sized offwhite head, spider web lace. Smells sweet and malty with a big red fruit hop presence. Caramelly sugary sweet. Tastes about the same. Sweet and malty and caramelly overall with a big, sweet, red fruit, hop presence. Nice. Full body, subdued carbonation.

Pours a medium brown with a beige head that doesn¬ít go anywhere fast.  The beer smells like heavy bread, coffee and roasted malts.  This beer has a strong flavor with a lot of body.  It is a bit bitter and has hints of woodsmoke.  This isn¬ít the best hibernation ale I¬íve had, but it certainly has a lot of flavor.

Bottle. Pours an amber brown with a foamy head. Malty nose with more bitter hop aromas than I was expecting. Taste is very malty, almost chocolatey, with a surprising amount of hop bitterness. Finishes a little bitter. Alcohol is well hidden. The dry hopping doesn¬ít really mix with the malt characteristic of this beer in my opinion.

Bottle at the brewery.  Our buddy went in the back and grabbed this for us prior to 2010 release to public.  Pours dark brown, with lots of spice, hops, dark fruits including cherries and fig, roasted malts, and lots of happiness.  what an afternoon at Great Divide. thanks guys

Pours rich dark amber with superb heavy head. Aroma of molasses and dried fruit (apricot) with alcohol note. Beautiful looking beer!  Terrific tasting ale, although more bitter than the average UK Barleywine style ale. Great malty taste, hints of wood, hops, sugar, molasses, and cherry. Love this strong ale!

Dark amber brown with a big retaining beige head.  Sharp roasty aroma with a bit of herbal character, toffee, dark fruit.  Flavor is very roasty and rich, with more toffee and dark fruit, a little touch of char, finishes out slightly resinous with herbal, slightly minty character and a welcome alcohol warmth.  If I had to pick a beer to define "winter warmer," this would be a strong contender.

(12 oz bottle)  Pours clear copper with 2" thick beige head. Nice lacing already developing.  Aroma of bread (a nice, thick crusted boule, not the sliced garbage), some caramel and floral notes.  Also getting some resin.  Not really sweet or sour.  Actually, mostly salty with some light dry roasty bitterness-almost smoky.  This is a very savory beer. Medium bodied with a oily/thick texture.  Finish is smooth.  This is a beer I feel like I should always pair with food.  I think this is a nice beer, especially for winter.  Too bad it¬ís almost 100 degrees today.
Red-orange brown, beige foam.  Aroma is malty, sweet, fruit, light spicy hops.  Taste is sweet, apple, plum, caramel, cocoa.  Toast, light grassy spicy hop finish.

Bottle:
Very small beige foamy head.
Dark brown red-ish color.
Smell is terrific, a very full smell of spices and fresh hoppy smell.
Taste is very good too: lots of spices, dark fruits, caramel, wood, hints of hops and some roasted malts.
The bitterness is pretty low and perfectly balanced with sweets and spices.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Dark golden brown with a creamy off white head. Caramel spice malt and alcohol aroma and taste.

Bottle at Taco Mac.  Poured a dark red with no head, didn¬ít leave any lace either.  Aroma was of some earthy hops and caramel malts.  Taste was of some sweet malts and a nice lingering bitterness.  Good malty mouthfeel with just a hint of bittersweetness in the finish.  Another good one from the dudes @ Great Divide.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark red-brown color with a head that disappears quickly. Aroma is coffee, caramel, and hops. Surprisingly light on the palate, but really warms me up somehow. None of the flavors are very strong, but i get some hops, maybe some cherries, and a little caramel. A little coffee aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2010 Bottle bought from Utobeer, Borough Market, London 18 months ago. An amber coloured pour with a small beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel. Tastes malty, caramel, dark fruit. Easy drinking ale.

Aroma:Malty, hoppy, alcohol.

Appearance:Amber, clear, foam is medium.

Taste:Very hoppy, lots of roasted malt, a little raisin. slightly nutty. A dry finish. Some alcohol heat.

Palate:Smooth and creamy. Alcohol warmth.

Overall:A little too hoppy to really enjoy, and the hops used are not the most flavorful.

Rich, malty bbrew with treacle, figs and prunes.
Enough bitter hops packed in to balance. Complex beer, every sip reveals soemthing new. Malt and pine in the finish.

The body is crystal clear reddish-copper with a thin and lingering khaki colored head. The aroma is full of pinewood and toffee mixed with earthy spice.

There¬ís a distinct chocolate flavor that permeates this beer, kind of a mix of very dark chocolate and cocoa. Lightly roasty with a hint of smoke. But a lot of toffee and fruity, oaky malt in here as well. A woody mouthfeel, if that makes any sense. A bit like having the reed of a saxophone in your mouth. Lingering sweetness and herbal hoppiness in the finish.

Really extraordinary beer. Get some if you can.

Sampled a recent tasting. I believe this one was provided by thirdeye11. 

2006 vintage sampled in May 2010. The beer pours a nice brown color with a tan head. The aroma is heavy on the caramel, chocolate and toffee malts. The flavor is chocolate milk and toffee. The alcohol is faded and this is extremely easy drinking. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
caramel, citrus, grape, chocolate, cacao, pine, brown, cloudy, tan foam, medium sweetness, very bitter, medium body, sticky, lively, long finish, bitter,
This tastes sooooo brown, double brown, quadruple brown. Molasses with a little pine, burnt toffee finish. I love this beer! Even better when aged a few years. I¬ím drinking the 2009 now.

Draft sample at the 2nd Annual Rocket City Brewfest. Amber with off-white head that had some yellow highlights. Settled to a ring and left light lace. Aromas of chocolate, roast, and molasses. The flavor found chocolate, roast, a hoppy background, and hints of nut. Medium body, sweet beginning and a slight bitter end. Molasses malt aftertaste.

Bottle: Poured a reddish rusty amber with a thin off white cream head. Aroma is a mixed bag of hops, spice, and malt. Taste is a rich roasted malt sweet up front and then a lingering bitter hop finish. Leaves the mouth warm.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99 Very good!

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2010 On Tap. Pours a clear dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma & taste: Roasted malts, bold hops, citrus & pine, mild notes of chocolate & coffee. Good body. Aftertaste: roasted malts and hop bitterness. Overall a good beer. I thought this brew tasted like a good Porter mixed with a DIPA... both evenly balanced but still bold.
Note: this rate was for the on tap version; the bottles of this beer I have had since were not as good: the taste was not as defined and balance was not there.
Decent in small doses, but way too sweet. Sweet malts, mainly prunes, dominate the flavor. Syrupy, heavy mouthfeel. Sweet finish with some alcohol. Not the most drinkable beer.

Very dark brown pour, loads of chocolate and some great peaty smokiness also. Flavor is full bodied and very smokey. More cocoa Nd some cofffee come through in the finish. Leaves a nice sweet mollasses aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2010 Great Divide Brewing Company--Hibernation Ale--Old Ale--English--12 oz. Bottle.  8.10% ABV--65 IBU.s.?

2005 Release.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Mild lacy head.  Clear rich black cherry red color.  Toasted malty rich hop front.  Roasted spicy sweet thick burnt caramel spice body.  Tangy hot hop nutmeg spices end.  Rich & spicy but too sweet.  Sampled 11/23/2005.

2006 Winter Ale 45 IBU? Release.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Rich lacy tan head.  Clear dark ruby brown red color.  Malty mild burnt cinnamon hop front.  Rich thick sweet roasted malty toffee mild Winter malt spice body.  Hot EtOH hop spice end.  Big Winter.  Sampled 1/13/2007.

2007--Old Ale--Winter Ale--45 IBU¬ís.?  (4.0 / 5.0)  6-Pack $10.99.  Mild lacy head.  Clear bright dark ruby red black color.  Rich malt spice toasted hop front.  Cloying thick sweet toasted toffee caramel big malty Old Ale body.  Hot mild hop spice cloying tangy malt EtOH fruity hint end.  A touch too sweet.  Sampled 4/3/2008.

Hibernation Ale--Malty--English Style Old Ale--Robust--2008 12 oz. Bottle.  8.10% ABV--45 IBU¬ís.?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Old Ale--Winter Ale--Dense lacy off white head.  Clear dark mahogany bronze color.  Toasted dry hopped malt ester front.  Roasted chocolate hint mild sweet rich toffee body.  Tangy hop spice malt EtOH end.  Big, Balanced, Complex & Tasty.  Sampled 2/13/2009.  6-Pack $10.99.

Great Divide Brewing Company--Hibernation Ale--English-Style Old Ale--Malty--Robust-- 12 oz. Bottle.  8.70% ABV.  45 IBU¬ís?  (3.5 / 5.0)  Foamy lacy light tan dense head.  Clear dark deep red color.  Roasted dark fruit mild hop malty fruit ester front.  Thick sweet spicy roasted toffee caramel crusty doughy aged fruity body.  Mildly hot EtOH mildly hop bitter end.  Sampled 10/29/2010 from 6-Pack purchased for $10.99 @ Saleh¬ís Deli--Crown Hill on 1/6/2010.
Has a nice nutty coffee aroma. The appearance is a light black with an off white foam head. The taste is pretty nutty with toffee notes.
Pours a dark, ruby/caramel brown. Little head, lacing and carbonation. Chocolate aroma and flavor. Very complex with heavy malt overtones. Big beer in every way with good balance.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Now this is a great winter warmer. After almost a hundred days of snow in Bergen, this is just the kind of beer I like to step into a bar and pick up. The bar, in this case, is Henrik, Bergen. Pours a clear amber with a small, off-white head. Smell is nougat, vanilla and caramel, with hoppy hints. Niceness. Hibernation Ale is a smoothly blended brew: deep, malty caramel with some hoppiness showing up midway in the sip, turning the taste into strawberry or peaches at some point before vanishing again. Aftertaste is fairly short but pleasant. Despite its smoothly masked ABV, it does give me an almost tender warming feeling. A great ale which should become a classic of its genre.

Bottle from La Birreria Decanter, Milan. Attractive dark brown pour with a decent and lingering tan head. The aroma had plenty of dark fruit alongside the prominent roasted malt. The flavour provided a similar profile but with some really well placed hoppage to balance out the sweetness. Rich and pleasing, a really excellent winter beer.
Dark brown pour. a super malty spicy mouthful.A robust dry hop finish. Nice beer

12oz bottle. Brewed 11/09. Pours a dark amber with a slight head. Very malty but hops still come through. There¬ís alot going on with this one, very complex. Raisins, caramel, more. Sweet, somewhat sticky. More flavors as it warms. Would love to try again after aging for longer.

Bottled 11/18/09. Consumed 2/24/10. 98 Days old. 

A - Malty in a sense of malty. I think. Caramel, chocolate, biscuit, and fruit. 

A - Reddish amber. Tannish head. 

F - Chocolate and a "Fat Tire" Amber malt most prominent. Fruity. Maybe some light pale. Balanced with just the right amount of hops. Quite a few steps down from (Bell¬ís) Third Coast Old Ale, but similarities, nonetheless. 

P - Nicely drinkable. Don¬ít know how many I could actually drink. 8.7% not a challenge at all. More of a perk. Would like to try fresh. Or tapped. But for now, it does the job quite well. Good linger, though not extremely hoppy. And mild-bodied. 

O - After a bit of time, this seems like an amped up Fat-Tire. Maybe just to my palate. After a B9k. But I will give credit. I liked this overall as an easy drinker, but it could be really great with some more *BANG*.
Pours a dark reddish brown with a small beige head that dissipates quickly. Smells like malts, spices and alcohol. Thick full body, you get a malty caramel taste with a bitter/alcohol finish.

Bottle from Vinens Verden, Denmark. Poured cloudy, red brown. Not much head, dissipated quickly. Aroma is caramel and strong hops. Pretty sweet and a little bitter taste, maybe a little flat in the mouth.  Pretty good, definitely recommended if you can get your hands on it.

12oz bottle from Volo. Pours a cloudy brown out of the bottle with a nice sized white head. Aroma is chocolate and hops. Flavor is intense chocolate with a nutty aftertaste. This is probably the most "chocolate" tasting brew i have ever had and it is quite tasty. Alcohol is well hidden which makes this very easy to drink.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep, amber brown with a thin, tan head which quickly dissipates with little lacing.  Woody, nutty malt aroma with hints of chocolate and floral hops.  Heavy, roasted malt aroma up front, tailing off into a rather sweet, citrusy finish, albeit with a strong, bitter alcohol bite.  Maybe a bit sweet, but other than that, a quite delicious ale.

Bottle. 

Clear reddish brown with a small off-white head that leaves a ring of lacings.

The smell is very malty with pleasant hoppy undertones. Notes of caramel, sweet fruits, powdered chocolate and rye bread.

The flavor is sweet and malty. Rich caramel flavors, chocolate and toffee. Perhaps a toasty note and a hint of coffee. Very muted hop aromas. The finish is warming with a touch of alcohol, rye bread and some bitterness. The taste gets blurry and too sweet after a while in the glass. 

Full-bodied with a creamy texture. 

An enjoyable beer, but it lacks some complexity.

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Pours a clear reddish-brown with an off white head. Aromas of cherries, nutmeg, wood, roasted malts, vanilla, bit floral. Very interesting. Flavours of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, sultanas, raisins. Complex. Sharp, vinous flavours in the mouthfeel. Finishes dry and warms the cockles. Perfect for a freezing cold day in the UK. Nice.

(bottle from Cheers Liquor Mart in Colorado Springs, sampled 2/2/10). Clear dark red color, with amber hue. Medium off white head, which is mostly diminishing. Grass/floral hop aroma with light malt. Moderate malt/bitter flavor, with light alcohol. Avg duration. Finish with light sweetness, alcohol, and bitterness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Bottle, 2009 vintage.  Pours a chestnut brown color with two fingers of nutmeg colored creamy head.  Nice aroma is sweet and malty, bready, nutty, and light toffee.  Taste is deeply malty with more bready notes.  Seemingly a little earthy and some florals too.  More nuts.  Chocolate is beginning to show up.  Light floral bitters in the tail.  Overall a very nice brew to enjoy fresh, but I¬íd like to try an aged version as well.

35.5cl bottle from Systembolaget. Best before 2010-10-04. It poured an amber golden colour with a medium big, white creamy head. Aroma is hoppy and a tad bitter. Notes of grass, roasted malts and some citrus. The flavour is both smooth and bitter at the same time. Interesting. Some hops, roasted malts, nuts and some alcohol. Short aftertaste.

Poured a dark brown with thick tanhead that lingered well and left okay lacing. Upon opening, the malt chocolate, toffee and roasted nuts of the aroma fill the nose. The mouthfeel is full and almost chewy, and the taste picks up and accentuates the scents of the nose. My only complaint with this one was toward mid-to-late glass, the thickness of the mouth became sticky, syrupy and a little too sweet. Beyond that, a darned good beer.

Bottled on date of 10/28/09

Pre 2008 the abv was 8.1%. 2009 was bumped up to 8.7%abv.

Poured into a tulip glass. Deep rich ruby red with some burnt orange highlights throughout. Head was about a pinky in thickness and very thin. Little to zero lacing on the glass.

Smell is mostly nutty. Like roasted Brazil nuts. Lots of chocolate from the chocolate malts used. Candied fruit and molasses are also present.

Taste is really good. Lots of nuttiness and chocolate notes. Lots of roasted flavors, caramel toffee and coffee.

Mouthfeel is rich and creamy. Full bodied but really smooth. A touch of alcohol warmth on the finish.

I like this beer. I give it a high drinkability score because of the smoothness of the finish and the great taste. Even with the 8.7%abv. i could drink about 3 of these before i needed to switch it up.
From a bottle poured amber with a good amount of head.  Strong malty flavor with a lingering bitter finish.

botella comprada en spain
aromas a lupulo, resina, un poco a levadura y un poco a frutos secos.
color cobre oscuro, notas de color ambar en color, y al moverla una capa gruesa que se transforma en color oro!!...surrealista...increible..!& color marron claro verdoso.
las burbujas tambien color oro!!...i por debajo de la espuma burbujas gigantes haciendo algo increible!!!....surrealismo puro!!!
poca carbonatacion, poca espuma, buena retencion y buen encaje.
gusto pronunciado a toffee, amargante al final, gustos a citricos y pino.
delicada e invernal...compleja ...interesante...muuuuyyy rica!!!
creo que con un buen chocolate seria lindo!!
mas que nada surrealista!!!
( 12oz bottle) Pours clear dark red/brown with nice oily bubbles. Nose of sweet caramel, pine hops, grass and roasted malt. Taste of grassy hops, coffee, cream with a nice creamy finish.

pours deep brown medium white head. aroma is tons of caramel, roasted malts, nutty, bit of pine and earth. drinks smooth with thick caramel malts and a nice nutty note with a bit of bittering hop at the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 Bottle.  Mahogany pour with a medium beige head.  Aroma is of roasty, caramel malt, some chocolate, and a bit of hops.  Flavor is big:  lots of roasted malt, caramel, lots of nuts, dry hops up front fading to bitter chocolate.  Chewy texture.  The alcohol is there but is not too forceful.  A very tasty, warming winter ale.
had at belgian on tap. pour was dark. aroma was rich malts. nice on the palate. flavor was malty with some hay.

Pours dark brown with a medium light tan head.  Aroma is of caramel malt.  silky smooth body, but a little light.  Flavor is very malty with some alcohol warming.  This is the best Old Ale that I have tried.

[Draft @ CAH} Red brown color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, nuts, dark fruits, toast, and alcohol.  Taste of caramel, dried fruits, some pine, nuts, roast, cocoa, and alcohol.
Dark amber with small white head , rich aroma of malt and a lot of hop - Same taste, malt and a hugehoppy taste that leaves a lingering hop bitterness - well balanced and very good beer
pretty nice brew.  I thought it had a nice blend of hops and matls, hops were slightly bittering to the taste with a hint of spice and a bit of darker fruits in the taste

On tap at Mad Mex. Pours a nice brown color with a finger and a half of tan head. It has a nice malty aroma to it; perhaps a little woody and hoppy as well. The flavor was a tasty mixture of roasted malts, molasses, hops, and more roasted malts on the finish. Good beer for a cold day.

Hazy brown color with generous head at the start, but peters out within minutes.

Nose is tame for a rich winter ale, but noticeable is maple wood, baker¬ís cocoa, and steel.

Palate is full of roasted malt rounded out with miscellaneous Holiday spices. Finishes chewy & chocolatey.

I poured from a bottle to a pint glass.  It gives a nice little foam and the color is a good brown.  You can smell the nice mix of malts combined with the hint of hops.  You can taste the malty character of the beer with the alcohol kick at the end.  Definately a mainstay in my fridge during the winter.
This brew was excellent.  Rich, malty taste and a strong finish.  High alcohol content makes this one a winner in my book.  Will try this one again, for dure.

Pours a very nice light brown/amber.  Aroma is of sweet caramel malt, nuts, and floral hops.  Taste is medium sweet with caramel, and butterscotch while balanced nicely with a generous dose of hops.  Nicely balanced and well put together.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a mahogany orange, with nice frothy off-white head which remains as a small sliver, good lacing.  Subtle malt aroma, caramel, butter.  Balanced flavor, malt backbone, caramel, molasses, with hop bitterness roasted nut malt finish.  Nice and warming, feels smooth and creamy in the mouth.  Overall pretty damn good.
Chewy and complex, you can skip dinner to just drink this beer.  The aroma was delicious:  malty and oaky.
Reddish-brown pour with a light tan head. Aroma is nutty, roasted malt, hoppy, and sweet. Taste is roasted malt, nutty. Has a nice hop finish. Leaves a nice roasted malt aftertaste. Nice lacing.

Pours a clear, dark, ruby with a tan head. The aroma is very sweet, with nuts, caramel, and spices. The flavor is like a lively, hoppier scotch ale. There are some light spices and chocolate on the finish. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

12 oz bottle pours a dark amber with ruby hues. The head was thin and dissaptes quickly - decent lacing. The aroma is dominated by hops malts, malts and some more malts - with some faint hop aroma hidden in the background along with some sweet caramel and molasses. The taste on this brew comes across as a malt monster.  I am not usually that big on beers with this much of a malty flavor but I liked this - it was balanced with some citrus hop that made this a pretty enjoyable beer.

Pouring a gorgeous ruby dark red color.  Half an inch of head that is really staying around quite nicely.  Oatmeal on the nose and of course malts, but a lot of oatmeal there I am getting.  Medium to a full bodied beer.  Great lacing on the glass.  I taste oatmeal, some hops and malts along with hints of chocolate, delicious.  Great beer and a nice spin on the old ale style.

on tap @ Plan B Simsbury. The first thing I noticed about this one was how dark it was, a lot more than i thought. Very easy to drink although I will say that it got a little annoying towards the end of the pint. nice malt butteriness and little carbonation, good hop balance, one of the best winter ales ive had, GD didnt try and go over the top like some other breweries do, they just make great beer, and this one is a perfect example of that.

Bottle...  Poured deep, almost opaque, reddish-brown with a thick, fluffy, tan head.  Roasted grains and toasted oats on the nose.  A whole lot of alcohol warmth on this beer.  Full, thick palate.  Lightly hopped with sweet oak tones and big malts.  An acidic finish with a tart aftertaste.
Tap. Red brown pour with very nice lacing. Aroma is booze and malt. Taste is very malty, with nut and a hop bite. Pretty creamy texture.

Pours a reddish orange with nice carbonation and little to no head.  Sweet, heavy malt followed quickly with piney hop notes on the nose.  Definitely taste the alcohol and not as sweet as the nose would make you think.  Flavor evolve and become complex as you let the beer warm.  This was a great beer when the temperature was below 20 degrees outside.

12oz bottle: 
Appearance: Dark copper/ruby red with a nice tan head with some lacing 
Aroma: Caramel, roasted nuts and sweetness 
Taste: Sweet malts, roasted nuts, alcohol and bittering 
A good beer, especially on a cold night to warm you up....

Pour of a dark red from a bottle. On the nose, there is a very strong and sweet oatmeal presence. Lacing on the glass is very sticky, much like an adult movie. Oatmeal comes through on the initial sip, with a few oats making an impression. Body is medium/heavy, akin to syrup. The taste is rich with some very strong malts with a sweetness that is not overpowering of the rest of the beer.

Pours out amber with lots of creamy head. Taste is sweet malt and bitter hops. Roasty and sweet toffee flavors upfront with some bitterness from the spicey hops. Great caramel and spice notes. Good balance crisp and complex. One of my favorite holiday brews.
Leathery malt aroma. Clear chestnut color, thin yellow head, good lacing. Harmonious boysenberry and leather flavor. Not one of my favorite styles, but unique and tasty.
Caremely, malty, hoppy, alcoholy. Not big on this one...I was alone in this opinion at the table.

Enjoyed via draft in a pub glass.  The beer pours a dark but semi-translucent brown color, with a small and thing off-white head.  The nose gives more of a porter-like character than one reflecting old ale; ash and  roasted malt character.  The palate is fairly complex, and is subtle given the abv of the beer.  Roasty, slightly ashy, and generally malt-forward without much hop character.  Overall, it doesn¬ít seem to have the  overall complexity that such classics as Old Peculiar possess, but it is in any case a competent example of the style.

I had this in the bottle at Redcoat Tavern in Royal Oak, MI. It was a solid ale, that was true to the style, and was overall a great brew. Poured a dark brown with cream head. I liked it because it had some hop character, which a lot of old ales don¬ít have. Cheers!

12 oz bottle from TC Craft.  Deep brown color, big foamy tan head.  Malty aroma, small notes of oak and coffee.  Flavor is big, sweet, malty, oaky.  Palate is thick, chewy and like the bottle says, this beer is very robust.  Amazingly good beer.
Dark garnet with a creamy long-lasting off-white head. Smells of caramel, raisins, and dark fruit cake. Huge malt overtones with a pronounced hop finish...  great winter warmer.

Very good winter cold day drinker.  I have a cold so I am not appreciating aroma very well.  There is nothing wrong with my taster though.  This beer is bold, crisp with tastes of nuts, roasted malt anf perfectly blended hops.  Very nicely done.

Solid tight-bubbled head; leaves chunky lace on the glass.  Brown color and quite clear.

Crystal and chocolate malt aromas; light floral hop in the background.

More bitter than the smell would suggest.  Good malt base which provides good body--creamy; moderate carbonation.   Starts with a darker malt flavor.  The finish is bitter to harsh hop, almost astringent.

12 ounce bottle from Capital Ale House, Fredericksburg, VA. Pours a clear copper color with a medium tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, berries, chocolate. Taste is chocolate, berries, leafy bitter hops, plum and other fruit notes and faint toffee. Medium, full bodied.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Pours with red amber hues and a thin creamy head on top.  Attractive lacing is left behind on the glass.  Smells of chocolate, licorice, and coffee seem to be most prevalent.  Other aromas include nutty, candied sugars, molasses, and some sweet fruits which tend to be minimal.  Tastes of chocolate, earth, caramel and molasses wash over the tongue to provide the most flavor in this beer.  The alcohol is definitely noticeable in this beer which provides a nice warming effect for the cold winter months.

RnH:  Old Ale indeed... the style should be retired!  The beer is aggressive for sure, the aging is apparent in the richness... however it comes at a price.  Dark notes, roasted, even overcooked malts, syrupy yeasts, sugars and rotting fruits overpower the palate.  Esters feel higher than the ABV suggests, this is no sessionable brew.  HOWEVER, if this were handed to me whilst sitting fireside, on a bearskin rug in the dead of winter... yeah I could see this going along quite nicely.
Bottle at Volo.  Pours a clear brown with a small tan head.  Aromas and flavours of brown sugar, dark fruit and toffee.  Big body.  Nice beer.
Bottle. Pours a dark clear brown with a beige head. Aroma is dark fruits, malts, slightly hoppy. Flavor is very malty, slightly spicy, pretzels, and hops.

12oz bottle.  Clear amber brown pour with a finger of tan head and some sudsy lacing.  Interesting aroma of caramel, cherry, apricot, spices and malt.  Tastes of sweet malts, dry fruit, alcohol, toffee, nutmeg (maybe?) and some woodiness.  finishes with a nice tingly bitterness.

12oz bottle (2009) into a pint glass.  Pours brown but mostly red when held to the light, with a slight white-ish head.  The aroma is some fruitiness, but a lot of chocolate, caramel, and nuttiness.  The flavor has some chocolate, a bit of fruity esters, big nuts and roast, and even a dash of coffee.  This isn¬ít a bad brew at all!
Bottle. Brown with off white head. Aroma and taste has chocolate malt and some nice hops in perfect balance.

Location: A draft on 12/10/2009 from Boulevard Wood Grill, Arlington, VA


Aroma: Sweet and malty aroma.

Appearance:  Redish brown color varried between clear and a little hazy.

Flavor:  Medium bitterness and lightly sweet.

Palate: Medium body

Overall Impression:  This beer definitely would keep me warm in the cold months.  I liked the amount of matliness and hops. A solid beer to enjoy.

Dark beer with a very light tan head that had decent lacing, but is disappearing quickly.  Two holes in my head detect a milky, creamy sweetness.  The mouthfeel reminds me of my previous beer, Yeti, but lighter.  I taste roasted or black malt and the twang goes to the back of my tongue and is a little more harsh than I¬ím ready for.  Most of the finish is gone before the minute hand can swing around, then it¬ís time for another sip.  I like this beer, but wish I had another Yeti sitting around.

Aroma of slight vanilla, spruce, and caramel. It poured a dark maroon color with great head and lacing. This brew has an initial taste of herbs, grass, and has a strong roasted malty finish. Decent on the way down. Overall this is another good reason to go to the beer store during winter.

Bottle:  The aroma contains lots of chocolate and caramel along with some roasted nuts and alcohol.  It pours a transparent reddish-orange with a quarter inch beige head.  The flavor starts with some chocolate and caramel.  The finish has some watery roasted nut flavors with some mild citrusy hops and just a hint of alcohol.  Overall the flavor is pretty bland.  It¬ís medium bodied with mild carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.  I was really looking forward to this one, but it fell way short of expectations.  I¬íll have to give it another shot soon.

09-DEC-2009, bottle @home.
Beautifull dark amber with fluffy off-white head. It looks like an old ale:-)
