Nose is quite complex with roasted malts, and some hoppy tones as well. Definately some barley wine tones in there due to the heavy malt precense, but then the hops and alcohol kick in, and I know it is no barley wine. Lovely aroma.
Taste is malty sweet charamel, very nutty, rye bread, mint, grape fruit, and loads more.
Very long and very bitter aftertaste. I love this beer. just my type. Complex, balance between malts and hops, and then the high alcohol level.
Great, Great Divide!
good strong ale, great winter brew.. very heavy with a white tan head. careful with this one!
I like this one but I must say that the taste is a bit nutty.  Good overall smell and feel.  Taste is a bit long lasting in the mouth with several notes.  Good overall.

Deep amber-ruby pour with a loose, lasting, off-white head.  The aroma is subtly roasty with notes of toasted nuts, cocoa, faint dark fruit, and a gentle noble hop spice.  The flavor if full and earthy with lots of caramel, roast, and toasted nuts.  There¬ís also a hint of plum and fig with a pronounced noble hop bitterness on the finish.  The body is creamy, medium-full, with soft but plentiful carbonation and a little bit of alcohol warming.  After a few sips the alcohol starts to come out in the flavor, so it¬ís not super well hidden and tastes a bit bitter.

330 ML bottle in the USA. Cloudy, dark amber color w/a moderate white head. Roasted malt aroma, burnt malt flavor. Not roasted, burnt. hoppy w/a bitter finish. This one didn¬ít do much for me, the longer I drank it the less I liked it.

Sampled courtesy of CUJO.   Poured ruby dark brown in a wine glass.    Tastes of dark fruits, sweet malts, and simple spices.   Pretty basic but still powerful.  I could see this being a nice winter warmer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 Rerate! Just tried the new release and love it! Wow! Got a taste of this and must say I like it! Was afraid I would not but it is very balanced and flavorful, good stuff...must try a full bottle soon

12 oz bottle. Clear amber/brown with a small off white head. Nutty aroma with roasted malt and dates. The taste is about the same, very sweet and malty with lots of nut and dark fruit flavors. Medium to full body with a thick syrupy mouth feel. Solid beer, very roasty and nutty, alcohol is very well hidden.
¬í09 Bottle.  Pours deep ruby with a small off-white head.  Lacing is fair.  Burnt nuttiness in the nose carries to the palate and turns to praline pecans with notes of crab apple and herbs.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Solid medium-big beer. Pours a dark, reddish-bluish brown with a soft white head. Rich aroma of sweet malts and dark fruits. Flavor is nicely complex: quite sweet, strong chocolate character, notes of dark fruits and licorice. Decent ABV gives the brew a strong sense of body and some nice warming sensations. Lingering sweet aftertaste. Pretty darn good winter beer.

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Pours dark maroon with very little head.

Good taste of chcolate, licorice and dark fruits.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2010 Saved one of the 2009 bottles (2010-05-26)
AR. scottish toffee, mild coffe liqure, tropical fruits
AP: reddish amber, high creamy beige head
F: more complex then this christmas, more coffey tones, a bit sprity but with a soft feeling = 3,8!!!

Bottle 2009 edition. Christmas tasting 2009-11-27
AR: american hops fudge, orange peel
AP: brownish fudgy body, high head
F: burned almonds, fudgy sweetness a desert christmas ale

F√§rg: Grumlig Earl grey tea, fudge f√§rgat skum
Smak/Doft: amerikansk humle, pomerans, aprikos, ordentlig beska
Eftersmak: beskan pulserar p√• n√•got s√§tt, kommer och g√•r. Smakar l√§nge och gott. 
Anteckningar:  
Provdatum: 2008-12-27 

Mumma, 2007 edition, rating 4,5
Provdatum: 2007-12-23

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2012 It poured a very dark golden liquid with a small beige foam that left a nice lacing.

It had a very malty smell, similar to how it smells when you open a bag of freshly ground malts just before a brewing.

It had a smooth mouthfeel with a thick body. It had a very malty taste, just like voert before you boil it. Very sweet rich malty flavour. It had some alcoholic warmth but no real alcohol taste.

It isn¬ít very christmasy but I really enjoyed it. I¬íve never actually tried a beer that was this malty before.

It has a sweet but potent aroma up front. The brew pours with a medium frothy head and has a beautiful dark chestnut color. It tastes like a strong ale for sure - rife packing a punch to you with some maltiness and vague hops for a nice balance.

Bottle.  Beautiful reddish/brownish color with a rather large beige head. 

Aroma of hops with some sweetness, raisins and fruits. Nice! 

Roasted tones, hops, some alcohol, fruits, spices and malt. Pleasant mouthfeel, quite long aftertaste. A very nice beer!

Pours deep mahogany with a small off white head. This beer has a nose of toffee, sweet malts, and a little spice. The taste is much the same with sugary caramel as well. The alcohol is nicely hidden. Great winter brew.

355 ml bottle @ Cardinal , Stavanger.  Pours deep brown /mahogney with a small off-white head. Strong sweet malty aroma with distinct notes of caramel and hay. Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, toffee and some burnt caramel. Hoppy bitterness in the finish.Nice and interesting.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2010 Bottle served in a snifter. Polished brown-amber in color. Some viscosity. Doesn¬ít really have a head when poured at fridge temperature. Short head if given a little time to warm. Still, the nose is expressive. Really malty with a hint of hops. Caramel, soy, dark chocolate, slightly doughy and a tinge barnyard. The hops are floral and green. Quite complex. Medium+ body, prickly carbonation, s-thicky texure. Ultra-long sticky bitter and roasty finish. Some oil and alcohol is present. Nice. Let this warm some.

Pours a clear dark ruby copper brown with beige head.  Aroma is resiny hops, some fruit, chocolate and carmel.   Taste starts with sweet malt - caramel, chocolate, toasty - changing to citrusy fruit and finishing with piney bitterness.  Average carbonation and a lighter body than you¬íd expect from the flavor and abv.  Quite flavorful and drinkable.  I¬íd probably like it even more with a bit more age on it (bottled Nov. 5, tasted Nov. 25).

A reddish-brown beer with a nice but disappearing head. The aroma is fruity with some alcohol. The taste was fruity with berries coming out the most with some cocoa dust at the end. This is definitely an old man¬ís beer meant for sipping & seems could do some good ageing.
Med en doft som sl√•r ut som en bukett av sinnligheter i n√§san, en blommande √§ng av frestelser, och en smak som f√∂r en n√§rmare paradiset, √§r Hibernation en klar vinnare.

355 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 8.7%. Beautiful clear and deep copper to mahogany coloured beer, big off-white to beige head. Strong malty aroma with distinct notes of caramel and bakery. The flavour has loads of malty sweetness and caramel, maybe too much caramel for my taste. Noticeable hoppy bitterness in the finish, also notes of burnt bread crumbs. Not entirely balanced in my book, but an interesting beer all the same.

I anticipate this beer every year.  This is one of the best yet.  Higher ABV makes this a real bang for the buck.  Very roasty and malty for an old ale, but nonetheless perfect.  Hops mingle in and out to try and tame the malt. Can¬ít wait to try this one in a year or two.  A must have for beer lovers of all types.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Gilly¬ís, 11/22/09 (2009 Bottle, 8.7%)


Aroma: Aroma of caramel, bread, nuts, brown sugar, toffee, dark fruits, light alcohol, light smoke, light earth

Appearance: Pours a clear ruby-brown color with a thin off-white head, light lace

Flavor: Taste is medium sweet and highly malty, similar to the notes that exist in the nose

Palate: Medium-soft carbonation, medium-full body, an interesting mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
This makes for a pretty good beer.  A nice old ale with some interesting flavors and characteristics.  Another good brew from Great Divide, I¬ím glad to see these guys are becoming more available around here, as they make some quality stuff.
reddish brown pour, little head/carbonation, tiny amount of lacing...nicely balanced ale, complex without being overwhelming

Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Relatively dark reddish-brown that glows ruby red in the light. Minimal head but leaves light lacing lines.

Aroma of brown sugar, toffee, cherry, dark fruit, English hop spiciness and alcohol; the English hops become more apparent as it sits in the glass.

Complex malt profile that seems both sweet and dry at the same time. Hard for me to separate the individual flavors, but cherry and caramelized sugars appear to be in the mix, with notes of bitter chocolate, peat and a stale mustiness. The English hop spiciness/bitterness is apparent throughout, especially at the finish. However, it does grow more malty and deep as it warms.

Low carbonation, full body, with a mostly dry (and warming) finish.

Very nice example of an Old Ale which begs to be sipped. However, I feel like I enjoyed it a little more less year when it was a little lower in alcohol and the malts seemed to be richer in comparison to the spicy hops. Not sure if the beer or my palate is different. Either way, still a great beer.

Dark ruby tinged amber liquid. Decent head which has good retention and some pretty good lacing.

Big, dark roasted coffee hits first. Strong, sweet maltiness follows. Hints of chocolate ice cream. Slight vanilla caramel notes. Good dark fruit presence. Tobacco notes.
Nose is quite complex and inviting.

Like a chocolate coffee malt. Hefty roasted malt backbone. Sweet caramel/brown sugar notes. Hints of espresso. Nice dark fruit presence, here. Good yeast presence. Slight oakiness.

Very nice and silky smooth. Great carbonation level.

Tasty, tasty, and quite drinkable. Many more of these shall be consumed, now that they are readily available to me.

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a clear, dark red liquid with a medium-sized head. Smell is mostly of caramel and nice, fruity hops. Taste is very well-balanced. A rich malt background with notes of caramel and toffee, but also some hops giving a fruity character and some bitterness. Some roasted notes in the end. A really nice brew.

Pours a nice brown color with hints of red.  Off-white head that lasted with decent lacing.  Chocolate, malt and alcohol in the aroma.  Malty and very bitter for the style.  Bitterness starts right up front and lasts quite awhile.  Hints of malt and chocolate but I get a lot of alcohol in the taste.
Deep, dark copper - lots of bitter molasses on the nose. Flavor is the nose,with a choclate bitterness and aboozy  malted milk ball thing as it warms. OK

Bottled. Light brown-big tan head. Aroma is caramel, molasses, and syrup. Flavor is very syrupy, and also in texture. Bready and sweet. Back bitter bite is off putting. A lot of flavor packed into this brew, but odd.

Tasted blind.  Pretty copper/ruby body, reasonable off-white head.  Nose is dusty chocolate, not quite grapes, not quite raisins.  Rich caramel maltiness.  Flavor is robust malt, raisins, lightly astringent hops, dark chocolate.  Finish has cocoa, raisins, tingly hops.  Somewhat slick mouthfeel.

Has a deep dark amber color.  Aroma is of roasted malts, dried fruit, and some caramel.  Taste is of sweeter malts, chocolate, caramel, and a little dried fruit in the back end.  Leaves a bitter sweet aftertaste.  This is a pretty good brew.
Very malty aroma, smoky with no hop smell. Dark pour. Tan head. Smoky flavor. Strong alcohol aftertaste. Not bad but not for me.

Aroma  is very big on malt. Similar to a scotch ale, with lots of oak and smokiness. No real presence of hops.

Pours a 2 finger tan head, body is dark brown. Head retention and lacing are barely above average

Flavor  is similar to the smell but better. The smoke comes out more and there is a bit of vanilla which could pass as the oak aged version. There is an aftertaste of warming alcohol that isnt too overpowering but is nice for this style. Hops come in and out and balance nicely with the sweetness of the malt

Mouth feel is good. Carbonation is a bit on the aggressive side but body has some substance to balance things. 

Overall it is pretty good. For such a high abv beer its somewhat session able. Great beer for cold nights, definitely a malt bomb, sweet, smoky, and just enough bitterness. Another very good beer from Great Divide.

Bottle. Poured a beautiful ruby red color with a decent white/creamy head. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel, and yeast. Flavor is caramel, some alcohol, and plenty of malts. Very good. Very balanced. Flavors all come together to make a great  beer. Warms as it goes. I love it!

Great beer that pours a very dark brilliant ruby color that reflects light almost.  Very pretty to look at. The flavors are so varied in this one it¬ís fantastic. I get soy sauce, smoke, peat smoke, toffee, hops, and some beef jerky. Mmmm. Very interesting and cold weathery!

Bottle as part of a tasting at Catskeller.  Pours a clear copper color with a medium-sized tan head.  Chocolate and caramel malts on the nose along with hops, brown sugar, and wood.  The flavor follows suit, with more caramel and wood coming through.  Medium bodied, rich, smooth, and very dry, with warming alcohol.  Nice warming winter ale.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Ar√¥mes de malt chocolat√© et de caramel anglais. Robe rousse fonc√©e et limpide, effervescence moyenne et peu de mousse. Moyennement ronde en bouche, un malt chocolat√© et caram√©lis√© l√©g√®rement sucr√© m√®ne √† une finale l√©g√®rement am√®re o√π pointe √©galement l¬íalcool.
a 12 oz bottle. the beer poured like a glass of root beer, nice foam head. the smell is of coffee and roasted malt. the is just like the smell. good carbonation.

Pours brown with thick tan head.  Great lacing.  Aroma has huge chocolate nose with toffee and malt.  Taste is chocolate and caramel and roasted malt.  Thick, smooth mouthfeel.  Easy drinking.  Great beer.
Smells chocolatey and roasty.  Deep brown with a big head that fades fast.  It is smooth and chewy with cocoa chocolate strengths and a clean English finish.  Excellent fall brew.

12oz bottle, 2008 vintage, poured into a snifter.

Pours a really nice deep copper with a huge billowy beige head that shows excellent retention and lacing.  Really good looking beer here.

The aroma is very sweet with lots of caramel malts and toffee.  Some brown sugar and dark fruits mix in as well as a hint of chocolate.

The taste is excellent with the typical old ale tastes coming out, namely caramel malts, toffee and dark fruit.  But there is also plenty of chocolate and brown sugar, and maybe some hops though I think they¬íve probably faded over the last year.

The mouthfeel is pretty full bodied for the style with good soft carbonation.  Sticky sweet overall feel.

This is another solid beer from Great Divide and one that I¬íve taken too long to try.  Excellent.

Pours a really beautiful deep ruby color with a thin off white head.  Aroma is massive malt, sweet malt, biscuity, bread, roasted malt, malt malt malt.  One giant malt bomb.  Flavor is similar.  Almost cloying, but not in a sweet way, just this intense malt flavor the peaks immediately and never quite subsides.  Massive malt bomb, but not terrible.

Clear garnett pour with a creamy tan head, good retention and nice looking lacing.  Aroma consists of brown sugar, roasted malt, light chocolate, and spicy hops.  The flavors found in this beer are citrus and pine from the hops and caramel sweetness.  Starts off bitter with carbonation and a brief second of sweetness in the middle finishing slightly dry and bitter.  Medium body, moderate carbonation, mildly warm from the alcohol.  Good beer!
Poured a deep murky brown. Nose is huge malt, earthiness, some floral hops, some sweet fruits. Flavors are big sweet caramel malt, roasted grain, some dark fruits, sweet cherry.

REALLY digging this one. Big brown malty flavors, gorgeous mahogany color, and a very complex aroma that only hints at what is to come. Sometimes people go too sweet and cloying with this style but GD is getting it right! Finishes really clean with a perfect level of bitter on the back of the mouth. The 8.7% ABV is very well hidden and you could easily get yourself in trouble with this one if you start pounding too fast. If only beers like this were available year round.
12 oz. bottle brewed in August ¬í09. Colour... dark brown with thick head. Nose... very roasty, sweet malt. Palate... very rich and roasty, sweet malt, biscuit, brown sugar and toffee.

2008 Bottle - Thanks motortoddhead! - Aroma is sweet and dark, roast malt, raisin, hop florals...flavour is sweet and grainy, bitter but fleeting, finish is a bit thin, good late fall brew, but seems a bit disjointed...

On tap at Great Divide.  Dark reddish-brown color with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma is roast, brown sugar, dark fruits, and faint hops.  Flavor is caramel and roasted malt, somewhat sweet, with brown sugar, dark fruits, and substantial hop bitterness.  Body is medium-full and palate is very smooth.

Hops AND flavor? How creative.

(Looking back on this rating, I just have to laugh at myself.)
Aroma is robust vegetal/malt, deep auburn, sporting a small tan head. Taste is a milder malt than the nose, caramel and butterscotch notes. Medium bodied, well balanced, light bitterness. Great!

Clear mahogany with a foamy beige head that leaves plenty o¬ílace.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, alcohol, heavy grains and caramelized brown sugar.  Taste of roasted malt, alcohol, diacetyl and brown sugar.  Not terribly flavorful but not bad either.

I have been cellaring this beer for a year now all because of the aged sample I had at last year¬ís GABF. The first sniff at the bottle is candied chocolate. The beer is so dark red in color it is almost brown but when held to the light it reveals itself. Nice, pillowy, khaki-colored head. The smell holds true with a sweet, full chocolate, tootsie roll and candy aroma, with slight alcohol fumes in the back; it smells fantastic! The taste is malty, cocoa powder but does not quite match the smell, which is good in my opinion. The alcohol is hiding and the mouthfeel is neither thick nor thin. I am still undecided as to whether or not I should buy more for cellaring this year since I still have several 2006 bottles. This is a very malty beer and good for a cold day such as today. I¬ím surprised this is not in bombers or four packs but I am not going to complain because a sixer for $8 is a very good value. Drinkability suffers a little as I did not want another.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-25-2007 15:10:00

Cellared a bottle since last winter.  Thought that now NFL pre-season games are on the tube it was time to dig it out and consume.  Holy-Molee!  This American Strong Ale may be built for a cold winter day but worked well on a mid-summer¬ís night.   Sharp malt, full bodied, medium bitterness and overall a well done beer.

Bottle at Volo. A surprisingly tasty beer, as I hadn¬ít heard this is one to look out for. Pours a dark amber-red with minimal head. Big malty aroma with roasty nuts and spice notes. Taste is big and complex with caramel malts, ripe fruits, and some citursy hops.

Pours dark reddish brown with thin tan head.  Aromas of roasted nuts, coffee and caramel.  Similar flavors with a little vanilla and oak.  Finishes great with small bubbles and slightly spicy.  Great winter time beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2011 Last year¬ís bottle has aromas of raspberry and wood, though a bit dry and oxidized.  Dark ruby brown, small tan head.  Rich and full burnt creamy coffee character, filling and slick.  Warming and subliminally sedating.  Warming throughout, I want to put some mini marshmallows in it.  061011  05 bottle from susygreenberg. great marriage of aromas here, dark orange and saturated pine. little charcoal. rich intense, warm and inviting. more charcoal and pine,seems to be peaking.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 1. On Tap at the Great Divide Brewing Company, Denver 12/10/2007
Strong malt aroma. Small white head. Mid brown coloured with plenty of alcohol present. Fruity. Some bitterness in a warming nutty malt finish.
2. On Tap in the Brewery Room at the Great Divide Brewing Company, Denver 10/10/2008
Malt aroma. Mid brown red coloured smooth on the palate and malty with a crisp dry and slightly bitter finish.
3. From the Bottle at TAG Restaurant, Denver 22/09/2009
Hoppy pine nut aroma. Amber coloured very hoppy and a little sweet on the palate with some dryness in a crisp and bitter chocolaty malt finish.
Bottle. Dark chestnut coloured with a nice lacing off white head. The aroma is malty, caramel, milk chocolate and aromatic hops. Flavour of malt, hops, caramel and a hint of coffee.
pours ruby red with a small beige head.  notes of dark fruits, booze, cough medicine, caramel, and sweet malts.  not too bad.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a beautiful mahogany colored beer with a small beige head. The nose is mainly of ginger, overripe fruit, raisins, licorice, candied apricot, pumpkin, fennel, cherry, aniseed and candy. Nice balance between chewy malts and resiny hops. Hints of lime, ginger, aniseed, fennel, cherry and lactose with quite a lot of caramel in the taste. Sweet. Good lacework. Subdued bitterness. Decent. I don¬ít care much for the malt profile.
Bottle tasted at fordest house on a surprise visit he opened this up. A very nice old ale. Malts, caramel, roastiness. Very good.
Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours an ambercolored beer with offwhite head. The aroma is malts, caramel and hops. The flavor is complex with caramel and roasted malts. Nice smooth palate. Overall a good beer.

Bottle from Bottle Trek via an internet order. Poured a dark amber color and smelled of spices. The hops and malts were well blanced with the main flavors being roasted malts and toffee.Very well done brew.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear, deep amber-red body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves some nice swirls on the surface and a good amount of lacing. Aroma is rich malts and a good amount of hops. Lots of toasted toffees and caramels, some light chocolates and roasts, a hint of smoke, and some over-ripe dark fruits and grapefruit. Flavor is along the same lines with a coating, rich toasted toffee and caramel malt feel. Nice amount of citrusy hops balance the big, robust malts very well. Some roasts and chocolate and even some light vanilla in here. A hint of dark fruits come in towards the end with a lingering flavor of sweet and toasty caramel, roast, and a light bitterness as well as a nice, subtle fruity character. Finishes smooth and rich. Full bodied with a drying end. Overall, a great beer. I love the big flavor and balance. Good one!
Bottle. Dark red brown. Meaty tasty caramel and spiced hop aroma. Dark amber or copper. Mouth coating malty hoppy beer. Mouth drying woody hop taste.

pours a clear brown with a red tint and a small light beige head, and a really good lacing.

smell of burnt carmel, brown sugar, and some vanilla.

taste is semi-sweet, woody, caramel, and roasted nuts, ends on the bitter side.
Deep dark brown colour with head,who stays.Aroma of caramel,dryd fruits and fresh brown bread,powerful full body and wonderful ,sweet mouth feels well balanced and fresh finish.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2009 This is very reminiscent of an old ale.  The aroma is malty, brown sugar, toffee, bread.  The appearance is very attractive, a brown/red, tan head.  The flavor is malty, bready, sweet, brown sugar.  The finish is malty sweetness, few hops.  Good overall.
Darker brown with a roasty, malty aroma.  Flavor is quite malty with raisins, alcohol, and a caramel taste.  Not bad, not great.

Pours a medium-dark ruby tinted brown with a 3-4 finger peach-beige head that has great retention and leaves decent lacing. Aroma is lots of dark caramel, toasted nuts, roast, toffee, dark fruits and some planty hops. Flavor is roasted nuts, toasted wood, caramel, vanilla, dark toast, toffee and planty hops. Finish is slightly bitter hops, roast and burnt caramel. Palate is medium thickness with a playfully light carbonation, a slick feel and a fairly neutral finish that leans toward dry. Overall this is a really good beer that has a lot going for it but fails to keep my interest.

Absolutely delicious. Pours golden brown, thin off white head. Strong, nutty aroma. The taste is roasted and hoppy, complemented very well with the malt. Just the right amount of carbonation. Will drink again and again.
Poured brown with a white head. Aroma of caramel. Very sweet. Lots of caramel with vanilla and fruit.

Pours dark reddish brown and clear with a light beige head.  Smell is nuts and borderline toasty/roasty malt.  Taste is dark dry toasty malt and almost with a burnt, charred quality to it along with a bit of hoppy bitterness.  Medium bodied with an average level of carbonation.  Pretty enjoyable, and it¬ís a nice holiday ale without all the typical spiced flavors.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 Well I drank a Hibernation bottled in1996 last night, i cant believe how well this beer held up over 13 years...It lost little of its carbonation and retained many strong ale characteristics, almost  barleywineish. Lighter on the hops than a fresh Hibernation, somewhat sour finish....good
On tap. Mahogany colour. Thin white head. Berries in the aroma. Rich flavour with a syrup texture. Malt with roasted wild berries. A little earthy. A spiced warming ale.

Bottle- Dark amber brown pour, decent foam head and lacing.  Malt smooth with some nutty notes.  A little roast and some spice with a good hop blend, some dry sweetness there as well.  Nice winter warmer.

(Draught at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2009-03-18) Amber and almost clear. Small white head. Sweet and malty aroma. Full bodied and dry palate with medium carbonation. Malts, saltiness, some fresh malt flavours, bit of sweetness, caramell, bit of grass, fruitiness and bitterness in taste. Malty and bitter aftertaste.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits I believe.  Pours a rich amber with a small off white head. Aroma has a nice hoppy aroma and some great caramel malts.  I also get some animal crackers.  Flavor is hoppy and malty.  A bit of roasted malt melds well with the hops.  Very well done.

Pours a nice amber with a thick head that dissipates quickly.  Thick lacing.  Nice malty aroma.  Thick mouthfeel, with good bite.  Very toasty and malty flavor with lots of coffee malts.  Slightly bitter aftertaste.

It basically tastes like a Fat Tire, except with a coffee malt base.  Not one for hopheads, but a very nice beer.
Bottle. Mahogny body with a creamy off white head. Lots of malt, dark fruit and hops in aroma. Complex malty flavour with some spices, chocolate, mollasses and hops. Smooth silky mouthfeel.
Pours a dark amber.  Nose is very unique kind of earthy.  That earthy flavor is very noticeable in the Flavor. Full Bodied.  Very Interesting Beer.
Bottled Poured a hazy copper color with a thin beige head. Very complex; dark fruit, caramel malt, and spice are all present.  Definitely wasn¬ít blown away.  Maybe it would be nicer aged?

Dark amber pour with a thick beige head. 
Aroma of caramel malts, a touch of cocoa and berry-like fruitiness. Spicy, fruity, sweet and smooth. Very rich and very tasty.

12 oz bottle enjoyed while catching up with all my ratings from my amazing "Birthday Weekend" (Feb 14th) planned by my wonderful girlfriend. After a long day of cleaning, cellaring all of my haul from Wisco, and getting errands done, I found this at the back of the fridge. 12 oz. bottle from the Binny¬ís Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL). Pours an iced tea reddish copper with big tannish bubbly head that begins to dissipate. Aromas are brown sugar and molasses, some light chocolate, tobacco, nuttiness, and some light booziness. The aroma reminds me of a nice desserty bread or cake. Initial is heavy on malts as some bitterness comes in on the end. Brown sugar and cakey biscuity malts come in strong with a touch of caramel, chocolate, and coffee evident. Alcohol is well hidden, as it smelled stronger than it tasted. Smooth. Good body, but nothing overly heavy or hard to quaff. Head dissipates down to a small layer, and the bitterness starts to come in fuller. Very malty, but I was not dissappointed. I just personally have a hard time loving ASAs. Still, a very nice brew.

clear brown pour, a bit of dissipating white foam
aroma is very biscuity, some definite alcohol, caramel, and some fruit
flavor is fairly fruity, with minimal alcohol bite, a lot of malty sweetness, and not very hoppy
very warming
finish is light bitter hops
medium body, nice that its not too fullbodied, otherwise it would be kind of cloying

Bottle into red wine glass.

Pours a dark reddish brown, murky, with a thin, soapy off-white head.

Nose is loaded with cocoa mixed with a caramel sweetness. Fruity esthers and some boozey alcohol almost run wild. Nice nose, very intense, but very new too. Put a little age on this one to refine it a bit and I think it¬íd take it to a whole new level.

Taste has lots of cocoa, a bit of brown sugar, and a leafy hop presence - almost vegetal. Seriously, it¬ís like someone chucked in a dry leaf towards the finish. Some warming alcohol on the finish.

As the beer warmed from cellar to room temperature, the leafy hop presence receded and left an earthy bitterness instead. Still a bit leafy, green, vegetal, but no longer dominatingly so. Much more palatable, though this is still a beer that would come into its own with some time in the cellar.

Mouthfeel is fluffy, a bit creamy, lively, and a bit syrupy.

Weird beer at first, but as the palate acclimated, got better. Split the difference in the score.
Draft @ Cockney Pub. Red, golden brown body, creamy lasting white head with good lacing. Hoppy aroma, citrus and malty caramel. Well balanced flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 12 oz. bottle. Pours a tan head of good duration, with attractive lacing,  over a clear coppery red brown body....nose is green pine resin and cocoa malty with dried fig.....initial taste is mild hops which gradually build towards a bitter finish ending with cocoa overtones...mouthfeel  is medium to heavy.

Tap.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy malt with detectable dried fruit, malt, and rye.  The taste was a bit bitter up front, with rye, malt, nuts, dried fruit, and slight caramel detectable.  Slight alcohol burn on the finish.  I liked this.
4 oz beer flight, draft ( i think) at Old Chicago Peoria, IL.  Pours dark brown.  Very woody aroma of cedar.  The alcohol is there every bit of the way.  Very good stuff.
This was done very well. The hops play a big part here and work with the other flavors as opposed to detracting from the taste.

12 ounce bottle that I have had for a few months in my fridge. Poured a beautiful dark amber color with a one finger width tan fluffy head. The aroma consisted of a lot of malt with some caramel, nuts, and dark dried fruit. The taste was a bit bitter because of the amount of malt present. I could pick out some characteristics that were similar to a bock though... some light chocolate hints with nut and dark fruit. I was very surprised by this ale... I usually do not care for winter brews that much... this one was very enjoyable though.
Bottle from Bottleworks.  Great coffee and malty aroma.  Pours clear amber with a nice orange head.  Tastes sweet but has a good caramel malt.  Lingering aftertaste.

THOUGHTS: Nice flavors, but it didn¬ít hide the alcohol all that well. Should age incredibly well. The flavor changed a little from sip to sip.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark, brownish amber to mahogany with an average, off-white head that kept a thin sheet and left fair lacing. The aroma was light to moderate caramel, light to moderate citrus hops, raisin, prune, maple syrup, vanilla, alcohol, dark fruit and when cooler a little chocolate. The flavor started sweet and a little bitter, and finished acidic and a little bitter with a long duration. There was slight chocolate, caramel malt, maple syrup, citrus hops, alcohol, and at the very end pine hops. The medium body was oily then dry with soft carbonation and a dry and moderate to heavy alcoholic finish.

Clear, dark reddish brown with a centimeter of tan head.  Aroma is rich decaying fruit (in a good way).  Taste is similar with an added malt roast that complements the fruity notes and an odd mineral cocktail in the initial taste and finish. Bitter chocolate notes persist thereafter $2/12oz
Brown in color with ruby highlights and a small beige head. Aroma is of chocolate and nuts with some caramel and fruits. Taste is of caramel, chocolate, and fig.

12 oz bottle courtesy of mreusch. Pours a hazy amber with a small beige head. The aroma is moderate in strength with chocolate, mocha, musty fruits and roasted malts. The taste is rich with chocolaty malts, some earth and some biter oak. The mouthfeel is smooth and (mostly) creamy with a touch of grit. The finish is medium, in duration with lingering mocha. Overall: Another winner from the folks at great divide.

Pours a deep ruby red with a very thin white head.  Aroma is of cherry, plum, oak, and candied sugar.  An immediate taste of oak, malt, and fruits that evolve as the beer wamrs.  Very complex and warming, a great beer for winter.
IT POUR A DARK BROWN COLOR WITH A THICK CREAMY HEAD. THE TASTE IS A LITTLE BITTER FOR A WINTER ALE. IT IS VERY HOPPY WITH A ENGLISH MALT AFTERTASTE.

Style and Glass: American Strong, Trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 8.1 % in 12 fl oz. estimated at 200 C
Purchased at: Canal¬ís Lawrenceville, NJ for $1.83

Aroma: caramel, syrup and roasted malts. Some pepper, spice, and citrus.

Visuals: Beautiful packaging, recently redesigned cohesive brand from Great Divide.  It does the beer within the bottles justice. The ruby mahogany body is deep and contemplative. hard to see through, but clear rather than hazy. Thin tan head is long lasting, lace is intricate and shows this brew¬ís freshness.

Taste: Well balanced flavor starts with roasted malt, follows with a rush of crispness from carbonation, and finishes long with a dark roasty deliciousness. Sugar overtones, followed quickly by a light sourness. Easily drinkable. Alcohol is quiet and well hidden.

Palate:  Smooth, crisp, drying, and long fantastic finish add up to a wonderful session brew, despite the high ABV, so beware!

Overall: A beautiful, enticing, delicious beer, affordable, from a great brewer, and entices the senses. I¬íll have it again, for sure.
Address : <http://beercritic.wordpress.com/>

Crushed with Jakebra.  Interesting aroma.  Kinda leafy and fruity aroma.  Very thin-bodied.  Flavor is very leafy.  Probably coulda aged this one a little bit longer.  I¬íll rerate it one of these days, but for now, it stands as is.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2013 Bottle, black/red color aroma of coffee, toffee and roasted malt. Initial taste is thick and slightly sweet. Then it gives way to a dry smoked malt aftertaste with dark chocolate notes. Nice beer it was real nice on tap I first time I had it.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker.  GDHA pours amber-to-copper color.  It smells like malt and lima beans.  The body is thick and oily.  This beer has a deep malty flavor tempered with figs, nuts and musk.  It is surprisingly complex.  The finish is sweet but short of cloying.
Bottle from BierKoning. Dark oaky bottle with walnut head. Malty, sweet and coffee nose. Great flavour of malts, caramel, toffee and coffee. Smooth as usual. Warming and excellent finish.

355 ml bottle. Clear amber body with a fine, dense beige head. Aroma is slightly roasted malt, raisin, brown sugar, overripe fruit and some alcohol. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, dry fruit, hops, alcohol and a distinct but pleasant bitterness. Very flavorful with a long and warming alcohol finish. A sostificated beer for enjoying.

Pours clear, amber-brown with a thin beige head, good lacing.  Smells of pine, caramel, apple, and alcohol.  Medium body, crisp and warm.  Big caramel malt flavors, with hints of apple, fig, and nut.  Has a complex English-style hop flavor, grass and pine, with a mild aftertaste.  Very well balanced and drinkable for the strength.

Poured from a bottle; nice head.

Color is great

S - alcohol smell was too strong for my liking; same as in taste.

OK overall but not something I would purchase in futuer

Bottle.  Pours a deep reddish brown, with a light head.  Aroma of caramel barleywine malts, with a bit of hoppiness.  The flavor is somewhat like a cross between a barleywine and a Scotch Ale, with a good dose of hops thrown into the mix.  Tough to classify (I wouldn‚Äôt agree with their classification of an "English-style Barleywine"), but very well-done.

very nice english hop aroma with a touch of oak and roasted nuts.  dark opaque ruby aroma with a thin light head.  nice hop profile in the up-front flavor but a sweet maltiness unbalances the finish which doesnt live up to the promise of the aroma.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Bottled on Nov 11 2008 enjoyed 1.4.09.  Pours a dark deep mahogany with a lovely red hue and a thick creamy frothy beige head that sticks around forever.  Love the aroma, dusty chocolate, light toasty crystal malt, maybe some nutmeg, really sophisticated for Great Divide.  Wow, this is a delicious complete unique sophisticated beer, very impressed.   Really quite dry,  chalky coca powder, nutmeg, lightly caramelized malts, a touch of roasted malts, some woodiness, and a nice laid-back piney hop bite.  Super smooth and soft, the flavors are so well in-tune with each other while completely disguising the alcohol.  Quick chocolate nutmeg finish.  This is fantastic.  Another example of how a beer¬ís sum can be greater than its parts in this relatively simple beer.  I don¬ít see this getting any better with age, its flavors are already pretty mellowed and the strong hops add greatly to gentle malts.  Super drinkable with a chalky medium watery mouthful with very soft carbonation.  

8.5.9.5.17 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 

[Bottled on 9.17.09 enjoyed 12.4.09]  This bottle is quite hoppy, juicy, but has considerable amounts of acetaldehyde which really ruins it... 8.4.8.4.15 . . . . . . . [2010 bottle]  7.4.7.3.13

dark dark brown with thick off white head. aroma i swear is of a nut brown. tastes of it too. super malty, buttery, nutty of course. a little hopy and spice hops bite after it leaves the tounge. quite nice, one of the better ive had lately.

2008 bottle.  pours a light brown with a quarter inch off white yellow head... which does not last long.  wonderful citrus hop laced aroma with some deep malts as well.  very soft on the sides, medium body, extremely smooth over the top of the palate.  nice biting bitterness up front with some caramel and a touch of alcohol.  excellent finish with the perfect blend of hops and malts.  this is a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 bottle thanks to swalden28. re-rate.  poured brownish/ruby with an off white head.  aroma was caramel, chocolate, coffee, and brown sugar raisins.  flavor was pine, caramel, alcohol, and cherry.  light body with high carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a dark red/brown with beige head. Aroma is interesting, burnt grain, nutty, caramel, hoppy pine, a little raisin. Flavor has a light sweetness, burnt grain, grassy, dark fruit, burnt caramel. Mouth feel is heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, very nice drinking and warming, tasty stuff!

October 29, 2008 vintage. Dark amber pour into off white foamy head that melts into heavy lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malt and piney hops. Initial flavor of spice, sweet malt fading into a warming bitter hoppy finish.
cleanish amber color with a rich fluffy tan head. aroma of sweet malt, toffee, and herbs. toasty sweet brown sugar start with am herbal hop and a smack of pine needle. spicy finish lasts a while.
I like most of the winter ales that Ive had but this just had something weird about it.  A cigarette kind of scent and smokey flavor going on.

Bottle. Wonderful brown and a bit reddish colour with great beige head. Caramel and yest aroma. Taste is a bit sweet in the beginning, than rich hop flavour where you can sense the power of the alcohol. Long aftertaste.

Bottle served in a stem glass. Dark reddish brown pour topped by a half inch of beige foam. Lots of nuts in the nose along with notes of cocoa and molasses. Tastes sweet and nutty, some toffee and chocolate linger in the background. Smooth slick body with minimal carbonation. Lasting finish that leans toward sweet. Not my favorite style but they pulled it off really well.

pours  nice deep chestnut with huge tan head that lasts and lasts. aroma is warm and inviting like christmas dinner with a beer in hand.  flavor is malty but not sweet and nice light winter spicing and almost fruit like.  bready and malty to finish.

12oz bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with light tan head. Aroma is malty with caramel, spices and some hops. Flavor is malty with chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, spices and some hop bitterness. Has sort of a roasted chocolate malt character to it. Mouthfeel is thick and chewy. Nice winter brew.
Clear ruby red pour with a thin light tan head.  Malt dominates the aroma - caramel and fruit.  Very strong almost barley wine like, but roastier.   Bitter roast flavor with fruit and lots of hops.

Dark brown and ruby pour with a short off white head that produced spotty lacing. The aroma was roasty and malty with light chocolate, spice and thin hops. The flavor was malty, lightly hoppy with some spice in there as well. Average mouthfeel. Just another winter warmer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear reddish amber color with a medium sized fine beige head that leaves sporadic lacing.  The aroma is very malty with doses of chocolate, caramel, and some nuts.  There are also notes of hops that come through.  The flavor is again malt driven, but the hops play a more prominent role.  I get chocolate and caramel with citrus and pine hops.  Medium to full bodied that warms as it goes down.  This is a solid drinking beer especially as the temperatures are dropping.
Very nice body, warm strong, malty with a nice deep bitterness.  It borders barleywine, but walks the line nicely and is quite drinkable.  Alcohol hidden well.  Nice.

An outstanding representation of the style. Poured from the bottle a dark amber with a nice fluffy head. The aroma is spicy and sweet. You can pull out dry fruits, cinnamon, caramel and other great winter treats. The taste is all of the above with a bit of toffee and chocolate. It is better a bit warmer then cold and it goes down smooth. Just great.

draft at barleys in greenville. pours a clear, dark amber with a soft, half inch white head that leads to great lacing on the glass. aroma is great with touches of roasted caramel malt, figs, plums, coriander, cinnamon and earthy hops. flavor is wonderful and unique. almost like drinking two different beers with dark malts, spice, and dark fruit up front with earthy hops and citrus on the back end. mouthfeel is slightly heavy that warms on the swallow. an excellent beer thats perfect for the winter.

bottle. very appealing, sweet aroma with toffee undertones- flavor was well balanced and smooth. a nice beer for sipping at home if your not due for a hop explosion. very earthy and subdued strong ale. Enjoyed.

Bottle at Redlight.  Brown with a thick white head.  Bouquet is hoppy with grapefruit and toasted malts.  Heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor reminds me of a pumpernickle bread with roasted malts, a good amount of hops and some winter spices.  Very good.
6 pack 12oz. bottles. one of my favorite winter seasonals. nice amber color. would like to try cellared.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber with a 3 finger fluffy beige head and great lacing.  Nose is caramel malt and light earthy hops.  Taste is roasted malt, light bitter chocolate, toasted caramel, some spice and that earthy hop from the aroma carries through in the finish.  Nice full mouth feel.  This is quite good.

Poured deep amber with a tan head. Roast malt aroma. Taste of roast malt, caramel, toffee and a hint of dark fruit. The presence of earthy hops become apparent as it warms. Some bitterness. Nice balance.
Great dark chocolate aroma right off the bat. Nice!  Dark leathery brown in color.  Roasted malt flavor that finishes with a little hoppiness thrown in.  I like this for a sipping winter beer.

Pours clear dark brown with a good sized head.  Aroma is malty with caramel and a hint of toffee and alcohol.  Mouth feel is a bit thin but lively with carbonation. Flavor is sweet but not excessively so. Caramel, roasted coffee like flavors and a touch of nut finished off with a nice hop bite.

Out of a bottle. Smells like a caramel sundae tops with a bucket of juniper berries. Looks like a glass of aged Merlot with a creamy high head, as it dissipates it leaves prodigious lacing. Nutty, sweetened coffee with a big balanced finish slightly. No surprises but a damn good beer. Thinner than expected with a slight alcohol taste. It goes down very easy.

Bottle served. Pours a copper/ brown, almost mahogany, with a big, foamy, light tan head, and heavy lace. Aroma brings roasted malt, chocolate, a little yeast, and a touch of toffee and caramel. The flavor keeps the roast and chocolate and adds a little coffee and nuttiness, along with a pleasant mid-dryness. A little tangy in the finish. A nice winter warmer with a more than decent abv.
Draft from rattle & hum. Wow this was surprisingly good. Poured brown with a significant head. Nice sweet caramel taste and malitness with a nice finish.
bottle, almond colored with a big fluffy head and strong coffee and fruit nose, flavor is cocoa, red wine, fermenting fruits and spices, finish is smooth with a touch of alcohol

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear medium brown with a huge off-white head.  Aroma of sweet caramel.  Flavor is caramel and toffee up front, but has an unexpected but quite welcome dry coffee/hop finish.  Not your ordinary winter ale.  Killer stuff.

Perfume resin hops with some real bite.  Large frothy off white head.  Sparkling clear with no particles.  Lightly acidic initial flavor with a light bitter finish.  Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation.  A hoppy beer from a hoppy brewing company.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep mahogoney with a slight amber tinge. Tand head that flattens but does not fade. Good lacing. Aroma of citrus hops, some toffee malts with some chocolate powder, a bit of alcohol, berries and unripe plums. A touch of leather as well. Reminds me of NB 2 Below. Taste is toffee, chocolate, leather, and nuts. THere are some faint hops in the mid taste and a berry and chalky malt finish with a bit of alcohol and bitterness in the aftertaste. Moderate carbonation and a touch creamy mouthfeel and just ever so slightly warming.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 Mmmmm.....now this will warm you on a cold winter night. ABV is solid, especially for a winter beer. Alcohol not present in the flavor. Very hearty to drink, with plenty of malt (caramel, biscuit, toffee) to keep you warm.

Very nice reddish brown pour with a nice but small head and solid lacing. One of those beers that actually taste better a little warmer, the heat brings out the caramel and tamps down the alcohol flavor a bit. Nice dried fruit flavor backdrop as well, very tasty and yet another winner from Great Divide.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 Bottle. Pours a nice red/brown color. Taste is caramell and some fruit with a nice burning alcohol finish.
On tap at Magoos.  Big earthy strong ale with caramel, almonds, tootsie roll flavors, Dark Amber color, not much head but nice lacing.  Alcohol is prevalent  and pleasant with a sweet finish

11.16.08  Bottle given to me by Adamskillin.  I‚Äôm so happy that the winter seasonals have started to roll in.  They warm my heart and cockles.  This brew from Great Divide was no exception and I will seek it out immediately.  Very delicious.

Pours a brown/amber color with a nice white head leaving some lacing. Aroma of toffee, malt, dried fruits, plums, hops, citrus. Flavour is quite sweet at first but passes over in a pleasant bitterness. There¬ís notes of malt, toffee, dried fruits, hops and grapefruit. Full bodied, creamy and oily, average carbonation with a long, bitter, warming, finish. Very balanced. This is a very good beer, I must say. It¬ís something to sip slowly during these cold winter months. It probably improves with age, but I¬ím not sure if I can afford another bottle at the moment (it¬ís so many other beers coming to Sweden right now).

Always one of the brews I look forward to coming out around the X*MasISH time of year...this well balanced supreme malty ale comes off nice and hoppy while remaining sensitively sweet on the palate.  Touches of brown sugar and holidy spice abound on the tongue...goodness in a 12 oz bottle!

12 oz bottle. Two-finger firm lightly tanned head. Brilliant, dark copper-brown colored body. Inviting caramel aroma. Chocolate, ripe fruits and a rather pleasant whiff of alcohol too. Tasty. Spiced  dark malts, roast, caramel, and a plummy fruitiness. Big chewy body. Fruity bitterness and ashy malts in the finish. A really nice beer.

Pour a nice ruby with a small head... Aroma of sweet roasted malts with an ever increasing alcohol nose as it warms.... Taste of sweet malt and bitter chocolate and the alcohol becomes apparent again as it warms... A slightly bitter alcoholy finish... Overall it was above average, but not the experience I was expecting...

Brown color with a thick creamy tan head. Powerful sweet malty aroma with english toffe and hints of coffee. Promising aroma leads to a roasted malt flavor with a coffee bitter finish. A strong alcohol presence disturbes the flavor.
Clear body.  Amber in color.  Heavy aroma of Pine and citrus. Medium body.  Dry texture. Overpowering strong hoppy floral finish.  Just not my style of beer.  Not a fan of strong hops.

I gave one of these to the owner of the best beer bar in my area (Circa, in High Bridge, NJ.  It‚Äôs great, he knows his stuff).  His question was "If this is winning silvers at GABF, who the heck is winning gold?!?!"

That‚Äôs basically how I feel.  This is a strong beer that will give you a warm sensation going down without the alcohol heat in your mouth.  The malty sweetness is just right and there‚Äôs hops that please without overpowering.  One of the new beer world‚Äôs future classics for sure.

12oz bottle thanks to drewbeerme i think.... pours a mostly non-trasparent dark reddish brown with a thin frothy off-white head.... aroma mostly of dark fruits, toffee, cough syrup, and toast.... caramel, dark fruits, and some smoke and roasty aspects come through flavorwise. a little thin on the palate with decent carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2012 Draft at Jerry¬ís. Red-amber with good, creamy, orange-beige head / Sweet, toasty, nose of brown sugar, dark fruit, and biscuit / Medium to full body, sweet and malty, chewy, with excellent hop balance on the long, sweet and  lightly bitter finish / Flavor of raisins, dates, smoke, oak, brown sugar, and tobacco / Just great.

12oz bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a generally clear dark mahogany with thick and puffy tan head. Some retention and lacing. Aroma has notes of coffee, hops, some warm milk, musty, hints of chocolate and toffee. Flavor is generally sweet and malty with notes of wood, hops, some slight molasses, cocoa, bakers chocolate and hints of nuts. Generally medium to full body with a bitter, coffee finish. Reducing the hop character on this beer (or aging it) would significantly improve the profile.
330 ml bottle. Reddish-brown color, off-white head. Dark malty aroma with alcohol. Strong bitter flavor with some winy notes, noticeable alcohol. Somehow didn‚Äôt really appeal to me.

Dark amber pour with a lasting cream colored head. Quite fragrant with red fruits, piney hops and some malt. Fairly lively mouthfeel. Some malt, bread, raisin with a little pine. Flavors open up nicely as this warms. Faint red fruits but not tart at all. A solid amount of hop character balancing well throughout. More than usual hops for an old ale. Rather crisp and clean. Dangerously drinkable for 8%. Will be curious to see this one age a bit.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 11/12/08 notes: bottle.  Settles a clear ruby-brown with a medium-sized cream head.  Aroma is deeply fruity, bright, with fresh wood chips, and maybe a touch of vanilla and alcohol.  Flavor is beautifully complex, and palate is dry and mellow.  There is milk chocolate, malt and some light brown sugar to begin.  This transitions into more fruity character and hops, nhounderpinned by delicious woody flavors.  Hibernation finishes with slight warming effect, and a festive blend of sweet-but-balanced flavors.  Recommended, especially to sip and contemplate on a wintery day.  I draw many parallels in drinkability to a good Barley Wine.
Very rich. Lots of malt sweetness. Very smooth and easy drinking. The alcohol is nowhere to be found. Great for those cold winter nights. Days too.

2008 version. Pours a deep amber. With a light head. Aroma of rum soaked fruits and alcohol, some faint hops. Flavor has the fruits, with some vanilla, oak, whiskey. Very drinkable for a high alcohol brew. Going to save a couple of these.

2008: Poured a ruby brown colour with a thick tan head. Roasted malt aroma, toffee and caramel, some light dark fruit tones and some oakey vanilla as well.
Nice roast malt flavour, woody vanilla, dark fruit, toffee sweetness and some light bitter coffee tones.
Very nice and very drinkable. Very well blended for 8%+

Pours a warm light brown with a small, but dense head. Deep, earthy notes in the aroma, especially leather - I felt a little like I was smelling some old piece of rancher‚Äôs equipment that had been fixed up. A bit of wood in the flavor, which was a little flat for my liking. It was big, but unbalanced - rich malts weren‚Äôt countered by anything, and it ended up not being as dry / clean as I normally like. Good effort, but it needs work.

12oz from Bottleworks. Tawny and ruby red pour with a tight head. Deep and robust, leather. smoke. oak (mahogany?). old world ale like ‚ÄôAdam‚Äô. bittering finish but body is all dark and leather polish. nose is woody, a touch medicinal. very earthy; not my favorite.

Dark amber pour, alcoholic aroma with malt. Tastes of choclate malt and dark fruit (figs/prunes) - bready sweetness prevails throughout but taste is well balanced especially with the nice hoppy finish. Great carbonation/mouthfeel.

Poured a nice dark brown color with very little head. Aroma of malt, hop, and faint chocolate. Taste is smooth with a good finish of chocolate. Great balance in the hop vs. malt department. Great Seasonal. Maybe a touch of caramel toffee.
Poured a midnight brown, had aromas of chocolate or cocoa powder.  Tasted like semi-sweet cocoa and hops, and was disappointed that it wasn‚Äôt boozy.

On tap at the brewery, dark amber color, with a beige head, grainy, toasted malt nose, with some caramel, brown chocolate, nutty accents, with a faint of dark dried fruits, and a light floral hop grassiness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate witha sweet warming, grainy, toasted malt character, with a fruity, caramel, toffeeish note, and a light flowery hop leafy accent, some faint coffee, mochaish flavors, leading towards a warmth, toasty, lingering hop piney, leafy bitterness finish.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of smoke, hops, chocolate, roasting, caramel, pine, and wood.  Poured copper/amber in color with a small, dense, beige head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, hops, pine, resin, and tar.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Sweet, creamy, resinous finish.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2008 Thanks to robert for sharing this bottle. Light brown in color. Aroma was smokey, brown sugar, pecan nuts. Taste was enourmous amount of smokey burnt roasted malts but in a good way. Also little coffee, caramal. I will have to pick a bottle for myself. Good beer! Thanks robert*****Update***** Just had my own bottle, I am very impressed with this beer. Nice roasted malt taste.. Slight trace of alcohol but gives you that nice warming feeling. Very rich. Good winter beer.

Almost everything I want in a beer. Dark red/Light brown pour. Aroma is big on the malt and hops. Piney hop coated with caramel, toffee light roast in the aroma. One whiff of this beer and you know what you‚Äôre in for. A smile is inevitable here. Flavor is a plethora of flavors: Grainy sweetness, earthy but in-your-face hops, cocoa dryness and a faint tropical fruit meld in to a symphony of ridiculousi flavorisi. Nutty aftertones dance around the palate after each sip: A little bonus! Every nuance seems to be in balance. This beer is a spectacle. Nearly a year old, this baby still has lots of life left in her. Wish I still had some left from last year but, luckily, this year‚Äôs batch is just around the corner! A luscious brew.
Bottle.  Pours a mahogany brown body with an off white head.  Roasty and sweet with caramel malt, chocolate, and nutty.  A nice hop character with a rich warming.  Great beer.

Had on draft. Poured a glowing red/amber with brown on the edges. Alcohol was strong in the aroma with roasted malt and faint floral hops. A great taste of roasted malts and molasses. The alcohol really came in strong at the finish with some hops.
Bottle. Poured deep teak red brown with thick white head.  Aroma of caramel, malt and hop.  Caramel and malty flavour, well balanced. Lingering finish, more malt and a bit of alcohol.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 06 VIntage. Poured ruby amber color with small off white head. Aromas of malt, caramel, and some hops. Flavor was really smooth with almost a cherry taste. Alcohol is not present at all and damn, really liked this one.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 30, 2009 Nose is full of coffee, milk chocolate, burnt toffee and maple syrup.  Deep garnet amber color with a thick long lasting frothy tan head.  Rich malty sweet taste that transitions nicely through bitterness and warming alcohol providing excellent balance.  Full bodied, medium carbonation, with a long mapley nutty warming alcohol finish.  A superb beer, one of the best winter seasonal available.

bottle 2007(last winter) poured a light brown color with an off white head that fell quickly. aroma has dark caramel malt, nuts, and light hops. medium thick mouth feel with lighter carbonation. flavor is boldly malted, light roast, caramel sweetness, bitter resinous hops, and coffee. this has really mellowed nicely but is still bold and chewy. finish is lasting and well malted.

ambrato carico schiuma non abbondante non  molto persistente note maltate leggera sdpeziatura fruttato caramelo e luppolo in bocca malto dolciastra abbastanza fruttata piccoloe tostature caramello finale luppoloto che per√≤ non la rende molto amara

This has a beautiful deep red color with a thin residual head.  The aroma is full of toffee, grains, and malt.  The body is full and tastes of malty goodness, with only mild bitterness underneath.  It finishes with a malty, grainy aftertaste.  This graininess isn‚Äôt quite a barnyard wet blanket flavor, but a subtle form of that.  The alcohol is slightly noticeable and contributes to the experience.  Overall it‚Äôs a very tasty, interesting beer.

Pours a hazy orange with small tan head.  Pick up some sweetness and  alcohol in the nose.  Flavor is unusual.  Cocoa, vegetal, malty, sweet, bitter.  This was a pretty fresh bottle, so i‚Äôd be interested in trying some vintage stuff.

i‚Äôve always been a fan of this brew.This is 04 Vintage! Pours a medium dark amber but still see thru! Small head and medium bodied. Smell is of brown roasted sugar and malt. Taste Has mellowed. I Think i‚Äôve caught this one at it‚Äôs peek. Usually i think of this one as a great chocolate milk for adults.This beer is good,and all flavors have married. Cheers Conway!!!!!
The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass also. Very complex aroma. Starts very strong and intense - like a barleywine. A bit roasty-smoky, becomes milder in the end. Very good beer!

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2009 V - clearish brown color with a thin film of a head A - caramel, hops, nutmeg spices and toffee T - toffee comes first with a fading of alcohol and a lingering hoppy note P - nicely balanced with a good finish.

re-rate
rich oaked wood. big head, big hoppy malts and strong bitter finish.



re-re-rate on Blind taste at concordia. darker color slight coffeeish/floral notes. medicinal.

Pours a dark burgundy with small white head leaving scattered lacing, somewhat clear. Alcohol aroma with some strong hop and dark malt aroma‚Äôs along with some spiciness. Much lighter body than I expected creating an appreciated drinkability to it. Strong hoppy bitterness and nice roasty flavors coming through. Very distinct and damn good.

pours a small white foamy head. beautiful amber color. smells off toffee, toasty malts and hints of coffee. This beer is delicious has intense toffee and coffee\mocha flavors with beautiful tasty malt undertones. light carbonation and delicious.

Pours a deep amber/crimson colour with a small creamy beige that fades quickly. The nose is dominated by toffee notes with toasted bready malts and hints of cocoa. The flavour brings fourth a nice piney hop bitterness atop a rich coffee, toffee and roasty chocolate malt backbone. The finish is long and roasty with delicious coffee and toasty bread flavours with citric hops overlain. The body is medium/full with soft carbonation and a drying finish.

Bottle from Utobeer. Reddish amber in colour with a slight, off-white head. Malty aroma of powdered chocolate, dried fruit and spice, with a lot of pine hops. Big mouth feel, leaving a coating of chocolate. Spade loads of malt collide head on with grapefruit hops, before a long dry finish with plenty of warming alcohol. Too extreme and disjointed for me.

12oz.  Beautiful pour of a very rich brown/golden hue with an off-white head.  Nose is as expected for a "winter ale", loads of malt and alcohol with some essence of hops.  Body follows suit, overloaded with thick malt that tends to make me think of sawdust, dirt, grass, and sweet honey-oozing wood.  A bit heavy on the palate with a somewhat dry, awkward finish.  Just not quite feeling it.

Very aromatic floral hops some pine.
Pours dark amber with a large tan head. Great amount of lacings. Taste is brown sugar, molasses, some soy sauce, coffee, good amount of bitter resinous hops. Somewhat thick on the palate. Malts rule this brew but not by much. Alcohol is apparent but not overwhelming.  This was the 2007 version. Nice strong ale. Too high abv for frequent consumption though.

Pours a clear amber brow, with little head or lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, light hop.  Taste is malty with caramel, coffee, chocolate, bittering hops, and sugar.  Finish is bitter.  Mouth is creamy.

The most impressive feature of this beer is its balance.  It has the perfect blend of smokey caramel malts and hop bitterness.  Beautiful clear brown color.  The alcohol is dangerously well-hidden in this beer, if it wasn‚Äôt for that, I would drink this one all day.

Pours an even brown.  Smells of sugar, roasted malt and coffee.  The flavor is mainly roasted coffee and is evened out by the hops.  It has a great flavor which isn‚Äôt over the top at all.  Smooth and clean finish.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2011 Bottled - thanks to Reakt for picking this up for me.  A chestnut/ruby coloured beer with a slight off-white head.  The aroma is full on hops.  You can smell them from a distance.  There¬ís also a creamy warming malty alcohol hit.  Big, wondrously balanced flavours.  A ton of hops, great malty body, and superb big smooth alcohol.  A total sum of its parts, and a beer I could drink forever.  Score 4.4Subsequent rating scored 4.1. Average becomes 4.3

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2012 Back in the day, this beer somehow snuck into NC before the cap was popped. A rare high gravity treat! But it remains one of the better, more flavorful winter brews. It ages particularly well, with the hop presence that¬ís evident in its youth settling down nicely to reveal some of the warming malts and spices more fully. Subtle and flavorful.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle @ home. I¬ím in love with this stuff! Chestnut brown colour, nice creamy head. The aroma is awesome, notes of molasses, syrup, chocolate, caramel/toffee, resin and hops. Taste is gorgeous, just what you expect after sniffing the aroma¬ís. Taste is thus much the same as the aroma¬ís, but with a nice, dry, bitter finish that lasts. Texture is creamy and syrupy, very soft and dangerously drinkable. If you¬íre used to the Belgian strong ales, this will knock you off your chair!

This one is why you love to try new beer, on a whim, and reap the rewards of others obvioulsy hard labor.  This is such a vague category that it‚Äôs hard to compare with other A.S.A.‚Äôs so I‚Äôm gonna judge this sucker on an island.  Gorgeous deep brown hazy complexion with 1/2 a finger tan/brown frothy head. Amazing smell of chocolate like crazy, mild toffee and roasted nuttiness.  Flavor is more of the same and a perfect level of sweetness and alcohol. Flat out perfect mouthfeel for what this beer reminds me of which is a brown ale/ quad mix. Grab some of these, especially in the fall/winter.
Dark brown pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma of caramel toasted malts. This is sweet and malty on the tongue with molasses and caramel notes. Slightly bitter hops and a bit of pine. Finishes clean.

12oz. bottle--2004 vintage.
picked this up at the Whip In in Austin.
pours with light carbonation, color is nice tan leather. aroma is musty malty sweet. taste is dry, malt, and smoky. aftertaste is a slow fade of slight hop bitterness and wood-malt flavors.
Thx for a grand tasting, Chris_o :) Dark amber, notes of yeast, roasted malt, toffee, liqourice, sweet.

Bottle, big thanks to magic_dave6 for this one. Pours a fizzy dark chestnut with a thick creamy beige head. Nose is fizzy hops with some cinnamon, spice and strong alc. Mouth is sweet syrup, malty, some alc, molasses, with the robustness of Worcester sauce. Bitter and spicy. Almost some chilli! Rather good, but picked this on a warm day, not the best idea, but a log fire with snow outside and this would be divine.

Bottle 0.355 l. Bought Bjergtrolde Roskilde. Spicy aroma with chocolate and hops. Clear beatiful red-brown colour. Spicy taste - roasted malt, chocolate - a bit like The Dansih Broeckhouse Vintage. Medium body.
UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 Pours amber in color with tan head. Chocolate, caramel, spice and nuts with hops in the flavor .

Bottle. Nutty sweet spicy. Caramel and a candy sweetness. Lots of spice- cinnamon, clove, nutmeg. Light toasty flavors. Mahogany body with a thin swirly head. Sharp up front but thick and hearty. A good winter beer with a well rounded spice character.

12oz a gift from Dalekliz.  A series of 12ozers for the night.  Pours dark red with a 1 finger tan head.  Nose is malty with a bit of smokey caramel.  Taste is sweetl with lots of caramel and bitterness.  Pretty tasty and interesting.
Bottle @ Chris O¬ís tasting. Clear dark brown with tiny off white head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and hops. Sweet and hoppy flavor with roasted malt, caramel pine notes. Ends bitter.15

Wow I really liked this brew.  Its malty brown with scents of roasted caramel.  Its fairly havey in the mouth and tastes fo matly goodness, some bitter hops and a slight bit of pine.  The bitter finish lasts a good long time.  Superbly balanced.

Bottle. Pours red/brown with a sticky tan head. Aroma is piny hops first, which give way to caramel, roast, and fruit. Medium/full body. Smoke and roast hit the tongue first, followed by a sweeter caramel and fruit note and finishes with a nice grassy and piny bitterness. Very good.

Rich red-Mahagony with small off-white head. Chocolate, caramel, roast malts, and fruit dominate the nose. Flavor is salty malt dominance with caramel, but the hops really add some balance. Palate is perhaps a little sticky. Great Divide wins again.

Pours dark garnet red with tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, hazelnut. Flavors are sweet and similar to aromas with some hops and spices. Full body with average carbonation and a syrupy mouthfeel.

Bottle 355ml  
Appearance:  dark amber with sunny brown touch, medium light creamy top. 4- Nose  High alpha hops paired with some acidic , sour fruits. Toffee and vanilla. 7+  Flavor/Palate : Medium bodied , earthy nutty feel. Light brown notes  with hop bitterness . Some of spice added ending with clean alcohol burn. Neat.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and deep amber, golden, with a lacing light orange head. Wood hops aroma, a bit like wet wood. Flavour is smooth and dry hoppy yet with a nice chocolate smoothness and mild sweetness followed by a light liqourice sharpness and solid bitterness into the finish. Extremely flavourful, almost overempowering.

Reddish brown with a beige head, notes of slightly burnt caramel malts, cherry, spice, raisins, but none are overwhelming. A few different hop scents combine but nothing overwhelms. Somewhat sweet, earthy, a bit doppelbock-like. Could stand some aging, I bet.
355 ml bottle. Brown color, tan head. Aroma is hoppy with caramel malt. Flavor is hoppy and sweet with caramel. Nice!
Reddish amber. Thin head beige. Aroma is of chocolate and hop. Taste is mild presence of  chocolate, roasted and fresh hop, dry malt. Dry finish.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a big lacing head.  Wow! This smells great. Aroma of piney hops with a bit of brown sugar and alchohol.  Flavor is roasted coffee, caramel, toffee, mmmmmm.... bitter sting of hops at the end.  Lively carbonation and a very long lasting finish that kinda kills the palate.  I could see this one knocking me out for the winter.

Bottle: Darkish amber w/ a minimal off-white head. Chocolate caramel in the aroma w/ a little hint of alcohol. Flavor is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, a little smokiness & a touch of alcohol. Creamy mouthfeel w/ a dry finish. Very nice, don¬ít know why, but I was surprised by this one. Very good stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 12oz bottle.  Aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit and some earth.  Nice deep amber brown hue with an average off-white head that left decent lace and mostly diminished.  Flavor is sweet and hoppy with a good bitter finish.  Nice roasted malt flavor as well.  Palate is hefty medium body with almost a lively carbonation and very slight alcohol presence.  A very good brew from one of my favorite breweries.

Bottle from 2007.....Dark copper with a beige quite carbonated head with an appearance of soapy bubbles...Aromas of caramel and chocolate, along with the sweet malt smells...quite excited to taste this again and rate it...oh yeah! a smoky toffee flavor, leaves a sugar film on the teeth...sweet malts in the mouth and a baby bite of bitter in the finish...alcohol well disguised--wayyy too easy to drink for an 8.1% ...palate is light, yet full...this is a tasty creation

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 Bottle @ OT 080426. Dark brow with a red tinge. REally soft and malty aroma with notes of caramel and milk chocolate. Creamy. Medium to big body and a clean, creamy palate. You don¬ít really notice the alcohol, but it¬ís there to balance the malt and hops beautifully. I really like this beer.
8/4/7/5/16 4.0

Re-rate 081128. 
Bottle @ the Rover. Very powerful malty aroma. Hoppy citrus notes and chocolate cake. Thick body with chewy flavor hops and a citric biting tang. Very chocolatey and caramelly roastiness. 7/4/7/5/15/3.8
Pours reddish brown, beige head.  Caramel aroma.  Flavor is roasts, sweet, rich.  Some fruitiness and slight hint of alcohol.

Bottle. Dark ruby, thin head. Malty caramel aroma with a hint of spicy fruits. Sweet flavour, burnt sugar, roasted malts, some spice. Rather alcohol:y finish with some coffee and a hint of hop bitterness.

Beige thick medium lasting head. Brown colour with reddish shines. Aroma is malty with caramel and light spicy notes. Flavor is malty too with strong coffee and roasty tones, developing in fruity accents and ending in a moderately roasty finish. Medium bodied.
Bottle.  Pours a dark red almost brown with a thin fizzy head.  Roasted maltiness and some coffee aroma.  Thick and rich flavor that¬ís a bit sweet, caramel and roastedness.  Thick on the palate.
Deep red-brown colour with thick creamy head. Aroma is very sweet. Malt comes through strongly. Full, rich taste with some typical winter warmer flavours. Dry hoppy finish.
Big fat head, slowly diminishing. Heavy aroma, malty and sweet and a robust bitterness. A bit too strong in alcohol, but just a it. Definetly soething I could bring for an hibernation exercise.

12 oz bottle-cloudy, dark amber color w/a moderate white head. Roasted malt aroma, burnt malt flavor. Not roasted, burnt. hoppy w/a bitter finish. This one didn¬ít do much for me, the longer I drank it the less I liked it.

Bottle. Pours a wonderful deep dark ambur with reddish hough. A small tightly bubbled off-white head. Dense lacing. Nose is hops with a background of wet earth and dark fruits. Taste is strong hops and bitter earthiness, finishing with dark fruit esters and a hint of coffee. very nice strong ale.

A nice dark chestnut brown with a little off-white head at the top, leaving a nice lace on the glass as I drank.

Smells of hops and earth, nothing really outstanding in the smell but by no means unpleasant.

Taste of hops and earth and some coffee, somewhat bitter. No negative aftertaste, but it did leave my mouth a bit dry.

This was a really good ale and if I didn¬ít have to get back to work I would have drank quite a few more.

Serving type: on-tap
Pours a reddish brown with a nice white head. Aroma of malt, nuts, chocolate, hops and coffee. Flavor is very malty and roasty coffee chocolate and nuts. Has a nice mouthfeel as well.

Red/brown semi-clear with rather thick, lasting off-white head. Aroma is malty with nuts, fudge and hops. Taste is sweet with nuts and fruits/berries, and a bitter finish. Alcohol breaks through (which helps to keep you warm and cosy on a winter night). Runs thick.

pours dark amber/brown with huge tan head that leaves lacing all over.  aroma is slightly figgy, light though...flavor is first very chocolatey, then a bit fruity.  not a ton of alcohol flavor, but it will catch up with you.
Pours dark brown with a slightly tanned head.  Fruity malt aroma.  Nice spicy hop character on the flavor.  A little bit of warming down the throat.  Nicely carbonated.  Good enough of a beer.

Aroma: Hoppy and chocolaty with a fair amount of alcohol coming through. Flavor is more hops and mocha but a very nice burnt character comes in as well. But unlike many ASAs, it isn¬ít just a hoppy stout/porter, it maintains an ipa/red ale-like malt base with the burnt character sitting along aside it. Mouthfeel is very smooth w/ very good carbonation level, but it could be a lil thicker. Tasty.

Flaske. Flot m√∏rk ravfarvet √∏l. Kraftig duft af humle som ogs√• sl√•r igennem i smagen, god maltbase til at bakke den op. N√¶sten helt op at ringe, men en smule ubalanceret alkoholsmag sl√•r igennem til sidst. Men daym det er nogle l√¶kre √∏l de f√•r sig lavet.
Bottle at home ... Deep copper ... high malty fruity hop ... rich lots of piney hopes and hop resins ... little lime... little chocolate ... but just doesnt work for me that well.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2009 2007 12oz bottle.  Deep amber brown color.  Rich and thick, with a sweet and hoppy taste.  Very close to being a Barleywine stylistically.  Pretty well balanced, and relatively drinkable.  Lots of subtleties among the big hop and malt profile; chocolate, amber malt, pine, and toffee flavors galore.  Bottle holds up well with again, losing some hoppage, accentuating the malt profile.

pours a clear ruby-bronze with a thin off-white head.  aroma is roasty malt, cocoa & coffee, with an underlying hop scent.  taste is sweet roasty malt with a nice hoppy bitterness.  a great combination of roast and hops!  really a nice brew.  mid-full bodied with a creamy-but-quenching mouthfeel.  not to oily or thick, but has both the qualities of a nice choco-stout and a hoppy brew combined into wonderfulness.  definitely one of the best i¬íve had in a while.  would be an excellent session brew.  will surely buy again if i see it.
Reddish to brown in color with a decent head.  Malts, espresso, and slight alcohol in the aroma.  All of the contribute to the taste as well.  Not too bad.

Dark red-brown color with a head that disappears quickly. Aroma is coffee, caramel, and hops. Surprisingly light on the palate, but really warms me up somehow. None of the flavors are very strong, but i get some hops, maybe some cherries, and a little caramel. A little coffee aftertaste. Not bad, but the flavors could be more distinct.

Interesting earthy aroma of caramel and hops with a light hint of coffee. Pours a beautiful dark ruby/copper color with a thin off-white head. Smooth, light body with a nice caramel maltiness at first and a strange lightly bitter coffee finish. Not everything I¬íd expect from a strong ale, I¬íd definitely take and ABA or DBA, but still good for a nice cold night.
Dark brown colored brew. Aroma is malty, chocolate. Bitter dark chocolate, hoppy, coffee, roasted malt and strong liquorice flavor. Overall a nice brew.

Draught - @ HDG. Another winner from Great Divide. I have been drinking gobs of this lately. Nice aroma some coffee and lots of hoppy tones. Pours brown and thick and looks impenetrable in the glass. 

It¬ís deftly balanced the hops, the malts, the roasted flavors and the alcohol. This is good beer.
Drank it with Juancho at Hop Devil in NYC.  The first of the night.  Perfect balance between the malts and he hops.
Een beetje erg sterke smaak wel lekker maar ook erg apart.

Bottle that was given to me by Ian, Harrisoni. Many thanks for this one Ian, cheers  Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma I think is ¬íChoco hops¬í that¬ís my new word for big chocolate and hoppy aroma, Loz thinks dime bar. Nice initial fizzy bitterness, some cinder toffee, then good quality cocoa which slowly melts to reveal some nice milk chocolate flurries. The alcohol shows a little towards the end and the hops are ever present but they are well integrated here in this very well balanced tasty winters treat, loved it.

Pours dark, looks tasty. Aroma is coffee and cascade hops. Taste is fudge along with deifferent kinds of roasted notes. Nice bitterness in the finnish. This brew is fiery, too much taste of alcohol for me.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark brown with red highlights, thick tan head that disappears relatively quickly and leaves good lacing around the glass. Aroma is wonderful, filled with the smells of roasted nuts, malts, coffee, and cocoa.
