The taste is more of the same, an excellent blend of malts, roasted nuts, coffee, and cocoa that falls off into a clean crisp aftertaste with just a hint of alcohol. The initial mouthfeel is almost like its going to be thick and syrupy but end up being clean and tart leaving you wanting another sip. This is a great ale that I will be enjoying every winter from here on out.
Yum yum! First full-bodied and sweet, a little fruitcake taste and finishes with a smoky oakey deliciousness. I really enjoyed this brew of many flavors!!

Pours a deep brown with a lot of red.  Has a small light tan head that disappears quickly.  Nose of brown sugar, coffee, and a slight hop character.  Taste is sweet malty coffee.  Finishes a little bitter, but is an earthy dirt flavor.  Some molasses and a very subdued fruit hint.  Very complex, but muddled.

This beer has a nice dark dark brown color. It is almost black. Very nice looking American Strong. Thin white head that fades away quickly. The head is not impressive but the color is. This beer has a nice smoky, malty, and hop aroma. The aroma is very complex, and even when cold. The beer has a very roasted and smoky taste. The malts are very present. The alcohol is also slightly present, which is somewhat not good, but I am enjoying the malt and smoke presence. The slight hop taste isn¬ít overwhelming, and shouldn¬ít beer. The beer has a nice palate, but it is not anything extraordinary.  Overall, this beer is nice if you love malt and smoke. It is perfect.

12 oz bottle from a trade witht hecheeseman. pours brown with a small, short lived tan head. sweet dark malty aromas with noticable hops. the aromas dont jump out at you like with some big beers. flavours are mostly sweet malts but there is a bitter hop finish. not as big and bold as i like my big brews to be. enjoyable but not something ill long for in the future.

Thanks to drewbeerme for this freebie. Clear reddish brown, moderate head with decent lacing and retention. Aroma is sweet malts, mostly caramel, moderate hopping, fairly fruity. Medium bodied, quite sweet. Decent, but I like some of their other offerings a lot more.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a nice light beige head. The aroma is mostly malt, some sweet fruits and caramel. The flavor is really quite complex, with some hops, a roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and a bit of alcohol warmth. Some spices and bitterness round it out. A really nice brew. The best compliment I can give is that everything seems to be the right amount, all the flavors mesh well. Great job.
Bottle from Utobeer. Brown/ruby coloured with a thin white head. Alcoholic aroma with dried fruits and hop. Sweet, caramel, dried fruits, intense bitter finish. I thought this was a little crude.

Bottled. A lih√¨ghtly opaque amber beer with a small and disapearing beige head. The aroma is interesting, intense and contains notes of caramel, chocolate and fruits. The flavour is quite powerful and is maltier than expected, with again notes of caramel and chocolate, but the hops are well present with their citric character. Medium body, average carbonation, dry finish with medium bitterness. A strange beer, less bitter than expected, feeling at the same time really American. Good for winter.

2007 bottle. Pours a dark amber colour with an off-white head. Nice, but a bit hollow, nose with malty caramel, dried fruits and a perfumy note. Also a hoppy citrus note. The taste is sweet with roasted malts, caramel, some dried fruits, chocolate and powdered sugar. The alcohol gives some warmth. Long finish with roasted notes and a nice bitterness. Good one!
The aroma is hoppy with some malt. It pours a dark red colour with a beige head. The flavor is hoppy with malt and alcohol. There is also a bit of smoke.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2008 ¬í07 On tap at Fatheads.  Nice roasted malt aroma with some caramel notes.  Great flavor is dominated by nutty roased malts  that is balanced with just enough hops to make it fun.  The hops come out a little more at the end for a slightly bitter finish.  Overall this is a great beer.  

Update: Tried it in a bottle too and its very similar.  Still a great beer.

Wow, this was good. An Old Ale with a kick! Beer poured a dark brown with excellent head and lacing. Caramel base with some dark fruits and just a touch of roastiness or coffee. All that and a nice piney hop finish. Hops were a bit strong for an "old ale", but I really liked this "americanized" take on the style. Thick mouthfeel. Excellent!

This beer is freaking delicious.  Caramel malty, hoppy aroma.  Reddish-brown hue with excellent head retention.  The flavors are very well balanced between nutty, roasty maltiness and piney hops.  Alcohol content is not apparent until you¬íve had 4 or 5 and then realize it¬ís 8%.  Good from beginning to end, and a perfect winter seasonal!

Bottle. Pours a clear dark brown/amber with a large long lasting beige head that leaves good lacing. Heavy aroma of rich malt, roated malt, chocolate, floral hops, and a hint of caramel. Taste is the same as aroma with a robust roasty finish. Medium mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. Very good.

355ml bottle: Pours a very crisp dark ruby brown with an almost yellow moderate head. Very malty, biscuity aroma with a sense of graininess and a big hop backbone. Toffee, brown sugar, hop and caramel and christmas pudding dance around to the beat laid down by the grassy/hay-like hops. A very light touch of cardboard that doesn¬ít seem wrong. A very nicely balanced aroma. The balance in flavors is a little skewed towards the hops but by no means off kilter. Dark roasted cocoa beans, big malt, and a big grassy hop kick. It is less complex on your tongue than it is in your nose. However, it is a nice flavor progression which leads you to a decently long swirling brown sugar, chocolate, toasted malt and bitter hop finish.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, with medium beige head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, nuts.  Flavor is similar, very malty, caramel, some chocolate, peach, robust roasted flavor.  Bitterness in aftertaste--some from hops, some from roasted malts.  Little bit of alcohol noted as well.  Good beer!
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Great winter brew. Malty, but well balanced. Keeps me warm ¬ítill my favorite barley wine arrives. Creamy head with nice lacing.

Pours a five finger light tan head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace. Clear ruby/amber color. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Smoky/malty nose. Flavor is smoky, malty with some sweetness. $1.49 for a 12oz bottle from John¬ís Marketplace Portland, OR.

A big beige head, not to strong, it disapears in a short time. The color is light bright brown. Aromas of toffee, caramel and some fruits and flower. The flavor is dry toffee, with some caramel, some sweet and notes of alcohol. A nice drinkable beer for the cold evenings

The clear, dark crimson body sports a dense, spongy, cream colored head.  Thick rings of lacing adorn the glass in stratified layers.  The aroma shows rich toffee, roasted pecans, brown sugar, coffee, cream, and grassy hops.  The flavor follows suit, with bold flavors coming from both the malty and the hoppy side of things.  Biscuit, burnt sugar cookie, and brown sugar coated pecans are all present.  Cafe con leche with vanilla milk are in there as well.  Some piney, grassy hops provide excellent balance to this otherwise dessert-like concoction.  The medium-full mouthfeel is smooth, leading into a lingering, bitter toasty finish.  Solid brew.  A nice, warming slow-sipper for the winter.
Pours brown with an off white head.  Has a sweet aroma, mild chocolate and caramel, some hops.  Roasted chocolate flavor, mild bitterness.  Pretty good overall.

So someone left this at my house.  That someone is named Atlaggie and she is awesome not only because she left a good beer at my house.  Anyways, a bit of a porter feel to this one with some roasted malt characteristics.  Roasted coffee is that malt flavor.  Pours an almost opaque brown with red hue color.  Aroma of some red fruit and chocolate.  Kinda pleasantly reminds me of a fruit flavored chocolate bar. Big body but relatively quick finish.  Subtle flavors that all make this an easy to drink warming winter brew.
Smells like caramel coated hops.Smokey malts kick of the flavour which finishes with dreamy hops tempered by the malts.

AROMA - This beer had a strong coffee aroma and maybe a little chocolate.
APPEARANCE - Poured a clear copper/brown color with barely any head at all.
FLAVOR - As others have said, this is a very complex beer, and I agree with them.  I taste coffee, chocolate, prunes(?), chewy malt, cherries, smoke and a little hoppiness.
PALATE -  This beeer was well carbonated, sweet and hoppy in the finish.
OVERALL - This was a GREAT beer that was complex, delicious and it hid the 8.1% ABV very well.  Tastewise, this would make a great session beer, however the high ABV may make you regret making it one, the next morning when you wake up!

Bottle.  Wow, one of the most interesting and complex brews I¬íve ever tasted.  This is in the true style of an old ale and absolutely delicious.  This beer changes perhaps more than any other I¬íve ever tasted.  The first time I had this, I poured it very cold, and the aroma (and flavor to some extent) really highlighted the dry-hopping, smelling like an imperial IPA.  As it warms, the malts become MUCH more pronounced.  BIG brown sugar, caramel, hop spiciness, with a very interesting tobacco/chocolate aftertaste.  Slightly sticky on the palate, with lingering aftertaste (tobacco) that is slightly astringent.  An ideal winter warmer.

Bottle. Heavy malty, roasted, molasses, light yeasty and alcoholic. Dark red body, small brown foamy head, fast disappearing. Heavy bitter start, medium bitter finish. Average duration, later on the taste of chocolate shines through. Medium to full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, light alcoholic finish.
Very nice beer!
So I should try this one again because all I got was a lot of spice, spice and more spice. Like an Imperial Spice beer with some more crazy spices. Will re-rate somtime.
Clear dark orangey-red with a thick tan head that lingers. Woodsy aroma of hops, coffee, figs, malt. Deep flavor of malt and a bit of hops and spices. Very flavorful ale.

Bottle courtesy of moejuck. The pour reveals a clear brown color with a thin tan head. Very pleasant aroma of malt, caramel, hops and spices. Very good flavor of malt, caramel, hops and spices. The body is medium with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation. Great stuff.

Brown/ruby red color. Earthy smokey aroma. Rich roasted malty flavor with chocolate and coffee notes. Full bodied with a pleasant lingering spicey finish. It hides the alcohol well. Another first rate beer from Great Divide. As a matter of fact. i¬íd just like to say to all the other raters here is that...I love you guys. Give me a hug, you fuggers.

Bottiglia da 355ml comprata ad Alessandria; versa colore rosso rubino/marrone con riflessi rossicci e schiuma biancastra di buona consistenza e discretamente abbondante. L¬íaroma √® fantastico, dolce e sbruciacchiato, legna, bosco e cioccolata; il sapore inizialmente dolcissimo prende piede con toni da confettura improvvisamente e drasticamente mutati prima in un sentore di caff√® e poi in un amaro micidiale!!! Ammazza! che botta :) questi americani sono folli, mi devo un po¬í abituare a sto colpaccio, tanto √® che sorso dopo sorso mi ha conquistato pian pianino sempre di pi√π. Peccato che, quando cominciava ad intrigarmi, era gi√† finita... Che dire, buona, ma per me un po¬í esagerata nel suo sferzante cambiamento di carattere, prima il confetto e poi la cicuta! Per√≤ scalda, e l¬íalcool √® giusto avvertibile in un certo piccante, ma non si fa cos√¨ tanto notare in mezzo ad un casino del genere che ti esplode nel palato. Buon corpo, forse un poco leggero, ma almeno aggiunge bevibilit√† ad una miscela gi√† di per s√© non facilissima.

This one poured a chocolate brown color with a thin off white head. The aroma is of dark fruits, milk chocolate, sweet malts, and some piney hops. The flavor is much the same with the chocolate and malts leading the charge with the hops giving it a nice bitterness in the background. There is also hints of the dark fruits, coffee, a touch of spices, and some roasted malts as well. The flavor has a really nice complexity to it. This one is medium bodied with a smooth creamy mouthfeel that leaves a nice warming sensation all the way down. This is a nice winter warmer.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Gregis.  Pour is copper-red with some nice settling and a one inch tan head.  Aroma of rich maltiness, deep almost scotch like depth.  Some smokiness faintly in the background as well.  Taste is more of the smoky scotch malt, with just slightest hint of dried fruit sweetness.  Good full palate.  I really like the old world ale flavor, with the new world hop finish.  Finish is crisp and dry.  Nice beer, thanks Greg.

12 oz. bottle. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malty with notes of toffee, nuts and earth tones. Flavor is earthy with notes of malt cut by the hoppy bitterness so classic in the American strong ale style. There is a pleasant spicy complexity in this ale (nutmeg, cinnamon) along with the piney citrus of the hops. Very pleasant warming sensation and a medium mouth feel. A very nice winter warmer.

12 oz. bottle from 2006. Sharp and tart aroma at first but quickly fades to malty milk chocolate, plum, and perfume scents. There is also a musty, chalky component to the smell. Yeasty aroma with bread and muffin elements. Pours a hazy medium brown or dark amber with a brass hue. Moderate to large amount of cream/tan head. Extensive lacing. Coffee, candy sweetness, and chocolate-covered raisins in the flavor. Hints of lemon, apricot, and orange. Alcohol noticeable but not overpowering. Dry finish and aftertaste. Medium to heavy body. Oily, smooth, soft, and frothy in the palate. Easy to drink, especially for a relatively big beer. Great Divide Hibernation Ale with a year or two of aging is a very pleasant beer across the board.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a dark red with a small off-white head and a slight nutty, caramelly and roasted aroma. The taste is dominated by roasted malt and hops, with hints of black coffee. A great bitter finish rounds up a great beer

Dark ruby-red colour, medium off-white head. Aroma has roasted malts, coffee, and hops. Flavour is distinct; hoppy bitterness and fruityness is more prominent. Roastiness is noticable in flavour as well. Very nice.
Bottle 0,35ltr: Typical very hoppy American, sweet candy-like ale with great bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle - 2007 vintage.  Aroma is full of roasted malt, chocolate, toffee sweetness, and slight tinge of EtOH.  Pours a solidly deep brown, close to mahogany, with 2-3 fingers of creamy tan crown, decent retention and some fingery lacing.  Flavour has a huge malt backbone, lots of burnt and roasted goodness, with a prominent hop bitterness arising through the taste.  There is also a spice complex that causes a very pleasant and smooth finish, lots of cinnamon, mace, and nutmeg.  It is medium-bodied with low-to-moderate carbonation, the perfect amount of effervescence to allow the spice notes to come through.  An EtOH warming comes up the throat after the taste as finished, enhancing the spice aftertaste - quite pleasant, especially for a winter beer.  Overall a fantastic beer, very drinkable.  The flavour isn¬ít very complex - very straightforward but this is a case where simpler is better.  I can¬ít wait to cellar a few bottles of this and taste it next year and the year after that.

Bottle bought @ MicroBar. Pours mahogany with thin head. Aroma is malty / coffee / dark chocolate / slight hops. Taste is coffee / malts / honey / molasses / dark fruits with hops coming through in the aftertaste. Nice beer.

Pours a dark amber color with a great dark tan head with nice lacing.  Aromas of coffee and nuts, with some roasted malts in the mix.  Flavors of roasted nuts and and coffee with some chocolate and licorice.  A pretty good beer.

(35.5cl bottle) Clear, reddish amber colour with a big, beige and slowly lacing foamy head. Moderately sweet toast-malty nose with caramel/toffee, lighter notes of liquorice and peppery spicy, slightly resiny hops. Bitter-sweet flavour, full bodied with a moderate carbonation. Roasty malty taste with toffee combined with very subtle fruity notes, dark chocolate and liquorice spice; bitter-sweet, roasty and slightly piney hoppy finish with a long lasting, pretty aromatic aftertaste with an well-integrated alcoholic burn.

355ml bottle at Microbar, Clapham, 8th Jan 08, with tashi. Pours mid-brown with a ruby hint. Rich, malty aroma with notes of brie, smoked meat and soy. Great flavour of roasted malt, sweet malt, chocolate and a little smoke. The finish is smooth as silk with hoppy bitterness giving way to a deep alcoholic warmth. This is a great winter ale!

Nose of rich roasted caramel.  Feel is very thick and heavy.  Notes of chocolate in the flavor blend with the heavy dose of caramel and coffee.  Sweet.  Bitter hoppy finish.  Alcohol warming present, but generally the alcohol is hidden well.  Excellent.
1/12/08: On tap @ Smokehouse.   Deep ruby brown body with a small tan head.  Malty aroma.  Smoked malt flavor with hops toward the back.  Sweet and slightly bitter finish.

Classic example of a drink where you like all the ingredients but it does mesh together perfectly - regardless; a fabulous drink.  Heavy and thick with a very rich malt base - Slightly bitter Chocolate and sweet vanilla blend well into the silky profile. Slightly smoked alder woody essence with hints of nuts. Great hop presence that is well served by the aging process. Really a fantastic drink - exemplar winter warmer.
Really nice seasonal! A heavy malty laced amber ale. Some spices: maybe a little cinnamon? Great beer to sit back and drink while rest of family is arguing around the dinner table. Priceless.

Bottle. Clear bronze with a good yellowish head. Raisins meets citrussy hops in the nose- a pleasant blend. Rich nuts and raisins flavours, vinous qualities, some alcohol. Sirupy texture, full-bodied and rich. An extremely well-made beer- perfectly harmonious, but could it be more daring?

Bottle thanks to thecheeseman! Aroma is full of chocolate malts and biscuity grainy hints. Taste is balanced sweet chocolate malts and again grainy biscuityness, which i like, balanced with a citrus hop resiny backing. Nice but too much roasty malt character.

pours dark amber with an off-white head. The aroma offers a foreshadowing of the big malt and hops flavors that I¬ím sure are to come. Wow, the taste has a dark roasted malt character that I wasn¬ít expecting from the armoa. Nice surprise. Solid brew

Bottle: Clear, deep amber coloured, smaller, lacy off-white head, solid resinous hoppy nose, later underpinned by sweet dark and toasted malt; solid bitter-sweet flavour, full bodied; lingering resinous-hoppy finish, supported by sweet dark malt and followed by adry hoppy aftertaste. Good medicine.......

Pours a beautiful, rich, amber/copper colour, reminiscent of Bells Third Coast Ale.  Caramel, alcohol and malt dominate the nose. Smooth, syrupy mouthfeel and a robust hop flavour that also hints of leather, malt, cream and alcohol.  An interesting beer that proves to be dangerously drinkable.

Bottle. Slightly cloudy redish brown color with a slim, tan head. Nice aroma of roasted coffee beans, caramel, and nuts. The flavor is an interesting blend of hoppy bitterness and nuts. Nicely blended, clean finish. This is a winner of a winter brew.

12 oz with a Nov. 09, 2006 bottling date stamped on the case. 
Clear mahogany color with a 2 finger khaki head, nice lacing. 
Strong smell of blackened malts, roasted nuts, chocolate with a whiff of fresh hops. 
Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. 
Great taste follows the smell with rich, roasted malts and nuts with a lightly bitter hop and alcohol taste to finish. 

Only 8 days in the bottle it¬ís one of the freshest brews I¬íve tried. 

This beer also ages quite well if you¬íre the cellaring type. 

A very good winter brew here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Scrumptious! Rich malt taste with a thin surprisingly thin body. After tasting Yeti, I was expecting a thicker body from Great Divide. This is a yummy brew!

Bottle from Utobeer.  Ruby with thin lasting beige head.  Deep toffee and hop aroma.  West coast hop.  Smooth strong ale.  A lot maltier than Hercules.  Milk choc and grapefruit flavours come through.  A little powdery in mouth.  It¬ís incredible.  Unsubtle, huge, a kinda milk choc/lime juice thing I normally get from Rogue Dead Guy Ale.  Super.

Wasn¬ít expecting this.  Some light coffee actually, with a little chocolate to pair with it.  Some hops thrown in there as well.  Tried about half a bottle with a friend, and would love to get a 6pack of this myself.  Thanks shitstorm.
Draft. Dark brown body, small tan head, malty nose. Lots of chocolate, malty, light hoppiness. Nice.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2008 Pours a pretty dark red.  The good comments end there.  The nose is soy sauce, salt and funk, and not the good kind.  The flavor is like someone drained the grease from cooking bad hamburger into a beer.  Horrible.  Drain pour, and being as it is from GD I¬ím stunned.  I¬íve looked forward to tryiing this for a long time and I¬ím dissapointed.  I have five more of these.  Maybe I¬íll be in the mood for the next.  Maybe some age will help.  Maybe if I shotgun it.  


Re-rate 1/15/08

First beer of the night.  I either had a bad bottle or my previous consumption didn¬ít set up well for this beer.  Aroma of chocolate and rich brown sugar.  The first flavor is still a little meaty, but followed by a flavor that dances between sweet fruit and chocolate.  Still not my favorite beer, but not a drain pour, and definately worthy of more than a 1.4.

On tap at Flying Saucer. Has a dark amber color with a medium light tan head. Not much on the nose but a faint malt. Good lacing on the glass. The taste was malty with light hop finish. A very good american strong ale from Great Divide.
Deep brown nearly black in color. Malt aroma, coffee/chocolate flavor that is very smooth. Nice hop flavor. Overall a very good beer.

In trade with beerandblues2.  Pours a lovely amber brwon with a minimal head.  Malt rich nose also gives off hints of vanilla and almonds and a skash of day old coffe sitting in a paper cup.  No shit!  Body is malts and a helping of hopsaracter.  Chalky finish with some booziness.  maybe its the East Coaster in me, maybe I was tired, maybe I should blame it on that asshole in the whitehouse.  I¬ím not sure, but the chalkiness at  end of body lasted until seemingly forever and overshadowed all other aspects of this brew.  Even the zany way the light came thru the tulip as nearly prue ruby red.  Maybe I need more sleep.  I¬íd like to try this one again....yah hear that Mr. Blue?  I¬ím figgin that the old tastbuds were a bit tired.

12oz bottle-A dark amber light brown body with a nice big tan head which has an aroma of dark roasted malt, coffee, caramel, and slight sweetness. Taste if full bodied with roasted malt, caramel, apple, and slight alcohol. A very well balanced Strong Ale. Great for a cold winter night.

Nose of dried fruits, berries, port, malt rum and alcohol. Reminiscent of a bitter. Ruby/garnet red coloured beer. Taste is malty, sweet, alcohol burn, molasses, lemon. All in all a measured, mature and balanced oak tasting beer. Nice.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle from Brennan¬ís Country Farm Market in Brookfield, Wisconsin. Pours a dark reddish copper amber with a thick off-white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing and off-white ring. Aroma of  sweetened caramel malt, some apple, flowery hops and some hard fruit character. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of sweet caramel malt, some fruity apples, and a touch of brown sugar. Finish is semi-sweet at first and then a dry bitter aftertaste with some caramel and apple flavors. The alcohol level is detected when served extremely cold, but once brought to a more room temperature the real beer flavor comes through.

12 oz. bottle from Broudy¬ís at Jax Beach.  Pours a nice "brown ale" color with a slight white head.  Aroma is very malty.  Taste is, for lack of a better term, "Booyah!".  All malts, really nice caramel and roasted malts taste with a slight bite of hops on the end. What a beer!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2010 Jan 10, 2008
2007 vintage.  Pours a dark copper/brown with a big foamy tan head that leaves plenty of sticky lacing.  This was a warm-ish pour, as I found this tastes better when it¬ís not straight-from-the-fridge cold.  Aroma is rather subdued, but the flavor on this is HUGE and unique.  Caramel, brown sugar, coffee, chocolate and some spice.  Rich creamy velvety mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation.  Gently warming.  Wonderful, wonderful brew.  Haven¬ít encountered a Great Divide brew I didn¬ít like.  Highly recommend!
Aroma 6/10, Appearance 4/5, Taste 8/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 17/20

Jan 17, 2010
2009 vintage.  Pours dark brown, somewhat thin, with a one finger tan head.  Reduces to a wispy ring and leaves a fair bit of lacing.  Aroma is sweet caramel, toffee, brown sugar, some chocolate with a bit of a hop presence.  Flavor is caramel malt, brown sugar, with a somewhat hoppy, bitter finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Mouthfeel is on the thin side, a bit oily, medium carbonation.  Aroma is nice on this one compared to other years, but the flavor and mouthfeel aren¬ít quite there. 
Aroma 7/10, Appearance 3/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 3/5, Overall 17/20

Jan 17, 2010
2008 vintage.  Pours brown with a two-finger tan head that leaves a nice covering and some sticky lacing.  Aroma is very malty, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, molasses, coffee, chocolate.  Flavor is another caramel malt bomb with some brown sugar and toffee, some light piney bitterness.  Mouthfeel is rather rich, smooth, a bit of carbonation bite.  Very, very nice after a year.
Aroma 8/10, Appearance 3/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 17/20

12 oz bottle at Maggie¬ís Attic.  Dark red pour with minimal head. Chocolate malt, coffee, and hops all come out in the aroma, but hops are nicely subdued and balance the coffee/chocolate well. Thick chocolate malt taste with a coffee dryness that make this finish very nicely. Very good balance throughout this beer, a nice winter warmer.
This was an unexpected surprise this holiday season.  Smokey chocolate aroma with a mellow yet challenging flavor.  I like it!

Pours a nice dark amber with little head.  Balanced aroma of chocolate, hops, and roasted malt .  Flavor is excellent, but wasn¬ít as intense I as expected.  Found the first few sips to be a bit hoppy for me, but the flavor balanced out over the course of the beer.  Palate was a bit thin, but overall a good seasonal.

355 ml bottle. Pours copper with some cloudiness and a stable, very light brown head. Aroma of burnt sugar, plums and cedar. Initially sweet with a very long medium to strong bitterness. Medium bodied with carbonation that prickles on the tongue.

hopheavy winter brew that then tastes like four roses whiskey (watered down some) warm velvety and almost creamy with a rich foamy beige head this salty stanky fishy timekilla is quite a number. murkey and dirty like batch 375 this big big mama will be a favorite for all occasions. i need to make sure i get that ph# again! multidimensional work of art. big hop aroma tells little of what you are about to come up against. old taste with touch of sweetness.

Bottle from Uto. Deep amber with a lasting off white head. Nice lace. Sprucey orangey hops, caramel, malt and candy sugar. Vaguely reminiscent of cough sweets. Sweet caramel, malt and a long, juicy orange hoppyness in the finish. Well balanced with a nice syrupy body. Intense indeed and much enjoyed.

A Mes rate: 33cl bottle from Utobeer.Dark amber with a bright red hue and an impressive off white head that leaves lots of lace. Wonderful 2xIPA like aroma with some balancing rich chocolate and malty notes. Nuts and caramel too. A really inviting smell. Not quite so brimming with complexity in the flavour but with such a great balance of chocolate malt and grassy hops it¬ís still well worth the 8. Stunning rich toffee notes in the finish. This really hits the spot for me and where I feel some of the Great Divide beers are a little over-rated I think this is the other way around. Lovely beer.

12oz bottle at local bar.  Pours thick with little to no head.  Creamy, thick, even slightly surupy texture, very slick.  Robust hop taste, pretty sweet, but not too sweet.  Goes down smooth like a porter or sweet stout. 8% holds a good punch, although you can¬ít detect the abv by the taste or scent, so watch out, cause this stuff can sneak up on you! Good beer overall, I¬íll be looking for this next Christmas.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 Brown with a thick creamy vanishing head. Very strong and pleasant aroma of earthy and spicy hops, very piney with a nice nutty and little fruity maltiness. Load of residual sugars, a certain thickness in mouth, quite bitter but with strong sweet flavours of over riped fruits, nuts, dry figs, somewhat biscuity and chocolate. Dry hoppy end. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours reddish dark amber with a pale orange head. Aroma of rum-soaked cookie dough. Medium body. light carbonation. Sweet taste of fruit, burnt sugar, cookie dough, figs, spice, biscuit. Semi-dry and lightly bitter finish. With a little bit of age this stuff could be fabulous.

Pours a clear mahogany with a creamy, beige head that laces nicely. The nose is a lightly nutty mocha with mild notes of burnt roast and earthy hops in the background. The flavor follows the nose: cocoa and lightly burnt roast malt a with a slightly peaty & earthy hop finish. A uniquely different winter seasonal & another tasty brew from Great Divide.

this was a rather interesting brew.  Upon pouring, it looked reddish brown with an off white head.  aroma was full of chocolate, hops, caramel and malt.  Flavor was much the same.  OVerall this was a rather good beer.

Bottle.  Pour is a dark brown, but lets a bit of reddish light in around the edges.  Finger high head dies and leaves little more than a thin scum on the surface.  Aromas are of amber malts with a touch or a roasty character with sawdust an chocolate.  Flavors are interesting... starting out with a chocolate malt presence that gives way to a heavy pine/resin hops finish.  Smooth transition between these two flavors, but definitely a strange pair of bedfellows.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: (Tap) Pours a hazy brown color with a small tan head. Dry, dusty aroma includes cocoa and a bit of vanilla. Taste includes chocolate and faint java notes, in addition to a crisp hoppy bite towards the end. Silky smooth mouthfeel and above average palate. A great winter beer, in my opinion.

12oz bottle pours a deep brown with a moderate off white head.  Aroma seems to be a lot of dark chocolate.  Taste is of toffee and chocolate with a slight  hop bitterness to balance it out.  I enjoyed this beer.

Bottled. 
Clear red-brown colour with fluffy pale head. Aroma is rich with earthy hops, nuts and milk chocolate. Very soft mouthfeel, with hazelnuts, caramel and chocolate. The alcohol really shines through like never before, and there is a hop bitterness that is felt pretty harsh and astringent. Some parts of the flavour holds a grapey/piney hoppiness. Good beer. although minor flaws.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Bottle. Deep red/brown color with a beige head. Aroma: Spicy and bitter hops, sweet toasted malt, chocolate, toffee, alcohol, dried fruit. Flavor: Sweet and malty at first, then bitter and roasted. Notes of caramel, toffee, chocolate, alcohol, pine, flowers and dried fruit. Smooth and creamy moutfeel.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a pint glass.  This beer poured a completely clear, dark red hued amber color.  A medium-sized tan head quickly faded away into a thin layer of foam.  Some heavy lacing coated the entire glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of roasted caramel malts, toffee, mild bakers chocolate, and also some floral hops.  The flavor included pale English malts, caramel, light chocolate, and mildly bitter pine.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with light carbonation.  A very tasty brew.  If it had to be categorized, I think it would be considered an English DIPA.  Well done.

on tap @ papago. pours a dark red amber with a white head that fades to a ring. sweet aroma...brown sugar, toffee, malt, orange and english spiciness. flavor is much the same with the addition of some grassy hops and an alcohol burn when i exhale. it finishes lightly bitter and quite dry with a lingering taste of grassiness and spices. medium bodied with a creamy texture.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012 Dark orange/brown color with simple tan head.  Dusty grain and apricot aroma Medium body with mellow mouthfeel.  Roasted, almost burnt malt.  Good hop balance and presence, ends with a orange and a little cherry.  Dry finish.

12oz brown bottle served in a shaker pint. Pours a clear dark copper with a slight tan head. Malty caramel aroma. Huge malt flavor, full bodied.
Lots of toffee, some dry cocoa in the middle. Nice amount of hops to balance it out. Long lingering dry malt finish.
I really like this beer, it is like an American interpretation of an Old Ale, very much to the malty side.
A little too much alcohol to be really drinkable. After a couple you really start to feel it. This has been one of my holiday favorites the last few years.

Initial pour produced a reddish-brown body topped by a rocky tan head of foam which slowly diminished.  A very full aroma of malty chocolate which covered up any notes of alcohol (very nice.)  A sweet flavor which slowly converts to a bitterness.  A medium carbonation combines nicely with toasted coffee notes with some hints of alcohol.  The aftertaste, which was a strong toasty hoppiness, diminished rather quickly.  This is a strong ale with a great nose reminiscent of a good stout.  I knew I was going to like this ale from the first sniff and was not disappointed.  I picked this up at Binny¬ís in one of their mixed six packs.  Get this one, if you see it!

This is a great one, even though my bottle had three labels on it.  Tastes more like an English Strong ale than an American... not nearly as hoppy as most.  Sweet and dark, and the higher alcohol content is not present in the taste.

12 oz. bottle.
Nice winter ale. Taste of an English Strong. Almost like Avery Jubilation, but not as strong or dark. I don¬ít think I¬íd call tis a strong ale. More like a dark semi dark English strong.

Big Flavors.  Really great winter Beer.  Has a nice alcohol feel and some nice malts.  Pours a nice brown with a light lacy head.

If you can get it, drink it!

Never tried anything from this brewer, but am impressed with this offering. Seems to really be spot on for style. "Massive flavors" is correct. The color was real nice dark caremel with a red glow. Alcahol warms at end which is also OK for a winter beer.

a great winter brew! ... very assertive ... lacing is wunderbar! ... lots of sweet and powerful aroma¬ís ... pours a dark brown-red colour... had at Coops... balance comes into play with this beer, but where?? ..."i finally got my diamonds"..
One of my favoirte winter ales! My buddy gave me one last year and I fell in love with it. Since then I¬íve bee getting it alot, but have finally rated it. Great flavor, great smell, GREAT BEER!
12/09/07 12 oz bottle from the local BP, thanks Greg.  Pours a dark amber brown. light head with a nice bite.  Malty yet rich.  Awesome winter beer.
(bottled 2007): Pours a dark brown color, tannish head, okay. Very hoppy aroma some malts, fresh & fizzy smelling, coffee. Coffee taste, malty nutty, balanced somewhat by the hops. Some alcohol.

12 ounce bottle.  Hibernation Ale easily makes it onto my list of favorite ales.  First, it is beautiful to look at.  It has a rich, ruby color.  It has a frothy, off-white head that stays around for quite some time and leaves intricate lacing in its wake.  The body is clear and sparkles with excellent carbonation.  Drinking it in the Trappist glass suggested by RateBeer.com seems to greatly highlight its visual attributes.

The aroma is of heavy malts, with molasses at the forefront.  Dark fruits of plum, prune, and a hint of cherry are also present, as well as a spiciness.  The flavor follows suit.  It is a well-balanced blend of malts and hops, sweet and bitter, although there is a presence of slightly too much alcohol and a slight burnt wood flavor that are the only faults.  But, the spices, which I cannot quite place help to alleviate some of that harshness.  The body is good in the mouth and on the tongue.  A nice warming quality is bolstered by the vibrant carbonation.  I would have to agree with others that this would be a good candidate for the beer cellar.  Another year or two would diminish some of the minor alcohol and burnt wood imperfections and make the rest of the great flavors really shine.
Cherry red with medium head. Burnt malt aroma with a little bit of sweetness. Taste is burnt malt, with sharp spicy hops and alcohol. Dry finish. Could really use a good year to mellow out more.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2013 12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Beautiful ddep garnet red with alsting light brown head and lace.  Aromas of coffee caramel and hops.  Malty winey fruity coffee flavors with somewhat unpleasant lasting hop bite in the throat. Full body and medium carbo.  Complex but not altogether pleasing.  Harshness would probably mellow with age.

Maybe a different recipe than six years ago.  Mellow, roasty, woody bitterness.  Caramel and chocolate.  Very good.

Nice dark amber body pours with a bit of head.  Aroma is difficult to find but is dry malt.  Flavor is not hard to find.  It is roasted malt dark chocolate.  Dark fruit an coffee are also in there.  A nice alcohol kick adds warmth to the flavor.  This beer resembles a porter or even a stout in flavor and does not disappoint.  What a great beer!

This beer appears dark reddish-brown in color and is almost opaque. It looks syrupy as you¬íre pouring it. The head is small. The aroma is pleasant and fresh with a semblance of pine. The flavor is rich, sweet and powerful, and slightly alcoholic. The aftertaste is of roasted malt, slightly burnt.

Wow, this is a great winter beer.  Pours a deep brown with a thin tan head.  Powerful aromas of roasted malts and a wonderful bold flavor.  Rich malts and hops with a roasted, nutty finish.  Smooth, thick mouthfeel and a clean finish.  It¬ís gotta be the best winter beer I¬íve tasted.  Sure wish I had the means to cellar it.
12oz Bottle Pours out a great clear amber topped with a off white almost tan head. A very nice aroma of sweet caramell and hops. Tast of sweetness and some bitter hops on it. Very tasty.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a copper red with a very thin tan head that stays around for the entire duration.  Aroma of malt, dark fruits, and hints of smoke and toffee.  Initial flavor is caramel, fruity, and malts.  Flavor turns hoppy with a hint of alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel, lingering aftertaste, good lacing.  Drinkable and complex.

2006 vintage.  Pours a hazy chestnut with a thin tan that quickly recedes to a film with spotty lacing.  Nose is massive toffee, biscuit, plummy fruit, quite nice. On the palate, the biscuit malt explodes with roasty undertones, fruity alcohol warmth, finishing towards a more understated minty hop resin than I remember it being.  Initially syrupy on the palate, it clears almost too well, leaving only the faint mintiness and rather strong yeast dryness.  Has definitely mellowed over the past year, quite beneficially, as the hops are pleasantly present but the rich chewy malts dominate the profile.  A pretty good example of the underrepresented style of Old Ales in America.

I could definitely see myself hibernating with this beer all winter long. An incredible beer from start to finish and in many ways reminded me of a barleywine on training wheels. Aroma is slightly oxidized, caramel, toffee, and a clear cut fruity hop profile. Appearance is dark copper in color with a nice one-finger thick off-white head. Flavor is what grabs you, with enough malt and hops to please damned near everyone. A nice roasted malt backbone but balanced out with enough sweet caramel malts and pungent hops to keep it all in check. Easy to drink and easy to enjoy.

Pours a very dark mahogony color. Almost no head with a small soapy ring. Nose is faint and roasted. Tastes like hops and roasted malt (coffee). A very different American Strong Ale. I really like this one!!  Great soft mouthfeel.

Pours a deep clear brown with amber highlights into tulip glass.  There was a two inch tan head that formed quickly and lace stuck to the edges. The scent was of malt, dried fruit, chocolate and smoke.  A warming mouthfeel is the staple here.  A quick burst of smoked flavor subsides to leave a trace of chocolate, malt and alcohol.  Hops leave a bittering aftertaste.  This is a very interesting beer, not at all like I was expecting....almost a cross between an ASA and a smoked porter.

Pours medium dark amber, aroma of malts, hops, flowers, raisins, and roasted malts.  Flavour is of fruits, caramel, hops, and lightly smoked coffee.  Very smooth winter beer, I love these Great Divide beer/ales.  Seems to be a close IIPA to me, however it might be a strong ale to others.  Good beer.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Deep dark brown with a soap-like thin head. Aroma is smoky and fruity sweet.  Flavor is roasted and sweet with malt along with some spices.  Finishes very dry.

Poured with a sparkling ruby color.  The head is just a continuation of such a crystal clear and deep red, it hangs around and doesn¬ít leave the party too soon.  Initially picked up some berry fruits in the aroma but settled into good hop aroma and stronger roasted grains.  First sip is toastier than expected but warms as it goes down.  Finsihes with moderate spice.  Just makes me want to go to sleep.

2007 vintage.  Clear mahogeny, ruby when held to light.  Strong Nestle Qwik aroma arises upon pouring a chilled bottle.  However, alcohol, caramel, and raisin-brandy become much more  apparent upon warming to room temp.  Substantial amount of hops and not enough earthy/woody/peat flavor or sourness for me to consider it an Old Ale, (as the side of the bottle indicates).  Notwithstanding, malt clearly dominates.  Oily palate.  Finish similar to an American Barleywine.

on cask at falling rock.  Chocolate and cops on the nose of this dark brown beer with amber highlights.  Crazy mouthfeel and faint head.  Chocolate malt and light coffee with a hop finish and light caramel hint.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 355 ml, 2007 vintage. Clear copper-brown with red highlights. Medium-large and lasting head. Aroma is roasted coffee and dry  cocoa.  Big earthy-woody roasted flavor: dried nuts and cocoa, with some slightly sweetened coffee, raisins, and a nice touch of sourish cream.  Palate is medium-heavy, smooth, and finishes dry. Awesome brew that makes me want to do battle with an elk using a butcher knife. Whoever wins gets to sit next to the fire in the cabin, cook the loser, and sip this ale.
very dark amber on the pour with a one finger head light tan head.  very sweet malt smell right off the bat.  nice thickness on the palate and just the amount of malts on top of all the flavor.
Amber body with small off white head. Aroma is caramel malts and light allspice.  Quite rich upfront with a sweet profile before drying and hinting of a brandy burn as it goes down.

Bottle.  Ruby / amber pour with a very thin head.  Malty aroma with hints of oranges and yeast.  The malt aroma actually reminds me of the sam adams oktoberfest.  The carbonation is a little high.  I don¬ít think the dry-hopped flavor goes well with the malt in this one.  It just doesn¬ít blend or progress well.
Pours dark amber with airy off white head. light lacing with a yeasty nose.  Caramel malts with a hoppy twist up front. clean finish

Pours clear ruby with a thick persistent creamy light tan head and superb lacing.  Aroma is complex and dominated by roasted malts and lots of peppery spice with some flowery hops on the swirl.  Flavor follows and is very full with deep roasted malts.  Good hop profile comes out in a dry, but flavorful and not overly bitter finish.  Medium full bodied, with moderate carbonation.  Smooth and warming but not hot.  Very nice winter-influenced strong ale.  Seems like this malt profile will age well....I think I am going to lay a few of these down.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 On tap--Poured a murky black body with amber hints. Non existent head. Boozy, malty, slightly hoppy nose. Sharp, very carbonated mouth feel. Spiced with nutmeg and perhaps allspice. Robust , roasty, and somewhat hot on tongue.  Alcohol presence appeared more than 8.1%.  A sipper and real winter warmer brew.  Quite nice, but not excellent.

Poured a mahogany color, with a dense and bubbly head. Spice and malt on the nose, plus a bunch of hop. Leather, caramel, some soapy notes, but also cinnamon and nutmeg, C-hops.  Chocolate on the palate at first, quickly growing very dry, with assertive hops and nutmeg. Cane sugar, espresso, caramel... quite a lot going on, but it¬ís all in   balance. Finishes smooth and rounded, yet dry and spicy. Rich-bodied, pretty heavy, and also low on CO2 - one to drink slowly. But definitely a nice one.
Sweet and malty.  Definite alcohol presence in the finish but not overdone.  Balanced throughout, and very enjoyable.
Deep amber color. Big flavor. If there was a Double Brown, this might qualify. Good blance between hops and malt. Long and dry finish.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: 12 oz bottle from BottleTrek.com.  Pours a beautiful mahogany with a thin head with a lot of lacing.  Caramel and dark fruit nose.  Flavor is similiar with that addition of roasted malts, and subtle hints of coffee.  Very rich and the alcohol burns as it goes down.  I hope that this will not be so rough as it sits under the house for a while.

12 oz. bottle from Liquid Solutions. Huge malty aroma with hints of chocolate. Something of a mahogany color with an off-white head that was impressive, quickly left, leaving lace tatters. Full bodied. The rich roasted malt really does carry chocolate notes, and there is floral hop. However, I don¬ít think there¬ís enough hop to balance all this malt. That does not seem to be bad though. Something of a brown ale on steroids? The finish is surprisingly dry, and some balancing bitter builds up. This is really, really good ale.

The first thing I noticed about this ale was the dark amber color.  The second thing I noticed was the very rich malty taste that left an afterthought on my pallet reminiscent of chocolate... and mountains.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 Second time around (12/07), not remembering that I had tried it before: Damn, I¬ím good.  3.5 is right on.  A reasonably tasty beer but nothing really to get worked up about.

I get a bit of fruit off the aroma; first impression is that it bears considerable resemblance to Victory Old Horizontal or one of Dogfish Head¬ís barlewines (Immort Ale and/or Olde School).  Not as rich and thick in body or flavor, though.  Maybe more like North Coast Old Stock Ale (also 3.5) with a bit of added spiciness.  Arrogant Bastardy in appearance, but not quite as much head retention.  There, referencing the known to describe the presumably unknown; how does a review get more helpful than that?  You¬íre welcome.  (Dry and lingering finish.)

Presently listening: Legendary Pink Dots, The Maria Dimension
Malty-sweet aroma with some alcohol notes.  Mouth feel is very warm and even spicy malt, cinnamon cookies, raisins.  Very rich.
nice malty nutty nose some alcohol amber color dark dried fruits taste good malt nice winter warmer type, brown sugar is evident and a bit of floral hops round it out, good beer

Pours a dark copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is of caramel malts, nuts, spices, floral hops, alcohol and a little roasted malts.  Flavor starts off sweet with caramel and dark fruits.  Gives way to roasted malts, nuts, spices, and floral hops.  Finish is dry with a little alcohol warming.  Wasn¬ít sure what to expect when I picked this one up but I¬ím not regretting that decision.  Very delicious.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2008 Rubin red with a thick off white head. Aroma of dark and orange chocolate, coffee and citrus. Fat and oily mouthfeel.Tastes like orange chocholate, hazel nuts, spices, coffee and alcohol. Near perfection.
Dark brownish red in color.  Very dark caramel in this.  Nice sweet malty base and warming.

Bottle: Pours a red/brown color with off-white head. Aroma is of carmel malts and dark fruits and some hops as well. Flavor is malty and juicy dark fruits with some roasted malt flavors as well. Moderate hop bitterness throughout also. Lots of flavors in this one.

Brun √∏l.

Meget bitter eftersmag.

Alt for meget humle. Krydret, St√¶rk og syrlig.

Smag af Grape. - Er dette en IPA?

Had this beer on 2/12/2006.  Aroma is a sweet rich roasted scent.  Color is a dark amber with good carbonation and a nice head.  Taste is heavy and rich.  Starting with a full body it goes down smooth with a rich feel.  Finish comes in sweet with a sharp feel and ends with a full bitterness.  In the end it leaves you with a warm feel.  Overall its a bit rich and sharp for me but it is a good Winter Brew and seems to fit in its category.
3/25/05. 12oz. 2004 vintage. Mahogany with small brown head. Heavy malt caramel aroma with some hop undertones. The flavor had a very spicy bitterness. Full bodied. Pepper and coriander.

12 oz bottle - 2005 vintage
Thanks to Tom (CaptainCougar) for sending this as a bonus in a trade a few months ago.  It was really good even though for some reason I was thinking it would be a barleywine.  For a two year old beer it has held up well and I imagine it could take another year or two without any problems.  I¬ím unlikely to pick up another bottle simply due to the sheer volume of other things in my queue but if you get the chance to try this it is worthwhile.
Aroma / Appearance - The flat deep brown body had a very short lived head and minimal carbonation.  The nose was caramel, black cherries, cooled sun tea and black licorice.  There were some hops evident but they were old from age.  As it oxidizes the nose begins to lighten up.
Flavor / Palate - Chewy toffee, molasses and alcohol are succeeded by a dry papery aftertaste.  For an 8% ABV beer it was very drinkable.  The middle of the bottle reminded me of carbonated iced tea with a handful of pop rocks tossed in for extra measure.  The finish was bitter and lingered on the back of the throat.  This isn¬ít too bad though I would like to have compared a fresh bottle to see how it has aged.

fantastic stout. smells like malt, little oak and hops. flavor was sweet, nice gentle hops, honey and than finshes with a little bit of a warmness from the alcohol.  poors black with a light tan head.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Date: December 12, 2002
Mode: Bottle
Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta
Appearance: Dark amber, nice tan head
Aroma: light malt aroma
Flavor: rich dark malt flavor, nice dose of spices

Date: November 20, 2005
Appearance: clear dark amber, thin beige head
Aroma: light spicy malt aroma
Body: solid chewey body
Flavor: rich warming malt flavor, a touch of chocolate, mostly dry, a bit of ripe fruit character, nice spicy character, light balancing bitterness

Date: December 09, 2006
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Appearance: lots of lace
Flavor: sweet fruity malt flavor, young sweet fruit, needs age, plenty of bitterness in the finish, too much raw sticky spicy sweetness

Date: October 20, 2011
Mode: draft
Source: Taco Mac, The Fred
same sweet rich malt with big spicy character, really does best with a few years on it for the malt to ripen and the spices to mellow, I think I may have a vintage bottle in the cellar that may be just about time to crack...

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **+ /4

Date: December 07, 2005
Vintage: 2002
Appearance: opaque amber after a nice yeasty pour
Aroma: rich earthy aroma with a touch of ripe fruit
Flavor: flavor has lots of the oxidized easthy quality and a bit of ripe fruit, even bitterness, touch of tartness

Date: October 11, 2007
Mode: draft
Source: brewery
Vintage: 2006
Aroma: sweet dark caramel and chocolate aroma with a nice earthy spicyness
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, nice brown sugar sweetness, light fruity character
Overall: age works well on this beer
Pours a pretty dark brown.  Aroma is nutty, roasted, caramel, and malty.  Molasses, roasted, fruit, and some bitterness. This was only a year old, can¬ít wait for the others at a 4yr vertical.

2004 12 oz bottle thanks to joeec. Poured a murky muddy brown with a light tan average size creamy head. Aroma was nice and complex with lots going on including honey, oak, chocolate and some dark fruit. Flavor was sweet with with only a hint of alcohol. Palate did haave a touch of alcohol warming in the back if my throat and light touch of carbonation. Very nice beer that I will have to search out this season.
Pours a brownish color with a off white head.Great big malty/alcohol/fruity aroma to this one.Great malty molasses flavor with a nice bitter finish to it.very good!
Poured brown with creamy off white head. Aroma of fruit and caramel. Big sweet caramel flavor with hints of molasses, fruit, and vanilla. Finished with a hoppy bitterness.
A great winter time ale. This beer has a sweet finish with a great hoppy taste that you can enjoy on a cold night. A very dark body that is full of hops and roasted malts, almost like a sweet stout.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 Deep mahogany beer with a lasting off-white head. Rich malt aroma with caramel, molasses, dried fruits, port, vanilla and some citrusy hops. Good malt flavour with plenty of hops to balance. A wondeful late night sipping beer.

Vintage 2005, in 2009: A little more wine and chocolate, a little less hops. Smooth malt and chocolate flavour with a lasting malt aftertaste. Not a lot of difference from a fresh bottle, but certainly not hurt by cellaring either.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a crystal clear ruby red beverage with a small creamy off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left some good lacing on the glass. The aroma was complex and fairly strong with notes of caramel, roasted nuts, dark dried fruits and floral hops. The body was medium-full with lively carbonation and a smooth, creamy texture. The flavor starts out fairly sweet and remains that way through the end of the long finish. There is a decided warmth that creeps into the chest toward the end as well.

Verre de d√©gustation, provenant d¬íune bouteille de 12 oz, d√©gust√© au Mondial de la Bi√®re 2007 (Montr√©al, QC). Ar√¥me: Odeur de caramel fruit√© avec une pointe de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est ambr√©e fonc√©e. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col beige mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de caramel br√ªl√© et d¬íhoublon avec une pointe d¬íalcool. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Pr√©sence de caramel en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #1075)

(Bottle (2005) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>CaptainCougar, thanks Tom!) Pours a cloudy brownish amber with about 1/2" of biege head. Aroma of candy-malt sweetness. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, pretty meaty. Thick rings of weepy lacing. Flavor is candy malt sweetness in the fore followed by a quick, kind of piney bitter bite, then flavor sort of dies off quickly where I was expecting something else to come. A little hot but more in a warming way than a burning way. A bit like a barleywine. Nice and tasty if not super complex.

Appearance: Pours a rather good-looking burgundy body with a creamy, off-white head.

Smell: This beer definitely has a hugely sweet aroma! Candy sweet caramel with a dusting of cocoa powder. There¬ís plenty of alcohol esters present, along with some subtle citrusy hops lurking underneath.

Taste: Rich maltiness through and through. Toasted caramel and brown sugar as well as the distinct taste of dry cocoa. There¬ís a slight ripple of fruitiness along the way. Lastly, some pine hops and smokiness rounds out the finish. The result was a beer which retained the luscious flavor of the malts, but which still imparted enough hops and spice that I felt I had really LIVED this beer, and not just chugged it down.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, but further fullified by its syrupy texture.

Drinkability: Truly, this beer is an enjoyable malt-forward ale and a solid winter release.

Rated 12/1/06:  ¬í05 edition, this is a mighty fine Old Ale/Strong Ale that drinks like a Barleywine. Thick amber pour with an initial fluffy head that dwindles to a nice film that leaves a lot of lacing. Hearty aroma, slight alcohol tinge to the nose. Heavy maltiness with an equally heavy hop scent roasted malts and floral hops. Not too thick on the palate, this is a relatively easy drink considering the potency of this brew. Flavor is intense and wonderful. Thick dark malts of caramel and coffee along with some bitter cocoa. Thick hops, rather floral with a resinous bitterness. Oh boy this is spectacular, very enjoyable on a blustery windy Friday night.
Bu au Mondial 07. Rousse terre cuite, peu de collet. Arome de malte caramel licoreux, un peu v√©g√©tal. Go√ªt de caramel faible, plus d¬íherbe et d¬íalcool. Pas pire mais...

12 oz bottle, bottled in 2006 from mreusch - thanks Matt! Pours a brilliant, clear, deep red mahogany with a thick beige head. Huge malted milkball nose, chocolaty and sweet. The body is near perfect, silky smooth and lightly creamy, one of the best I¬íve ever had in that department. Flavor is rich sweet malt and chocolate, grassy hop notes. Surprisingly zingy finish, almost light. Nice!

Deep mahogany color, or a rich red under a darker light, with a smallish head--not much carbonation. Exquisite, jaw-dropping aroma  pulls you in with bursts of toffee, caramel, and a whiff of deep, dark chocolate. Flavor emphasizes  candi malts with some chocolate on the finish then a re-emergence of toffee that lingers delightfully on the palace. The main detractor of this beer is the bitter bite. I expect this will improve markedly with age once the hops subdue and the malts further evolve. I will buy some to cellar for this purpose--should be sensational by winter.

12-oz. Pours a deep ebony black with a tall, thick, sudsy tan head. Nice plummy, figgy, grassy head. Not what I was expecting at all, for whatever reason. A little bit metallic, as well, both on the nose and the palate. Plenty of good stuff going on on the mid palate, which I love--caramel and butterscotch and lots of grain husk; nuts and leaves and earth and biscuity spicy goodness. This is really some sensational stuff and it hits me just right. Curious how it ages; this is this year¬ís batch, maybe 6 months old.

12oz. Bottle
$1.65 single

2006 Bottling
Poured with a very dark red body that I¬ím unable to see through. A 1-finger head formed briefly before falling to a creamy swirl of a cap. When held to the light the body turns firey red with clumps of slowly rising carbonation bubbles. Looks flavor packed. It¬ís tempting me.

The smell comes through with big caramel. As a matter of fact it brings to mind caramel apples. Theres some mustiness and dampness that compliments things nicely. Hops come through at the finish but are mild. Pine needles and a splash of citrus.As it warms it takes on a boozy character.

The taste is deep and rich. Like a winter seasonal should be. The big caramel carries over from the smell and is balanced nicely with a solid citrus hoppy goodness.There¬ís toasted grain coming through mid-palate and a faint hit of the mustiness. A spicy alcohol character finishes things off on the swallow. As this beer warms the flavors get more complex. I don¬ít get much hop bitterness but I can sense my tongue going a little numb. That¬ís pretty unique. Nicely done.

Mouthfeel is good for a high abv beer. Medium bodied with mild carbonation so the beer just makes its way slowly over the tongue. Theres a nice creaminess for the body. It¬ís in no way viscous like a lot of other beers of this strength are. The alcohol gives a nice warmth, especially as this beer warms.

The drinkability is good for a stronger beer. The body has a lot to do with this. I don¬ít think it would be so easy going down during the summer months but when it¬ís cold out Hibernation is hard to beat.

Overall this is one of my preferred winter seasonals. I try and have it on hand if I spot it around here. Very well made beer and something to look forward to every winter. The next step for me will be aging some for next winter.

12/12/06

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2007 Clear redbrown color, short off-white head. Aroma of hops, caramel malt, bit spicy, some alcohol. Belly warming. Taste of caramel malt, some alcohol, bit fruity. Bit sticky palate.

Bottled (Bottled 2006). Murky reddish brown colour with a long lasting yellowish beige creamy head, leaves nice lace. Aroma is nuts, plum, raisins, caramel malts, slight alcohol and a nice touch of hops. Flavour is roasted coffee, malts, some chocolate, bittering hops and slightly spicy. A very nicely warming brew, that is enormously wellbalanced. Leaves a nice roasted and hoppy aftertaste.

Murky reddish brown with a thick brown head that didn¬ít last long.  Aroma is sweet malt, apples, plums and a bit of herbal hops.  Malty flavor accented by cocoa, plums and earthy, herbal hops.  Nice bitter, smoky finish rounds it out nicely.

355ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki , American Week 2007).
Marmite! But only in a positive way.Ginger too, heading in the direction of a S.N. Bigfoot. While the ginger is perhaps a little prominant, there¬ís plenty of malty complexity and bitterness. Far more balanced than the other Great Divide beers I¬íve tasted.

2006 bottle. Unexpected chocolate smell right out of the bottle. Honest, that¬ís what I got. Pours out a ruddy brown with clear highlights, no hint of any deep roasts. Big stuffy brown head on top. Rich and thick malt flavor: cocoa and caramel apples, maple-flavored pipe tobacco and, yes, alcohol. A northwestern hop profiile seems to be in there, but it¬ís hard to find against these cheeky malts. Hop spices do come up further down the glass to help distinguish this from a barely wine. And of course I¬ím having this one a little fresher than most of my big beers, but I have no regrets over opening this now.
Bottle. Chestnut color with an off-white head. Nice aroma. Flavour is light roasted with a thin dry and hoppy palate.

Botle - 2006.  Pours a clear dark ruby with a slight off-white head that disappears immediately.  Aroma harsh, heavy cut-grass, with some resin and slight grapefruit.
Flavor is equally harsh, bitter and grassy, with a dirty, gritty texture.  A hot alcohol taste with a medicinal quality like cough syrup predominates.  Finish is bitter and long with a slight silky sweetness just barely peeking out.  Perhaps this one needs to age a little?

bottle - Pours murky brown with almost no head.  It has a caramel malt aroma with some citrus hops lurking in the background and a hint of plum.  The flavor is sweet caramel with some spice and mild hops.  The lingering finish is moderately bitter.  It¬ís a little thinner than I¬íd have liked and has a light carbonation that goes down well.
Tasted 2007-03-30. 2 years old bottle, 35,5cl. Dark red/brown colour. Nice off white head. Powerfull aroma of hops and grass and flowers. Somewhat bitter taste, but round and complex! Love it!

12 oz bottle, via sliffy.  Pours a clear mahogany brown with a ruby glow under a small fizzy beige head that fell to a thin film leaving lots of heavy lacing.  Aroma is very malty with a husky graininess.  A little toffee and caramel and a hint of alcohol.  Kinda like a souped up Brown Ale.  Flavor is nutty and toffee malt up front with a little resiny hop bitterness and a good amount of alcohol on the finish.  Quite a weird combonation.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a slightly grainy huskiness and a very prickly annoying carbonation level.  A little sticky on the finish.  Overall, I just kept coming back to a higher gravity Brown Ale concoction.  Can¬ít say that this one worked for me.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2011 Malty, raisinny somewhat earthy aroma and flavor with blackberries. Long earthy bitter aftertaste with licorice. Fine strong ale.


Bottle, best before 9/07, tasted in june 2011. Still a firm head. Licorice in the syrup-like aroma. Sweet flavor with licorice, anis and coughing syrup. Thick and sticky, but still a lot of life left.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown tanish coor. Aroma of chocolate and malt is present. Taste is nice and smooth with a chocolate and malt finish.

Poured a brown color with good head and average lacing.  Aroma was brown sugar coffee and pine maybe.  Flavor was carmel pine hops dark fruits.  the hops had more bit then i am use to in old ales.  Good beer.

On a snowy April day, a beer called hibernation ale sounded like a good idea.  Nice beer, one of the better winter seasonals I¬íve had in a while. Fruity, but the bitter aftertaste brings its score down a bit.

12 FL PZ bottle from mid 2005.  Very strong aroma.  Very similar to wine, has a chocolate smell along with several other fruits,  Color seems be more red than brown to me with a bit of tan head.  Taste is excellent, the more bottles of it you drink the more things you feel you are tasting.  The 8.1% alcohol is hidden very well.  I find this beer to go along very good with chocolate or anything sweet you may be eating.  A very good American beer.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a tan head. Sweet malty flavour with citrus & caramel. Flavour of grape fruits & toffee. Spicy and nice.

12oz Bottle-2006: Pours a deep rusty brown with clarity, and topped by a tan film. Extremely aromatic, I smelled it as soon as the cap popped off. Initially sweeter, with some chocolate, yet it gains much more. Has a great earthyness, peat, lots of nutty suggestions (almondy), caramel, sweet flowery hops, and even more. Flavor is similiar to the aroma. Solid malty body, without being sweet or cloying. It has a great nutty character, and a chewy earthyness with a nice spicy hop component. There¬ís also a subtle, smooth mint touch; along with light almondy sweetness in the background. The hop presense gives it a balancing peppery dryness. Nice nutty/dry smooth finish. Alcohol is very well hidden, quaffable. A great American Strong Ale!

2005 vintage. Chocolatey fudge, Tootsie Roll, with malted milk cocoa powder. Sweet with vaporous alcohol. Raisins, plums, brown sugar. Dark amber ruby clear with light tan lacing head. Heavy watery body with mild-medium carbonation. A bit of chemical harshness. Dry bitterness under some warming alcoholic notes. Mild sweetness from sugary malt, raisins. Wood chips and acetone. Bitter finish with chemical after. Can¬ít tell if this would be better fresh or not.

12 oz bottle pours a medium to dark brown semi-clear body with a thin and quickly fading off-white head.  Active carbonation.  The nose is of apricot, oak and alcohol.  The taste is earthy with some vanilla and spices thrown in, with a hopped up grassy kick to the end.  Warm alcohol feel and not too bitter on the tongue.  The best Great Divide I can remember.

Bottle. High alcohol presence in the nose with hops, molasses and a hint of barrel aging. Ruby reddish amber that is more red than amber. Small, off-white head. Pretty color, decent lace. Looks ruby red in direct light and cloudy brown away from light. High alcohol dominates the palate. Sweet. Hops are subdued. Nice, enjoyable, drinkable, warming brew. Very good.
Very strong wine like aroma, appearance is translucent brown with little head.  massive hop infusion poignant at beginning and end, notes of pine
some raisin, raspberry, cherry, and carmel corn, with flavors of carmel, vanilla, raspberry, cherry, and some orange with some hops.

Very deep ruby pour with pretty and vibrant mahagony wood hues, mostly translucent but almost too dark to tell. Looks like a liquified tree with a well retained head. Lacing is exceptional. Aroma is rich roasted malts coupled with nuttiness, toffee, brandy, plenty of fruits(raspberry, cheery, navel orange, peach) and slight vanilla and other assorted spices. Hops are nicely represented and in ample quantity without subduing lovely maltiness.Very nice. Flavor is more bitter than expected, medium high levels of hop resins and acidity are sharp and recklessly thrown about. Otherwise the flavor is similar and nice. Finishes moderately bitter, lightly to moderately dry and long and mildly warming. Palate is medium to medium-full, a touch sticky and moderately slick, very well carbonated. Pretty tasty fireside companion. Older well-kept samples have proven remarkably tasty, drying out nicely, steady noticeable hoppiness fading to a serene level. This beer would be a good candidate for long term wine barrel aging.

Bottled. Chalice. This amber beer is something lacking in visual aesthetics. Thin head that fades rapidly. Hard to get a good aroma, but when strained scents of sweet roasted malt, candy carmel and some spicy/earth is distinguished. The mouth feel takes me by surprise. Very lively medium body. Flavors of chewy malt are a bit overwhelming with a very bitter alcohol finish. Notes of warming spices, caramel and a very light pine can be perceived. Okay beer. Not special.

Bottle.  Brownish red pour with a fine off-white head.  Smoky and malty aroma, toffee, vanilla, oak, coffee, slightly acrid.  Like smoked almonds.  Interesting.  Smoky and roasty flavor, malty, toffee, awkward sweetness.  Like artificial sweetener or toothpaste.  Complex and accented by alcohol.  Not too shabby, but the weird flavor right before the finish really threw me off.  A little flat on the finish also, but still an above average brew.

Bottle courtesy of BeerandBlues2: Poured a clear dark brown color ale with a small foamy head with better then average retention. Aroma of rich caramel malt with some medium sweetness. Taste is mix between good caramel malt with a medium bitter finish. I thought the body was a bit too thin for the style and alcohol was very well hidden. Overall, I thought it was interesting but lacking a little something to bring to the next level.

Clear deep amber with a small tan head. Average retention. The aroma feels a little one dimensional, a bit of toffee and a touch of coffee... no sign of the hops. 
Flavour is much the same, light roasted malts give some vienna feel to it. Towards the finish I got some citric hops and some sweetness. Roasty finish. Its almost disappointing.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 This to me is nearly the perfect brown ale.  Excellent dark fruit flavor with hints of carmel/chocolate, citrus hops, and a slight smokey taste.  Definitely on the sweet side, but to me, it¬ís balanced perfectly with the alcohol and fruit.  Love the bold flavor.

Great Divide Hibernation Ale
12 oz bottle
Bottled winter 2006, awakened 02/07
Medium pour in a tulip glass.

Poured a murky amber orange brown with an average fizzy mostly diminishing light brown head.

Smelt of moderate to strong toffee, caramel and roasted grain.

Taste was upfront strong bitter grassy hops, roasted grain, with moderate caramel sweetness followed by a harsh bitter sweaty and rustic yeastiness with a light caramel on a long bitter grassy and yeasty finish.

Palate was medium bodied, oily, lively carbonated, strongly astringent and moderately alcoholic.

Overall, a strong malty and yeasty strong ale.  A little heavy on the alcohol and the astringency, but that should mellow out with age.  Flavor is phenomenal.

Pours a deep dark red with a nice tan head.  Aroma is a pleasant, mellow maltiness that is slightly sweet.  A pinch of chocolate underneath.  Medium to thick mouthfeel.  Tastes very malty with smooth chocolate and a long finish.  Quite tasty.  Another impressive beer from Great Divide.

Brown color, yellowish head, good lace. Sweet, raisin, light nutty, bitter, grass, herbs. Full and sticky with a dry finish. Very flavorful. Bottled, Mar 07, 3.0: Aroma of dades, raisin and floral hops. Light hazy, copper/brown colored, beige head, fair lace. Sweet, bitter, hops, thin. Something is really missing. It¬ís plain and boring but not bad.
Aroma of hops and some fruit. Clear, amber-brown coloured with a thin, off-white head. Taste is sweet with an hopbitter finish. Not much interesting in this one. Quite boring.

Bottle. [Vintage 2005] Appearance of head was small off-white and fizzy. Not much lacing. Body was slightly clear with a sparkling look and a brown reddish hue. Aroma was surprisingly hoppy with notes of sweet malt. Pine, grass, caramel, fruit and some spice. Some notes of alcohol could be felt in mouth. Medium bodied with a dry texture and a soft carbonation. Flavor is light to moderated bitter from the hops. Some balancing sweetness. Dry, crisp and light bitter finish. Lovely American Strong Ale!

12 oz. bottle courtesy of illini08, thanks Jeremy.  dark amber to brown on the pour with a short lived tan head.  malty aroma with a bit of citrus.  flavor is quite nice, kinda like an old Ale to barleywineish with malted barley, brown sugar, alcohol and citrus hops.  mmmmmm tastey

pours a very dark reddish brown with a one finger fluffy off white head that does not last to long. aroma is malt, hops, and orange peel and a touch of alcohol. has a medium body with ok lacing and carbonation. flavor is sweet malt with orange peel hops and a touch of alcohol. has a nice dry hoppy aftertaste and is another nice brew from great divide! has a warm feeling going down from the alcohol, it is a very nice winter warmer. aroma does get better as it warms went from a 6 to a 7. some roasted malt comes out as it warms in the aroma and flavor.

Vintage 2006...  Great Divide Hibernation Ale is fairly dark amber in color, but still transparent.  It has a small, frothy brown head with decent retention and speckled  lacing.  Malty aroma with notes of caramel, chocolate, and something nutty.  There are some earthy, citrus hops also dectectable as well as traces of slightly astringent alcohol.  The flavor is malty and earthy and reminds me vaguely of tea in some ways.  There is a bit of sweetness just before the hoppy, gentle bitter finish.  The hop profile seems to be citrus and pine.  After the finish there is a warming alcohol that lingers.  This beer is somewhat heavier and thicker than medium.  Moderately carbonated and the carbonation bubbles are tiny resulting in a smooth and satisfying palate.  This beer probably will improve with age (several years) as it melds and mellows...

12 oz bottle.  Year Bottled:  2006.

Bottled, vintage 2006
Dark ruby color, steady creamy tan head. Strong bready hoppy aroma. Mostly bready hoppy flavor, Bitterish and slightly alcoholic aftertaste. "Fading palate" ... could be more complex.

Brownish/Mahoganey color with a large frothy beige head.  Earthy hop aroma with elements of chocolate, roasted coffee, licorice, and some spice.  Different and unusually structured but it definitely works.  Dry, softly carbonated, and bitter.  With earthy hops, chocolate, licroice, roasted coffee, and spice coming through.  There¬ís even a touch of sweetness, almost like fruitcake.  I¬íll leave it at that.

12 oz bottle via rb secret santa (thanks!).Pours a dark clear amber/brown with a nice dense average sized beige head. Nose is smokey and earthy. Taste starts sweet and quickly turns to a bitter earthy and piney hoppiness with a very piney smokey aftertaste. Moderate/high carbonation. Medium body. It seems a bit rough around the edges. Not my thing.

Bottle.  This beer is deeply malty with evident hop flavor and aroma .  A warmer,  complex enough to hide most of the alcohol.     A rich licorice, caramel flavor. Hard to compare this to anything else I¬íve tried.
great winter seasonal ale. pleasant flavor, good malt taste. bottle from siciliano¬ís market in grand rapids.

Bottle. Red-brown colour with a nice big creamy head. Nice toasty maltiness and nuttiness in the aroma, some sweetness. Flavour is smooth and creamy, nice sweet toasty maltiness, bit spiced, good caramel, bit of chocolate, some fruity hoppiness. Bitter bit sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Very well done super-woody strong ale. Complex with many subtle inputs of fruits, hops, malts, chocolate, tobacco. You can tell it has been aged. Dry but with an oily, piney, liccorice taste and mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle. Bottled 2006. Slightly hazy,reddish brown colour. Little head. Appealing and intriguing aroma with dryness and hints of liquorice and pine.
Flavor dry and somewhat metallic.
Bottle.Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is hop, fruit, malt. Flavour is  hop, fruit, roasted, caramel, malt.

12 oz. bottle. Dark amber color.  Some roasted malts and piney hop aromas.  Very smooth and easy drinking for an ASA.  Well balanced.  Caramel malt, some spiciness, solid hop finish to it.  Well crafted beer.

Pours murk dark brown with a creamy brown head.  Aroma is of dark bread, toasted malts, and carmel.  Flavor is well balanced toasted malts.  Medium bodied watery, softly carbonated.  Clean finish, nice.

12 oz bottle poured out a striking clear amber color with creamy tan head. The aroma reminds me of their IIPA with hints of crystal and roasted malts sprinkled around a cake layer of pine hops. The flavor is the opposite with big roasted to caramelized malts with a solid pine hop backbone. Toward the finish some burnt malts make an appearance as does a nice alcohol warmth. Good winter time brew.

It¬ís a nice dark brown beer with a limited head. The aroma has wonderful notes of plum, raisin and other dark fruits and roasted malt. The mouthfeel is oily. The flavour has lots of dark fruits and roasted malt with notes of a bit of licorice and caramel sweetness. The entire flavour has a nice, dry and bitter hoppyness. A truly nice beer!!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2010 Bottled. Pours a clear, reddish brown with a decent beige head, and releases aromas of beef-stock, hops, light roastiness, caramel and some pine. It has a heavy flavor with roasted malt, hops, sweetness and malt. This full-bodied beer has a long, sweet finish with hops and malt. A lovely, potent, balanced beer. Rating: 7-4-8-4-15-3.8. 070106Bottle, 12oz, at Patricks Pub. It¬ís a clear, dark amber to brown beer with a finger-thick lasting,, beige head. Nice lacings too. The aroma is malty, with dried fruits and sugars. The flavor has a nice balancing hop addition to the sweet maltyness and dried fruits found in the aroma. Ends with a nice bitterness. Full body. Overall, probably a bit on the sweet side, but a nice beer indeed. 091211

A: pour produces a gorgeous, enticing cranberry red bronzed color, with a minor cream-colored head that disappears quickly and leaves barely any lacing.
