S: smells of toasted malts, deep roasted caramel and sweet bread. In other words, delicious.

T: this beautiful strong ale tastes as good as it smells, with some robust sweetness up front that quickly evolves into a nice smoked finish. The beer is not as sweet as it smells but more balanced, which IMHO is a good thing. As it warms a bit, some savory fruit flavors appear, though they¬íre not at all overwhelming. Just a bit of raisin here and there.

M: considering the beer¬ís aroma and flavor, this is much lighter on the palate than one might expect, slightly chewy and just full-bodied enough to remind you it¬ís a strong ale.

D: not quite a session beer (the 8.10% ABV sees to that), but a very easy to drink beer.

I¬íd definitely drink this one again. And again.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a  amber with a small  tan head. Aroma of hops, fruit, and roast. The flavor is roast, fruit, and hops. Decent beer.

The pour is dark bronze in color beneath a bit of orangeish beige foam.  Aroma is caramel, dates, cherries, and a lot of wood.  Flavor is much the same with a dry texture of cinnamon, finishing with a syrupy alcoholic cough syrup sensation.  There¬ís hints of bright fruity character evident maybe from the dry hopping, which might be the only thing that keeps this from tasting completely English.  A favorable warmer.

This is a good American Strong. I poured this and was delighted at the dark amber before me. The aroma was caramel and malt all the way. At first swig I thought it was a porter but after swallowing I was assured this was different. Remember the candy Sugar Daddy-s? Liquify one of those and that is what you have here. Sweet and to the point.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: First let me say I don¬ít care much for the american strong ale style, but I am interested in trying this one.  Since it is from great divide I have high hopes for the flavor.  Too often the strong ales can¬ít cover the amount of alky present. Pours ruby brown transparent red in my steeler stein.  Very little brown head that fades rapidly.  Has a rather sweet aroma in the background that is typical of a strong ale. Nice stream of carbonation each time you take a sip.  The flavor is overwhelming with alcohol.  Like most beers with a high alky content it is a bit ruff and unrefined. Carbonation on the tongue is below average and this stuff leaves a lasting bitterness on the palate that just will not go away.  You know you were drinking something offensive when you down this brew. I¬ím not sure how somebody could rate this so high and then turn around and slam the average cheap american malt liquor, they fall in the same flavor class.  Will not buy again, way too much for my girlie taste buds. Bitter beer lover probably think this is great stuff.  Finish is lingering astringent and medicine like.  I give it an overall rating of 6 only because of its buzz potential.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Odd that it wins awards as an Old English ale and is categorized as an American strong. smells great, like caramle and toffee. Looks great, thick creamy head. The flavor is very much English malts and hops, a little funny. Tastes like a bitter almost to me. Coats the mouth, with a little metal in the finish. Pretty good.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 Bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a descent, stable foam. Strong hop aroma with some roasted malt. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor matches aroma with additional spiciness and dark fruits. Alcohol well hidden.

[bottle]
Not just strong grapefruit hops aroma, but a nice toasty malt comes in later.  Notes of red currant and dried apricot.  Clear brownish ruby with beige head that recedes to wisps and a bubbly ring.  Salty flavour up front from hops that gives way to a bitter grapefruit peel.  Watermelon leading into ethanol, mixed with raisins and tobacco.  Minearly.  Medium body, slightly warming, and quite bitter but not astringent.

Pours a clear ruby brown with a thin layer of light brown foam. The head recedes very quickly leaving only a ring. Scant lacing. Mild molasses and hop aroma.

The initial flavor is both sweet and tart: sweet from a mildly roasted toffee and malt, and tart from the spicy hops. It finishes with an odd, but pleasant, mild sweet jalapeno flavor, not unlike one of those jalapeno jelly belly candies, but much more sublte.

A little yeast blends with the hops in the aftertaste. The hops really linger. There is a slight dry alcolhol in there too. Medium body, moderate carbonation.

Brewblackhole sent this to me as an extra. Pours a dark amber with ruby hues. The head was thin and short lived, had a light tan complexion. The aroma is dominated by hops with a moderate malt balance. Bitter aroma with some citrus hints and sweet caramel and molasses. Definitely a bitter beer, then comes the alcohol, definitely a roasty taste, some sweet malty taste too. I wish it were a little more balanced, but I prefer malts to hops anyways. The palate is average, a little harsh, bitter, waxy. The finish is bitter and very warm.

Received through trade with brewblackhole.  The color was a brown/amber.  The head was very thin and fizzy.  It disappeared quickly.  The aroma was roasty, spicy, and malty.  It smells bitter.  The flavor was hoppy, bitter, alcoholy, raosted, and what tastes like very weak licorice.  The palate was thin and carbonated.  The finish was bitter.

2006 release.

Pours a dark red-tinged brown with a one finger tan head, that slowly recedes to a thick cap. The subsequent lacing is thick, completely coating the inside of the glass.

Smell; at first the aroma starts out with coffee and a little bit of piney hops. Then it becomes chocolate, mixed with spices and fruits. This is one beer I could just sit as smell for a long time, very nice.

Taste; as with the smell, the flavor starts out with coffee and then turns to chocolate covered, rum soaked cherries. There¬ís a nice spiciness ifilling out the middle, and finishes with slightly piney hops. Mouthfeel is a touch on the thin side, and is the only real complaint I have about this beer. Drinkability is pretty darn good, especially considering the higher abv.

I¬íve been wanting to try this beer for a while now, and thanks to a friend who picked some up for me while in Colorado, I finally had the chance. Needless to say I was not disappointed.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
The smell of this beer instantly reminded me of sweetened, peppered meat, which indeed I have never smelled.  Also alcohol.
The body is a rich, bloody brown with a yellowish-white head.
Smooth, yet harsh, spicy.  The everlasting acidic bite reminds me of The Reverend, from Avery.  
Also, this beer tastes wet somehow, and yes, I realize wet is not a taste.
Bitter, sharp finish.
Bottle shared with wheninhell.

A ruby color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of chocolate, hints of vanilla.  Taste and I dont know why I think crystal malts, I am likely wrong but that is what I get.  Yea there is a rich chocolate, smooth taste and feel.  Hops, not so much for my 06 bottle, a dry finish but that is about it.  No alcohol tasted but felt.  Nice.

Bottle from Sam¬ís. Deep brown hue.  Nose is fruity, hops, toasted malts. Medium bodied-surprisingly roasty flavor, cocoa, with some resinous hops on the palate.  A bit of alcohol present on the palate. Dont know what I expected, but not this. A unique and tasty brew.
Dark red with amber head.  Has a sweet but alcoholic smell.  The taste burns like alcohol, although it is sweet and tastes of caramel.  The aftertaste is also alcoholic, and is a little sweet.
nose chocolate and sweet malt with teeny bit hops.  flavor is very bittersweet chocolate.  ok brew but wasnt to impressed

I picked this up knowing Great Divides propensity for brewing flavorfull beers. As a strong ale i thought the taste would be more alcoholic and less heavy. The chocolate tones were too much and i wish it had been a little more bitter.
Bottle @ American Week, Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Strong malty aroma with even some alcohol in it. Dark amber red, small white head (rhyme!). Lots of hops and alcohol in the taste, long malty finish.

Pours a copper to amber, deep, clear, with a big dense light tan head, fading to a thin film and then less.  The nose is lightly roasty, slightly sweet, and full of alcohol.  Chocolate is evident, as is floral to herbal hops and caramel, somewhat.  Toasty.  This is full in the mouth, creamy, with nice viscosity.  Really rough going down.  Not a smooth beer by any stretch.  Not bad in and of itself, but I feel like there are too many strong flavors in this and they aren¬ít complementary.  Big rich sweet complex malt, everything from chocolate and caramel and toasty roast.  The alcohol is enormous here too.  This is a beer that drinks like a poorly constructed 8.1 ABV drink, I¬íve had beers with nearly double the ABV where the alcohol was less noticable.  Big hops too.  Floral, grapefruit, and resin all really present.  Not a terribly clean beer.  Chocolate finish with alcohol and vanilla cream.  The aftertaste is overpowered with alcohol and dominated by brash hops and roasted malt.  I just didn¬ít care for this beer too much overall.  It certainly has complexity, but it just doesn¬ít seem thoughtfully put together.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2007 Bottle, label was notched between 2005 & 2006, poured dark brown with red, some off-white bubbles rise to the top, lots of sweet and chocolate, some cherry, milk chocolate, vanilla, chocolate milkshake and Tootsie roll fragrances, taste of malt, chocolate, some hops, very smooth, medium dry on the palate, alcohol warmth in the throat as it warms up, nice drink.

Quite a surprise for a American Strong Ale of this Magnitude. Its a strong syrup feel to it. the taste is over flowing with heavy caramel and overwhelming hops flavor. Even though its a strong beer it doesn¬ít hit you hard.

Pours a Mahogany brown with a thick, lasting head.  The aroma is of roasted malts and caramel, with a slight, slight bit of hops.  The flavor is semi sweet with a deep roastiness and a raisn character that is strong, yet hard to identify.  Overall, pretty good, but not somethng I¬íd go nuts trying to get again.

Bottle.  Reddish brown with a moderate cream colored head.  Dark malty aromas of molasses, coffee and chocolate with dark fruit notes of plum and cherry.  Flavors of rich dark malts-- molasses, brown sugar, with some good plummy notes throughout and a solid hop profile coming through on the finish.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Alcohol very well hidden even in my 2006 bottle. Good stuff from a clearly skilled brewer.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Ever so slightly hazy with a small, off-white head. Aroma of burned caramel. Medium body with very typically American, fat caramel malt and aroma hops without being very bitter. Somewhat biscuity. OK as such, just not very interesting. 050107

Bottle. Pours a dark red body with a thin head at first but developed nicely (weird?). Aroma is of chocolate and malts and hops. Sweet flavor with a small chocolate taste that warmed the palate. Smooth.
Bottle. Dark amber with thick tan head. Aroma: Caramel, fruit and chocolate. Flavor: Starts with malt and caramel and has a long bitter finish with a lot of aroma hops. Very complex.
12 oz. bottle. Carmel pour.  Bourbon aroma.   Slight antiseptic taste.  Sweet spice taste and finish.

[Bottle] Dark red-ish brown with a rich and creamy head. Aroma is malt, chocolate, toffee and meringue. Powerful, malty flavour with an oily hop and alcohol presence. The after taste is long and bitter.
Bottled, redbrown beer, very fantastic caramell aroma, caramell-hop taste, very special,good special strong taste
Botle. Cloudy dark brown with white head. Nice aroma of raisins and roasted coffee. Feels nice in the mouth. Medium body. Some sweetness from the alcohol, it is quite strong (hick).

12 oz bottle - 2004.  Murky dark walnut with a small tan and white cap.  Woody blackberries and dusty raisins.  Rich, medium body with just enough carb to balance.  Butterscotch, dates and coffee; hard to pin down.  Chalky hops and alcohol in the end.  Sticky lips.  Some age has served this well.

12 oz. bottle.  Darker cloudy amber with the various winter spices forming the aroma.  A tad on the bitter side, but still with the 8.1 ABV provides a solid kick.  For winter brews, I found Ithaca¬ís Winterizer a smoother yet equally potent potable, but this is still a very good beer.
The nose is of chocolate and caramel.  Mostly chocolate. I taste a lot of cocoa, coffee and caramel malt.  There is kind of a kaluha flavor to the beer.  Respectable beer.

Bottle.  Earthy toffee/sassafras root aroma.  Dark amber color with moderate head.  Chocolate malt and moderate hops and alcohol  finish.  Long lasting hops aftertaste.  Nice flavor but nothing that blows me away.

Pours dark reddish amber with a mostly receding off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit, big PNW hops, and some caramelized wort. Taste is extremely resinous and hoppy, with barely enough malts to provide a balance. There is some malty stickiness and a bit of alcohol hotness, but there¬ís no balance here. Mouthfeel is heavy bodied and resinous with lively carbonation. Needs at least six more months. Cellar material.

Dark reddish brown color. Smell of hops, malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, fruit and alcohol.  Taste of chocolate, hops, sweet malt, oak, alcohol, nuts and hints of roasted coffee and smoke.  Nice bitters at the end.  Great beer.
Dark bron with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of caramel, toffee, alcohol, with a slightly smokey, coffee smell.  Taste is caramel, coffee, alcohol, and light hop background.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2013 Hazy brown,small beige head.Nose of brown sugar and dark malts.Complex dark malt taste, the alcohol is well masked
Rerate Jan,2013
Sparkling deep amber,lasting beige head.Earthy malt nose.Complex palate of cereal grains,earthy malt aqnd medium hops, light alcohol heat
12 oz bottle.  Pours a chestnut brown color with a medium beige head.  Aroma is nutty and malty with hoppy undertones.  Taste is nutty with a pleasant bitter piney hop aftertaste.  Nice.

2006 bottle. Beer is clear, medium-hued brown. Head is initially small, off-white, frothy. Quickly diminishing into scant pockets of fluff.

Aroma is malty with moderate notes of husky roasted grain, toasted nuts, toffee/caramel; Hoppy with a light-to-moderate note of resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of cellar; Light miscellaneous note of slightly boozie alcohol, light dried stonefruit, wood.

Flavor is big. Heavily sweet, moderately bitter with a long, tummy-warming, moderately bittersweet, lightly acidic finish. Strange, slightly mousey aftertaste, though.

The body is medium, the texture is almost syrupy and the carbonation is lively.

Could almost be bananas about this, but something is just a little off-center, cloying and off-putting.

Overly hopped dark ale here.  Not much residence flavor in this "winter" ale.  I¬ím looking for a bit more staying power in my strong winter ales than this.  The hops are too present and basically turn this into a normal/lackluster IPA.  Too bad, too, as Great Divide makes good beer, a shame they rely on hops.

The pour is a nice chestnut brown with a medium head.  Chocolate and roasted malt scents dominate the aroma.  The palate is medium, but also chewy.  Flavors are rich and robust malts and wood flavors.  Bitternes stays in your cheeks throughout the experience.  Fairly good, but not great.
Bottle. brown colour with a big off white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, nuts and hops.

Fairly dark brown color with an off white head which doesn¬ít linger too long. Aroma is rich and malty with some toffee notes. Taste is dominated by malts with hops underneath. Flavor is fairly sweet, but the alcohol is relatively mild. Pretty nice winter warmer.

Nice malty aroma, some molases, nuts.  Pours a ruby-amber, with a nice littel off-white head, nice lacing.  Flavor is nutty, with some sweetness, a mild bitterness, and a soft alcoholic finish.  Relatively full bodied.  Yum.
Bottle. Brownish hazy colour with a huge mostly lasting off white head.rich aroma and taste of malts, fruits and hops. Nice beer. Laaaasting taste.
Chocolate and toffee dominate the aroma.Pours a mahogany color with a little off white head.Flavors are of chocolate and alcohol.Full mouthfeel with an alcohol finish.

Poured a brown color with mahoganey hues, nice initial head, very good retention, the lacing produced spotty but plenty, nice looking beer all the way down. The aroma was brown sugar, light roasted choco-coffee notes, some pine hops. The flavor followed the aroma, also caramel, pretty sweet up front, good pine (light grass) hop balance in the finish, perhaps a bit strong for an "old ale," although I¬ím not sure what this thing was supposed to really be. Raisins and some other dark fruits assert themselves mid-glass with warmer temperatures. Seemed a cross between an doppelbock and an imperial porter, tasty indeed, but not something I¬íd go to regularly. Mouthfeel was moderate to full, slight acidity, a little sticky (sweet) on the lips.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 12oz bottle, 2005 (1 year old). pours a deep mahogony with fluffly head. aroma is simply amazing a roasted caramel with chocolate covered cashews. flavor is reminisent of a BW but more nutty and milk chocolaty. some roasted and oaky flavors too. i really love how this beer ages..3.8. 

5/19/07, 2005 vintage, cellar aged approx. 19months. nose is pretty similar to previous rating. the malt just seems to have dropped out a bit and isn¬ít quite as malty as the previous rating. possibly some subtle oxidation taking in but this really hasn¬ít improved from at 1 year age. perhaps at 2+ years of age it gets more oxidized and changes a lot, but for now i prefer this beer at 1 year. 8/4/7/4/14=3.6. 

11/21/07, 12oz bottle 2005, aged 2 years. this is still holding up but i think it peaked at 1 year. it is sorta sour and not as malty as before.3.

Dark red, clear, medium tan head.  Interesting aroma, strong chocolate and caramel.  Very inviting, this beer has my interest.   Rich, heavy mouthfeel.  Velvet on the tounge.  Chocolate flavor, fairly bitter, well balanced with just a hint of alcohol.  I like this beer very much.

Amber/burgundy color with a tan head that quickly disappears.  Aroma of dark fruit, licorice, malt and hops.  Some alcohol also.  Flavor is somewhat sweet with carmel and dark fruit notes.  Warming alcohol.  Some hop balance in the finish.  Another winner from an excellent brewery.
Nice malty and hoppy winter warmer. The aging has made the maltiness very round and the dry American hops (grape fruit) gives a nice dry finish.

dark amber appearance with a tan head.  nose is of sweet malts.  flavor is dominated by the taste of carmel and chocolate.  a mid-taste of hops finished with a strong malty flavor and a tinge of alcohol.  good but the sweetness is somewhat overbearing

(Bottle) Dark amber/copper colour with huge, foamy beige head. Very aromatic, spicy nose with notes of toffee, chocolate fudge, brown sugar, caramel, citrus (Seville orange) and citrussy, spicy hops. Complex, spicy taste with chocolate, Seville orange, notes of ginger biscuits and hints of coffee. Long, fiery finish, slightly sweet but well balanced by the nice hoppy character. Complex and warming, lots of character.

Dark amber colored, little light brown head. Caramel, licorice, plenty of bitter hops in aroma, notes of alcohol come up also. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is richer with caramelly, sweet, hopped and licoricy tones, mild alcohol also with some vinous touch. Aftertaste lasts with bitter hops and warming alcohol. Crispy palated.

Bottle. Beautiful dark brown/amber color. Small tan head. The taste was mildly malty, nutty, carame, and roasted. Great beer, smooth on the palate with just the right amount of balance. Better then I expected. Great beer!!

bottle.  brown clear pour with big frothy tan head.  roasted nut, sour malt, mild spice aroma.  rich palate follows the aroma.  full bodied.  really a full malt flavor that you don¬ít find to often.  alcohol well hidden.

Pours a clear dark amber/brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is chocolate and spice.  Taste is chocolate, dried fruit, and hops along with even some licorice.  Very good and well balanced.  Not much alcohol detected.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Secret Santa.  Pours a deep, clear reddish brown with a generous linen white head and lots of lacing. My bottle was not all that aromatic. I noted some very light roasted malt and toasted nuts.  Flavor was roasted malt, caramel, and hops. A bit of heat from the alcohol at the finish. Full bodied and nice smooth palate. A good choice for a chilly winter evening.
Mahogany with a little, tan head. Roasty and bitter. A touch of alcohol with caramel malts and notes of dark fruits. Almost smokey. Dry and dusty with a cirtrus punch of a finish.

Bottle: Clear red amber colour, flat head.
Aroma of toffee,flowers,lots of nice hops,sugar.
Flavor is smokey,citric,Vine, flowery, lots of hops,and nice maltyness.Medium body, medium finish.
Werry nice bear indeed!!!

My favorite winter seasonal thus far. Pours a dark rusty brown with deep reddish and purple tints, surprisingly thin head (the only thing that keeps the appearance from being a 5). Nose has a lot going on...roasted malts, spiced fruits, and a touch of chocolate. Flavor is out of this world, with heavy malts and a perfect balance of bittersweetness. Lovely.
Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours a deep amber with a small light tan head. Aroma of hops, fruit, and roasted malts. The flavor is roast, fruit, and hops. Good body, good brew.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2007 The aroma has chocolate, alcohol, toasted malt, cardboard and a touch of pepper. The appearance is red brown with a smaller than average head. The flavor is like the aroma and acidic with some bitter hops, dark fruit, and a touch of vegetables. The palate is smooth. This beer is not anywhere near as good as it¬ís rated here.
Brown color. Mostly roasted malt flavor, with only light hops. Alcohol well hidden.
Pours a super dark clean amber with a small light tan head. Light roasted nut and malt aroma. I can detect mild dry hops in the flavor along with some malts and spice. A slightly bitter finsih.

Pours dark bronze with a tan head that leaves fairly quick.  The aroma has some spiciness and fruit with lots of toasted malt and a touch of hop spice.  Medium body with some soft carbonation.  Flavor starts with spice and fruit with caramel malt.  The finish has lots of woody earthy hops and a light bit of smoke.  It is very earthy tasting and slightly harsh with a bit of a warm finish.  A very nice winter beer.
This beer pours a deep amber/brown color with no head.  Nose of caramel malt.  The flavor is biscuity and malty with some spciy ending.  very warming.  Not a bad winter beer!  Cheers!

Bottle from cbkschubert; Nose of hops and cocoa, along with some roasty caramel malt; nicely balanced in the nose; clear dark brown with a small, glass-lacing tan head; flavor is toasty caramel, with smoke hints, cocoa, and a mild hop finish.

12 oz bottle.  2006.  Deep dark red and filtered.  Moldy bone white head.  Sweet cinnamon and citrus hops in the nose.  Spicy and piney aromas.  Smooth initial malts with a bitter finish.  Initial is caramel and toffee malts.  Nice burn.  Slight cola-ish flavor.  Sweet and cloying with a bitter finish.  Well done.

Bottle, pours dense but clear dark brown with slight tan head, no lacing.  Wow, a big hit of chocolate/cocoa and malt in the aroma that is very inviting.  Taste of very mild toasted malts, with hints of chocolate, coffee and some caramel.  A slight warm alcohol finish that¬ís comfortable.  An nice cold weather beer that¬ís well worth a try.  Recommended.

clear brownish ruby with a large foamy yellow head.  aroma of hops and sweet milk chocolate.  flavors of bitter stinging coffee, nuts, and hops in the finish.  kind of minerally.  hints of perfume.  dry finish.  has a unique flavor but i cant get into it.
Small fluffy brownish/white head, nice ruby hue, hazy in appearance, aroma is a roasted nutty maltiness, full bodied.  A very nicely done beer, perfect for cold weather.

(Bottled) Clear, dark ruby-brown color with a small, quite tight head. Nicely nutty-hoppy aroma with berries. Strongly hoppy, caramely and grainy-malty flavor with a berry jelly finish. Quite full-bodied, warming, sticky and low-carbonated palate. A very enjoyable and warming brew to be drank slowly and carefully.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a nice off-white head on top. The head has somewhat of a reddish tint to it. Aroma is full of caramel malts, toffee, and hints of hops. Flavor is full of roasted malts, caramel, oak, and hints of hops coming in. The aroma is quite similar to Double Bastard but the flavor is quite different. Another good winter beer. I would like to age some just to see how it holds up.

12oz bottle (dated 2006) purchased in a 6-pack from Bauer Wines in Boston.  Pours a deep copper with a somewhat large head and a lot of carbonation.  Strong and pleasant aroma of malt and hops.  First taste is rather heavy and sweet with a taste of molasses. The alcohol is noticeable.  The taste continues to be heavy and lingers long in the mouth.  Took a while to warm up to (or perhaps it just took a while to warm me up!).  An interesting beer, but not my favourite style.
6 pack 12 ouncers. Looks like alot of ingredients were put into this beer. Thick, mahogany in color. Rich light tan, maybe bit reddish head. I like it, good winter brew.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2014 Bottle.  Strong chocolate and toffee aroma, also very sweetly malty.  Really, I¬ím expecting candy here.  Pours deep red with a light brown fizzy head.  Sticky, bitter, and dry taste of chocolate, toffee, bittering hops, and light grapefruit.  Resin and pine, a bit of hop essence/oil.  Body is light, surprising considering the enormous rush of flavors.  Dry, bitter hoppy finish.  Very "dirty" character, though.  Strange and interesting, and surprisingly I do like the harsh grittiness here.  Bit of an alcohol burn.  One of the better winter brews of the hoppy variety. [2006.11.27: 3.5]Ah, finally coming back to an old favorite.  The resin and the distinctive, dank and pungent woodiness really jump out of the bottle, cedar and tobacco well over the modest pine, and the caramel and darker toffee are lively and jumping instead of flat.  Oily, woody hops with a light herbal component, man are they ever cramming every last bit of woodsy/natural flavor into this drink, lots of bold sub-syrupy surprises.  Sticky, dank, strongly bitter and spicy.  Really very gruntingly masculine, as in when perfume enthusiasts talk about ¬ísandalwood¬í and musk.  Strong alcohol is contained but not tamed.  A great treat for the fireplace and pit.  [2014.11.12: 3.8]

12 oz. bottle. Pours deep brown with some red hues, short off-white head. Malts, toffee, caramel and hops in the nose. Big flavors of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, wood and a pleasant hop bite. A real complex mix that is very satisfying. I¬íll let some of these age and rate again.
Bottle. Light brown short head. Hazy orange body. Lovely cocoa aroma. Cocoa caramel flavor plus mild hops to balance the sweetness.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2006 pours a deep ruby red with foamy offwhite head.lots of caramal in the aroama some alcohol
 and a hint of hops.tate is creamy sweet bubbley and warming.finsh is sweet.overall a great winter warmer from great divide
Red-amberish colour. Off-white head. Nuts, malt,wood and a raspberry touch in aroma. Malty, caramel and some alcohol in flavor.

Bottle. Clear deep red, nice head. Aroma delivers both hops and sweet malty fruits. Taste has less noble hops that I¬íd expected, very bitter. Resinous and sweet, in a good way. This is one huge beer, will try to get a few for the old cellar.
Not great. Poured a deep ruby red with a great lacing head. Aroma sweet vanilla and cherries. Flavor very sweet and a bit spicy, with some raisins and vanilla, but nothing stands up.

Pours a deep orange brown color with a small off white head.  An aroma that is of dark roasted malts slightly nutty with a nice dose of hop bitterness.  The taste is smooth dark malts, some biscuit, a bitter hop bite and a warming alcohol finish.  This is truly a great winter brew.
Amber color, offwhite head. Very nice nutty, malty aroma with some almond. Malty, nutty flavor, vanilla notes, some fruit, alcohol notes and some nice bitter hops. Well balanced.

Had this beer lots of times, and it¬ís always a favorite.  I had know problem pouring the first half vigorously enough to gurgle it, making sure that I had 1-1.5 inches of thick foamy head.  Aroma in this fresh bottle is much different than when I had my last bottle in July.  Very hoppy: lots of grass, herb and vegetable qualities, like this beer was plucked fresh from the garden.  Underneath that, some mild plum, and caramel notes.  Tastes smacks you kindly with some toast, caramel, toffee and roast elements all at once.  There¬ís still that pervasive veggie-hop flavor to it as well.  Finishes roasty, and pleasently bitter, almost smokey.  I can still breath that hoppy taste, which I know will disappear from this beer by July.  I¬íve always loved this beer.  Nothing balances the line between barleywine and imperial stout quite like this beer, even if it is slightly mellower than either.  An essential winter beer, which I highly recommend drinking as fresh as possible for that pungent hop taste.

Pours a translucent deep reddish copper with a think lasting tan head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Nose is dried fruit and a bit of hops.  Smooth mouthfeel with perfect amount of carbonation.  Taste of caramel, toffee, and raisins with slight hop bitternes in the finish.  Pleasant alcohol warming.  This is one fantastic, near perfect beer.  Oh how a wish this were available year round.
Bottle at √òlbaren. Deep red - white head. Nutty, chokolate, dried fruits, caramel. Nice hoppy. Smooth - very nice
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2008 Deep brown color with a touch of read.  Rich dark fruit malty flavors...almost Belgian like. Some coffee notes come though. Sweet malts. Very nice.

(2006 Edition) The beer pours with ease and that action creates a pillowing head. Dark brown in color with red highlights which makes for a sexy brew. The palate is full bodied and reminiscent of a mocha latte. The palate is very warming with a touch of alcohol that does not distract. It¬ís an incredibly chocolaty beer that seems to encompass most aspects of what makes a winter ale a winter ale. The finish is long and full of strong coffee and dark fruity chocolate. I must say this a very enjoyable pint as it warms it gets more complex.

[Bottled]
Copper colour. Small beige head.
Warm aroma with hoppy citrus and dried, sweet fruits.
Very malty and sweet flavour with fine dry-hopping. Fruity citrus.

Klar r√∏dbrun farve med r√•hvidt skum. Dufter og smager af choko, kaffe, kirseb√¶r, m√∏eke t√∏rrede frugter og rugbr√∏d. Dejlig lang eftersmag af bitter choko og kaffe noter, dejlig fyldig. 
En super l√¶kker √∏l.
Bottle, bought from brewery (green).  Dark malty foretaste, roasted malt finish.  Hints of chocolate, coffee, and pumpkin spice.  Great winter beer - keeps you warm inside.
Pours a dark brown with reddish hues and a small tan head.  The aroma is malty with chocolate and coffee plus a bit of spice.  The flavor is malty with a dark chocolate and roasted coffee flavor.

Pours a pretty red color, with a pinkish tan head.  Nose is malt, chocolate, and toffee, with spiced hops and mild alcohol sharpness.  The flavor is of brown sugar, toffee, chocolate, herbs, and earth.  The herbs and the earth come from hops -- they¬íre not very citrusy at all, but they¬íre a perfect strength to balance the sweet overall character.  On the palate, this beer feels delightful.  It¬ís not very carbonated, but still feels bubbly.  The sweetness leaves some stickiness behind, but I¬ím ok with that.  Sips finish with chocolate.  "Massive flavors" is pushing it a bit, but yay.  Thumbs up for this one, indeed.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2016 First rating.Initial Rating Date: 11/13/2006Chocolate scent with hints of orange, like some flavored chocolate bar. No hops that I could feel in the smell. Clear dark brown color, beige head. Clean malty chocolate moving on to raissin and then coffee. Long lasting coffee aftertaste. Mdeium to high bitterness. Some initial fruitiness. Mdeium body and co2. Coffee is very dominating, maybe a bit too sharp initial bitterness from the hops.7/3/7/3/14=3.4
Second rating.(Bottle)Lots and lots of chocolate, some strawberry, milk chocolate, nuts, flavoured coffee, scent. Chocolate taste with a bitter bite, alcohol. Dry hoppy citrus flavor. Alcohol taste as well. Red to copper color, tan head.8/3/8/3/16=3.8RerateBottle from Systembolaget.Sampled on February 26, 2011Clear dark red to copper color. Bitter grainy scent. Grainy taste. Smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/3/7/4/13=3.4RerateDraught at Bishops Arms J√§rntorget, on Christmas Eve 2012.Clear dark brown color, tan head. Sweet, raisin, caramel, citrus taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, high bitterness. Sweet, malty, fruity scent.7/3/8/3/15=3.6RerateAt the ekstedt vintage tasting on December 28, 2012. 2012 (thanks ekstedt) vs 2010 (thanks Johan, not on ratebeer) vs 2008 (thanks Johan, not on ratebeer). All from bottles.2012 vintage:Clear brown color, tan head. Sweet, malty, citrus scent. Sweet, malty, bitter taste. Warming alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/3/7/4/14=3.52010 vintage:Clear copper color, small tan head. Sweet, malty, grainy scent. Sweet, grainy, alcohol taste. Medium mouthfeel going to smooth, medium bitterness.8/3/7/4/14=3.62008 vintage:Clear borwn color, small tan head. Sweet, cocoa scent, some raisins. Grainy, cocoa taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.8/3/8/4/16=3.9RerateDraught at BAJT, 25/12-16.Hazy dark brown color, tah nhead with lacing. Roasted, malty, toffee, some light butter, coffee taste. Coffee, roasted aftertaste. Medium full a bit fizzy mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Toffee, malty, spicy scent.8/4/8/3/15=3.8

12 oz. bottled in 2005 from Plaza liquor - Pours a brown color with a good size light tan head.  Lots of nice lacing.  Love the aroma.  Has a chocolate mint scent to it.  The flavor is much of the same.  Semi-sweet chocolate.  A smooth, warming, medium to full body beer.  An excellent beer.  I¬ím gonna go buy the rest.  At a $1.65, you can¬ít go wrong.  A must try.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 Pours a dark amber/copper with clarity; head is full, off-white, creamy/pillowy, and well lasting with nice lacing.  Nice nose with toffee and molasses, roasted nuts, earthy and slightly piney hops.  Nice malt base, notes of molasses throughout with toffee, slight nuttiness, and a touch of raisin.  Hops have a medium bitterness to balance with flavors of earth and pine towards the end.  Finishes mostly bitter with some molasses hanging around and moderate length.  Palate is soft, creamy, and medium-fullwith only a slight warming character from the 8.1% ABV.  Very well done winter warmer from a brewery that has yet to disappoint me.  Nothing that will blow you away, but every aspect was well done.
Pours a dark red, amberish color, with a big tan head. Smells of prunes, caramel. Malty, with again prunes, yeast, and a bit of caramel.  This quite superb, another great by great divide.

04 bottle.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit (raisins), caramel, and alcohol.  Pours a dark reddish brown with white floaters and a decent caramel colored head.  Flavors of sweet malt, dark fruit, raisins, bread, caramel, and finishs with a little bit of alcohol.  Worth a try, but not the best.

New seasonal intake at the Systembolaget in Sweden

Appearance: Chestnut brown with appealing tan marshmellow head that lasted.

Aroma: Wow there¬ís a lot going on here. Definate liquorice, roasted malt, wonderful floral hops and caramalised sugar. Brown Ale meets American IPA.

Flavour: And here¬ís where it started to go wrong for me. A very chewy malt backbone to this beer, unfortunately complemented by a beef stock cube/meaty flavour I found hard to deal with. Would be a good beer to marinade meat for a BBQ.

Palate: Strangely soft, with a kiss (alright, more like a snog) of alcohol and slightly oily from the malt. Tounge-curly hop at the end, but it¬ís the whiskyish residual alcohol heat that marks this beer down for me.

Overall: A complex and powerful beer, but not one I¬ím going to rush back to. As refreshing as a run up stairs, and the lingering raw spirit taste is a turn-off for me.

The bottle cap proclaims ¬íGreat Minds Drink Alike¬í. Well in this case, apparantly not.

Bottled.  Clear copper colour, rich, firm head. Strong chocolate aroma. Sweet and malty. Potent flavour of chocolate sauce, tar, grapefruity hops and salt. Solid and warming with fairly soft mouthfeel. Long salty bitter finish. An excellent, hoppy winter warmer

Aroma: fantastic, fruitcake, raisins, sourish, alcohol, bitter malt, cardboard, sherry, dark bread, very lovely, some hops.  Appearance: lovely raisin-/amberred (pretty dark), yellowtinted head. Almost clear.  Flavor: bitter, rough, powerful malt, some sourishness, pretty full-bodied.  Palate: dry, mealy, slightly thin...

Thanks nick.
Aroma: Warming toasty and inviting. American hop nose spicy and molasses aroma with low diacetyl.
Appearance: Mahogany brown with a thick tan head.
Flavour: A whack of complex flavours, molasses, burnt sugar, spicy, citrus hop flavour, caramel, alcohol, granny candy (humbugs) toasted bread and licorice.
Mouthfeel: full bodied rich and syrupy.
overall: Wow, Quite a mouthfull. Rich and inviting aroma followed by an equally full rich and complex flavour. Very moreish. Excellent balance of roasty, malty, sweet, hoppy, bitter and with a long alcoholic hang. Like Old Peculiar on crystal meth.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep amber/light brown with orange and light red highlights.  Aroma is alot of caramel malt, some dry chocolate.  Taste is caramel, bready, lightly doughy, some chocolate, and some bitter hops to balance it out.  really nice strong ale.
Really nice winter warmer. Hops are there, but nicely hidden by a bountiful amount of malt. Alcohol very well represented. Surprised it took me this long to get to this one.

soft toasty alcohol aroma, occasional sharp notes, nice oaken color, thin tan head, a little flattish from the bottle (should have let it warm up a little). the flavors don¬ít quite blend but they4re a good range¬óslightly burnt, almost whiskeysih taste,the hops are there but just bitter, a little thin but quickly warming. keeps the mouth tingling.

Bottle.  Pours a really nice dark amber, almost light ruby color with small head and nice lace.  Nose immediately wafts up as I pour.... a bit of noble hop and tons of malt... sweet, wonderful maltiness fills the nostrils.  Taste is just as impressive with a slightly sweet caramel flavor followed by a great bitter bite on the sides of the tongue, then back to malt.  Really nice, and somewhat dry.  This is a fine brew.  I¬ím not sure if there are any spices in this (I can¬ít taste any) but what a fine specimen this is.  I didn¬ít realize that this was an 8.1%!  The alcohol is hidden very well, and this is actually a really easy drinking beer.  A tip of the cap to the brewery.
Dark red-brown body and a smallish head. The aroma is pretty hefty with caramel and cappaccino.  Flavor is very complicated with some oak, caramel, cherries, and sour grapes.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 Pours deep cherry wood w/ a shallow creamy froth that recedes to a blanket of dust on the surface with a fluffy lace. Malty aromas of chunky chocolate covered nuts and fresh ground coffee. Full nectar w/ soft residual effers creates a lucious creamy texture. It¬ía big and  malty  w/ an abundance of nutty caramel going on. Nuances of mocha and roasted  coffee bean. The finish is bittered mildly with a lingering coffe roast component. Alcohol is well hidden. A nice specimen. Highly recommended.
toasty nutty malt, a rich elixer, a smooth and rich beer, nice winter beer smooth finish well done

2006 bottle from Somerville Super Saver. This one starts off nice with a nutty resin-pine like character but finishes a bit too much on a starchy grassy note which is the smokey end of this beer. I like the aroma better and like the malt profile. I don¬ít care too much for the protruding bitter hops because they don¬ít seem to balance very well.
dark cognac brown. smells like honey roasted malts. chewy sweetness which ends upp tasting rich and bitter but still kinda sticky sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Re-Rate...Vintage ¬í06 Pours dark amber/brown with a thick frothy tan head. Aroma of barley, caramel malts, some dark fruit, and fairly strong minty/herbaceous hops. Roasted coffee, and chocolate dominate the flavor upfront, and carry through the fresh herbal hops towards the finish. Palate is medium/ full bodied, and all flavors linger fairly well in a very nice balance. Original rating 8 4 8 3 16 = 3.9

Dark amber/brown with little white head. Aroma of roasted malts - caramel - sweet & strong hops (of course:-) Some dark fruits appears as well raisin/plum. Little alcohol feel. Medium carbonation with a filling body. The finish is very pleasant strong hoppy and lasting. Pure Dope!

Interesting brew this is...... Smells like Dried tobbacco.  Super dark, amber/brown color.  Rich, malty and spicy.  Nice mix of wonderful hops and malts.  A tad strong and a little burn going down.  Probably would age well.  Great Divide is a solid brewery.

Had at the brewery during 2006 GABF, Dark brown with a nice tan head that lasted a good long time.  Nice aroma of rasin and fruity tones and a hint of alcohol.  A wonderful complex beer with a candy fruit, carmel and slight hop bitterness.  Finishes well with warming alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 Poured amber-brown, with foamy tan head, lasted well, very nice lacing. Nose very warm, hops and roasted malts, toch of alcohol. Mhmmm. There is a warming from beging to end. There is saour malts, some dryness from the hops, and more alcohol. I am going to age this a bit more to see if it mellows a bit. re-rate major hops in this how did I miss that the first time??

330 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown color. Clear. Almost no head to speak of. Rich raisiny sweet. Milk chocolate and toffee. Notes of coffee. The aroma is really pungent and very complex. The flavours is very similar, but perhaps not as complex. Rich chocolatey flavour. Sherry notes. Alcohol is a bit too noticeable. Little bitterness at first, but it kicks in immediately after swallowing. Leaves a drying hoppy feeling.

Dark mahogony color full thick well laced tan head w/ visable carbonation.  Warm brown sugar aromas light syrups and a hint of alcohol.  Palate is well coated and lightly creamy.  Heavily malted brown sugarars and carmels alcoholic warmth in the swallow a nice piney resinious finish.  Pretty good.

On tap at the Great Divide Brewery Tour 9/28/06.  Dark copper, good clarity, good head retention.  Aroma is huge malt with some alcohol notes.  Flavor - soft maltiness with some toasted caramel notes and hints of smokiness.  Hopped to balance, but nothing more.  Overall, an interesting beer....kinda like a mix of strong scottish and an old ale.  Well made, and clean, but not my favorite type of brew.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2006 Bottle.  

I¬íll drink it again, because it¬ís so wellbalanced. Aroma is hoppy and flavor is sweet with notes of "brown ale" fruits

Pours a deep reddish-brown with a creamy lighter tan head with a good deal of sediment. Sweet bready, toffee aroma...tons of caramel malt...with a touch of smoke and some dates. This is sweet and malty...the caramel and toffee is certinaly dominant...some rum and rasin elements with a small light bitterness of hops. Smooth carbonation over a solid toasty body with a creamy toasty/slightly bitter/clean finish. Pretty decent brew...nice one for dessert, to end the night with or have while hiding from the winter storms.

Bottle. Pours deep copper with a white head. Malty aroma with notes of maple syrup and dark fruit. Malty flavors of nuts and raisens. Finish is spicy and  bitter. Very smooth strong ale, not sticky like some. Texture a little thin in the middle. Overall, pretty nice though. I would drink this again
Bottle. Copper color. Light unclear. Light brown head. Caramel, hops and fruit in the aroma. Flavour is floral and dry. Hoppy and cocoa notes. Is sweet. Has a very fruity bitterness in the end.

Great aroma of dark malts, hops, toffee, and chococolate, which also come through in the taste.  Bittering hops perfectly balance the heavy body.  Not particularly sweet, but thick.  This is a great winter warmer type of beer that does not need spices to be a great example of the style.
Deep brown amber, with thin offwhite head. Full body and nicely balanced. Rye, caramel, coffee, toast and hops!
A very dark amber color with a yellowish head. A complex mix between malt sweetness, alcohol strength and hops. A good winter warmer !
Great smell, some coffee and toffee, dark amber, great balance with medium sweetness and bitterness. You could definitely feel the alcohol.

(2004)12oz bottle (thanks to beerandblues2) poured a deep reddish color with a nice light brown head. Aroma of mostly sweet caramel malt. Taste was nice and smooth with noticeable age and slight alcohol warmth. Another great beer from Great Divide.

Bottled. dark reddish brown, firm white head. Nougat, toffee, spices and orange-peels in the compact aroma. malty flavour of raisins, figs, nougat, sweet oranges and anise. Warming malty aftertaste of nuts and raisins with subtle hop note.

Bottle pours a clear deep mahogany witha thick chunky light tan head.  Lacing was blocky and resiliant.  Aroma is a great mix of lightly roasted malts, tootsie rolls, chocolate, dark pitted fruit and caramel.  Flavor was woody and a bit smokey.  Porterish at first and then moving to a slightly ascidic chared flavor.  Bittering was not the floral citrusy hoppiness, but a deeper, woodier charcola type.  Heavey palate but not syrupy.  Moderately carbonated.  Very interesting and I wish I had a 22 of this.  Thanks to lukin013 for this great American Strong.

Complex, enticing aroma that¬ís hard to place.  Dates, figs, maple, grapes.  Big, satisfying maple fruit flavor. Plenty of hops to spice it up. Something you might be tempted to gulp down but will probably get yourself to savor.  Big semi-opaque brown with head coating.  Traces of alcohol detectable but well suited to the beer.  Real nice, even in the summer.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2007 (Bottle at home) Pours dark, beautiful red with some brown notes. Allmost no white head... Smells fudge, syrupy and sugary malt. Dried dark fruits and some minty alcohol. Some liquorice. Lead. Rum raisins. Taste: not as sweet as the smell. Some chocolate. A bit minty with a coffee sourness. Small to medium body. Some syrup with dried plums and raisins. A whole lot of Great Divide-ish hoppyness in this one. A bit warming, but I had bigger hopes for a beer from this great brewery. Second try:   Pours red. Chocolate milk aroma with hazelnuts. Fruits and some flowers. Dry flavour with coffee bitterness. Flower nectar with a relatively big bitterness. Some chocolate.

Bottle: Pours deep amber with a little mostly diminishing, tan head.  Powerful hoppy aroma with a nice malt nose too. The flavour is with malt, burned caramel, dark chocolate and distinct hops. It¬ís full bodied. Pleasant bitter Great Divide finish.
Colour is brown. Head is off-white, creamy and lasting. Has a hopped aroma, some milk-chocolade. Flavor is heavy hopped, bitter. Long finish, real nice. Dry texture.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 Strong scent of cocoa and maltiness intermingled with chocalate/ spices. Pours out a dark cloudy colour with bits of sedimentation rolling through and has a mild to nonexistent head. Taste is a fine seasonal with chocolatey spiciness that rests well upon the palate and all the way down... Hops is very noticable and adds an inviting layer of flavour that balances well with the other elements. Overall an excellent brew, reminiscent of a hoppy well made home-brew...

Creamy offwhite head with some larger bubbles over deep dark red body with some ongoing carbonation. Lovely rye malt aroma with well balanced resiny hop background. Roasty malt cocoa in aroma. Deep sweet powerfully roasty chocolatey taste with resiny hop notes. Oily mouthfeel. Aftertaste is burnt and hoppy. Some alcohol heat. Excellent balance. Roasty cocoa notes. Excellent! A real star! (0.35l bottle.)
Pours a clear dark amber with a slightly tanned head. Sweet with aromas of caramel, light chocolate and resin. Dry, slightly earthy finish.
bottle. dark amber color. meduim tan head. malty aroma. malts and caramel. bit sweet and earthy. very good.

Bottle. Pours a deep, reddish-copper body with a medium-sized yellowish tan head. The aroma is moderately toasty and nutty with some subtle orange hops. Nice flavours - quite spicey and resinous (grapefruit). There are also sweet caramel notes. The palate is yeasty and warming though the alcohol isn‚Äôt over the top.  Very good.
Caramel, nuts, resin, very compleks. Dark amber, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, With a hint of ?

Clear dark red colour with very big creamy white head. Aromas of alcohol and sweet berries. The taste begins very vinious then changes into caramel and fruit. The taste stays for a long time. It has notes of chocolate as well.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 This has been in the cellar for six months.  Aroma is toasted with some mild coffee, raisin and port.  Head was creamy that completely vanished in 15 seconds.  Hazy brown.  Medium to full body.  Not as much of an alcohol taste as 6 months ago.  Upon further inspection, this was not bottled in Dec ¬í05 BUT IN Dec ¬í04.  So it took 1.5 years for this to show some improvement.  This should be even better in another 6 months.
Had another one of these last night (10/26/06).  This has really changed.  It now has a very distinctive oak aroma and flavor.  I was very surprised.  This was hard to drink fresh, but it¬ís now MUCH better.  Will increase my rating.

Bottle (2001) - Pours deep ruby red with medium foamy light tan head with lacing from the top to the very bottom of the empty glass.  Aroma is piney and citrus hops with some malty sweetness.  Palate is medium in body with a silky smooth mouthfeel.  Taste is complex and well balanced.  Notes of malt and chocolate upfront with some bitter piney and citrusy hops on the follow-through.  Alcohol warming and hops in the aftertaste but not too bitter.  Overall, an excellent American Strong Ale with a lot of what seem like contrasting flavors that balance out very well.

Tasty, well-spiced unique winter warmer. Without an x-mas and iverally snowy picture on the front. Body is a bit light, and a nice toastiness, all making it more drinkable. Carmel, nicely moderatley hopped. Must have again. This is 2005. Alcohol hammers by the finish.
Very full deep flavor. Rich and bold. Not too sweet but with lots of malt. Adequate hop flavor and nice finish. A good craft beer.

Nice, rich, full-nosed aroma, filled with sweet, herbal hops and caramel, cherries and even some maple.  The flavor is nearly as complex as the aroma, with particularly strong herbal notes.  Clean finish with a perfect amount of bitterness that makes this highly refreshing.

Powerfull sweet malty aroma. Nice dark amber colour and off white head. The head wil - typical for Great Divide - last for hours (almost). Very powerfull malty flavour, with a dry piney hoppyness. The isn¬ít the most full-bodied beer I have ever tasted, but the high alcohol contributes to a very warming winter beer. Cheers...

Bottle. Typically hoppy American strong ale, but there was more malt presence it it than i was expecting. Nice raisiny/toffee characters (sweet), balanced by the aromatic lightly spicy, piney hops. Warming finish, and sweet the whole way through, with some bitterness in the finish.

A nearly perfect winter ale - nice dark body, with just a touch of white lace - aroma of roasted nuts, fresh-baked cookies, brown sugar - full-bodied and warming, but no real alcohol burn to speak of - tastes like spices and holiday pudding all rolled together - doughy, chewy malt character - a very well done beer, but gets a little overly sweet as it warms.

2003, 12oz. bottle. Hazy reddish/brown color with a small beige head. Really nice malty aroma. Lots of caramel, brown sugar and a strange, but pleasant, florally perfume. Mildly sweet on first sip, but quickly dries. Caramel, brown sugar, oak and a bit of hop bitterness. A bit of oxidation, but does not detract from the flavor.

Wow ,what an aroma,big malty alcohol dark fruit biggey, sparkling amber color, malty oaky , dark fruit taste, and as warming as can be. Didnt get all the hops everyone else was . For a winter warmer, it really does the job. This was great

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2007 Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a mahogany color with a small tan head. The aroma is ripe fruit, caramel, brown sugar and almost a hint of cinnamon. The flavor is dominated by brown sugar though roasted malts and floral hops are evident and the finish has a bit of dry chocolate on it.
Bottle. Nice head with good duation. Beautiful dark amber color. Strong sweet and hoppy aroma. Taste is distinctive alcoholic but not at all in a bad sense. Very good taste.

2005 Bottle.  Very sugary, sweet aroma with lots of brown sugar, maple, and caramel aromas.  There is also some floral hoppiness which is pretty mild.  I am also detecting a bit of tabacco as well.  Very pleasant and complex aroma.  It¬ís a transparent garnet/amber color with a small off-white head.  Lots of chewy caramelly malts, which then turn more sweet with lots of the brown sugar flavor coming out.  There is some tobacco at the end and more of the mildly floral hop bitterness.  Tobaco follows this once again.  I get some lingering woodsiness and oakiness.  This is the quintessential "cigar beer".
Bottled 2005. Pours deep amber into a trappist glass.  Fruitcake, date and fig notes.  Well established head leaves a coat of lacing on the glass.  Smoked bread and pine with a long bitter finish.

Bottle from Premier in Buffalo.  Dark brown body with a solid creamy off white head (4+). Aroma is caramel malt with a tantalizing glimpse of hops, light notes of fruit and alcohol. Flavour is a bit of a let down after the aroma. Woody almost smokey character up front distracts from a caramel and malt middle. Hop bitterness and alcohol lingers. Medium to full bodied palate is quite nice.
Dark reddish brown, tannish head, medium sweet aroma, flavor is intensely malty, notes of ripe fruit, some chocolate, and spice. Smoky as well. Interesting, complex flavor.

35,5 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Reddish dark amber colour with a nice small head. Great aroma of heavy caramel-malt and a solid hoppieness. Great flavour of toffee, caramel, hops and ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol.

Pours a ruddy ruby/rust color with a nice display of head, thick with lacy sides. The smell is huge and rich with malty toffee, subtle mocha, earth, and robust hops to boot, this smell like a hell of a beer.
The taste is a bit acrid and I wonder if it¬ís because the beer is Ice cold. Me thinks this beer would taste a lot more bodied and less Hopfensive if it were a bit warmer, but none-the-les, a developed ber with strong malts, masked alcohol and a ripping hop sense. Surprisingly easy mouthfeel lets it go down easy.
Dont turn it down.

on tap at richos gravity head 2006. dark copper with a white head that leaves great lacing. aroma of nuts caramel and chocolate. deep bittersweet roasted nutty malt with a hint of hops and lots of chocolate. full body. long nutty chocolate finish. great winter beer.

This ale pours a dark amber color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is semi-sweet chocolate, caramel and a touch of cherry. A medium bodied American Strong Ale. Malts are caramel, chocolate, dark cherry and raisins. Hops are earthy and piney. Not a lot of bitterness. Very smooth taste. Lots of chocolate flavors. Nice carbonation. There is a touch of alcohol bite at the finish, but it hides the alcohol well. There is a nice alcohol warming from this beer. Nice holiday ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

(draft) This beer was simply hard to drink. Part of the problem was that it really clashed with the beer I¬íd just finished, but most of the problem was that it tasted like cranberry juice. It did get better toward s the end of the glass.

slightly hazy reddish-brown colour with a little foam; aroma of overmatured red fruits, very malty with light notes of alcohol, some caramel and chocolate appear too; a good malt body, some sweetness and a low bitterness; the finish is long and fruity with strong notes of anise
UPDATED: AUG 13, 2006 Bottle. Dark brwon with light head. Barley "wineish". A lot of malt - nice and roasty - a mild hop taste and a touch of caramel.

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry & tupalev - courtesy of me. Hazy amber colour with a small head. Aroma - I wrote "BURNT!" in big letters. Lots of bitter chocolate, some leather, and roasted malt. Flavour has notes of coffee and chocolate, rich malts, and a warm, boozy finish. I¬íd prefer it if the alcohol was reined in a tad, but it¬ís still a pretty fine beer.

Mahogany color; thin creamy head. Malt aroma, some hop resins, candies, light coffee, chocolate. Good body structure (maybe the carbonation is a bit too much aggressive on the tongue), good malt (but a bit thin and metallic at the end), not thick; caramel, quite big bitterness. Good and balanced, but with some off-flavors.

Very dark ruby red color with tiny light tan head. Aroma is malty, spicey, with cinamon, vanilla, oak, and a faint note of citrusy hops. Flavor is malty, sharp, hints of black pepper, burnt caramel, with significant hop flavor present. A little too much hop flavor for the style, in my opinion.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of GregClow. Pours a dark copper with a diminishing off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, some chocolate, caramel, spices and some hops. Flavour is quite roasty with lots of hops, chocolate and alcohol. For 8.1% the alcohol is pretty well hidden. Another great Great Divide beer!

Bottle shared with GregClow, Hogtown Harry, and Blankboy, courtesy of Greg.  Neat malt, dry baker¬ís chocolate, and burnt aroma.  Dark copper pour, decent sized bubbly head.  Lovely alcohol, malt, more dry chocolate and an interesting burnt aspect to the taste.  Lingering burnt alcohol in the finish.  A great sipper and a pleasure to drink, man I like this brewery...

UPDATED: APR 6, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow and tupalev - GregClow¬ís bottle.  Poured deep clear bubbly mahogany with a small foamy tan head.  Roasty aroma of leather and old pipe tobacco, baker¬ís chocolate and roast malt with leafy dry hops.  The taste is grainier with the roast malt seeming a touch sour (hint of red currant juice), and there¬ís quite a bit of alcohol on the finish.  Mouthfeel is alcoholic, slightly lively and decently thick - not their best, but another solid GD offering.

Clear, copper with red streaks and a fluffy, off-white head.  Creamy cocoa and caramel swirls mix with pine, toasted nuts, earthy malt, brown sugar, light alcohol, pumpernickel bread and a touch of coffee.  The body is large, soft and supple.  The dominate player in the mouth is obviously the malt--chewy, bready, toasted, slightly sweet, decadent malt.  The hops offer some semblance of balance, but the sweet malt reigns supreme.  A nice winter warmer with just barely perceptible alcohol, layered malts and a nice hop balance.  I¬íd drink a lot of this in the winter, perhaps next go-around...

12 oz bottle This was one great brew!  I¬ím not a malt head, but I really enjoyed the rich maltiness along with enough hop bitterness to balance it nicely. The initial aroma wasn¬ít particularly pleasant, smelling of something metallic.  As the beer warmed, the malt came through. Nice, rich mouth feel.  Note to self: Buy much more of this stuff next year!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2006 Fantastic sweet belgian  chocolate and maltaroma(sorry, spacebarbroken). Clear, dark brownpour with a touch of head. Very rich, velvety chocolate andstrong malt taste, complentedbynicebitter hops in the finish.  A very finebeer.

Thanks to BierBauch for this one. 12 oz bottle A dark maroon pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma is caramel, with big hops, and some toffee and brown sugar.  Sweet taste with a definite hoppy texture, caramel, and toffee.  Surprised that this is 8.1 % alcohol it¬ís a delight to drink and goes down smooth.  Great Ale from the people at Great Divide!  Something I will but on my "want" list from now on.

12 oz bottle.  Deep garnet tinted brown beer topped by 1" of tight light tan head.  Sweet hoppy aroma, pine/resin, a little bit spicy.  Behind that are some lovely complex malts, toast, milk chocolate, toffee and even a bit of earthiness.  Flavour is maltier than the aroma would have suggested.  Sweet milk chocolate and toast, caramel and a bit of cookie dough.  Light bitter finish backed by the grapefruit and pine flavour.  Some alcoholic pepperiness.  Gets a bit boozy as it warms up but this is still a very tasty brew.

This beer is fantastic...it¬ís a shame it has taken me so long to try it.  Pours brown brown and has a beautiful white head.  Smells of chocolate, roast, and a bit of citrusy hops.  Flavor is very full...almost stoutish.  Lots of chocolate and roasty malt...hardly any detection of alcohol or hops.  Mouthfeel is incredible.  I¬íll have to have it a couple of more times to make sure I wasn¬ít totally off my rocker.

This beer pours a dark brown and leaves a sticky beige lace that sticks to the side of the glass. This beer smells of honey, brown sugar, citrus rinds, and lemon grass. As I taste this beer the bitterness from the hops and a slight sweetness from the caramel malt comes out on the palate. I also get a slight aftertaste of the alcohal that lingers on the palate but is really hidden with the sweetness of the beer. Overall this is pretty good beer one that is a def winter time sipper.

Draught. Dark ruby brown with bubbly off white head that laced the glass. Aroma is of milk chocolate and subtle hops. Sweet from start to finish, but not cloyingly so. Alcohol flavor is prominent with a hint of chocolate brownies. The chocolate flavor lingers, and there is a bit of a medicinal finish.

Dark brown/amber. Small, tan head. Bubbles lining the glass. Aroma is roasty, caramel malt, tamed piney, resinous hops. Flavor is hoppy brown ale. Bitter chocolate finish and aftertaste. Alcohol only slightly detectable in the finish. Medium/full body, smooth.Very drinkable at 8.1%, especially after it warms a bit. Very good. I¬íd like more alcohol presence in a winter brew.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 (bottle - 12 oz) Cloudy red pour with a very thin tan head. Sweet aroma with hints of malts and cocoa. Lots of cocoa. The taste is very subtle at the beginning and then comes full force with a sweet and chocolaty roasted malt flavor and a slight hop bitterness and a finish of pine, hops and chocolate. Very warming with a nice porter aftertaste.
This was a decent winter ale, but had a very woody taste from what I can gather.  And this was not the oak version.  Still worth a try.

Poured dark amber, quite opaque. nose consisted of malty, candied sugar, molases, a hint of coco and mostly hop backbone.  Mouthfeel was considerably lighter than I hoped but it didn¬ít compramise on taste. Fairly smooth papate, quite bitter (too bitter for me) with it being somewhat unbalanced. Otherwise enjoyable.

Pours a clear dark ruby with thick white head that hangs around for a while and leaves substantial lacing on the sides of the glass. Big chocolate aroma with noticeable hop bitterness. Flavor is astringently bitter, grainy, dry, and somewhat chocolatey. Smooth and creamy palate. Unpleasantly astringent bitterness; otherwise hard to complain about this one.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2007 When it comes to winter warmers, not much takes precedent over Great Divide¬ís cautiously sweet Hibernation Ale.  This winter marked the first set of cold months since I hurdled over the 21 years age requirement, so I was looking forward to finding a good belly warmer and settling with it for the cold days to come.  What I found was neither a normal stout, or a disappointingly thin ¬ìwinter ale¬î.  At last, a winter seasonal apposite to a blizzarding day!  Only one other beer I had through November and December contends with Hibernation Ale (that being Hitachino New Year¬ís Ale).  The clear but furious glowing coal red colored ale floats beneath a dark custard head, intimating the details of the taste with a tempting smell of roasted malts and chocolate without the cloying bitter qualities.  The taste is surprisingly sweet; enough to satiate my youthful palate but not so light that it doesn¬ít kindle a glowing warmth in my stomach.  Also, the 8.1% ABV makes me a bit drowsy, so I¬ím prepared to settle into a deep chair for a brief respite from waking, cold hours.  Alongside the comforting textures and taste I can understand why they call this Hibernation Ale; a hearty beer with an alluring taste and a soporific finish.

12oz bottle: Pours a dark reddish brown with a light brown head that is mostly diminishing. Head leaves nice lacing around the glass. Aroma is roasty and hoppy with hints of flowers, pine and chocolate. Flavor is sweet with a well balanced hoppy taste that is creamy with a bitter finish.

On tap at Mr Goodbar in Buffalo. Very deep red.brown/chestnut color with a moderate and firm tan head. Looks great. Pleasant on all fronts, strong roasted and chocolate prescence, followed by very green yet not very bitter hops. On the sweeter end, earthy, well balanced, fuller bodied, alcohol is pretty well hidden. I¬íll definitely get this again if it¬ís still around.

Pours a darker ruby red with an average size off whie head that laced down the glass nicely.  Aroma of cocoa, a slight piney yet flowery hop, earthy and alcohol.  The flavor is interesting on this one.  Roasted yet hoppy.  Almost like a porter in some respects, but then there are the hops in there just changing it all up.  An interesting experience and I have to say one I enjoyed.  It looks like this beer gets some mixed reviews but I have to say I enjoyed it for sure.  Creamy palate to help out as well. Very complex.

Bottled. Pours a dark amber color. Aroma is quite sweet. Some hops, malts, and maybe a little yeast are present as well. Flavor is sweet and hoppy. Some roasted maltiness as well. This beer reminds me of a sweet IPA with some roasted malt qualities. Bitter finish. Good, but not great.

The visual is rather attractive, tan fluffy head and a dark burgundy body. The aroma has some nice flowery hops and a big maltyness, toffee, caramel, peat, very earthy yet the flavor has a big metallic presence. There is a lot of alcohol heat to the beer; it has some legs in the finish?? There is a hint of vegetables, odd DMS like suggestions, and a strange astringent like hoppyness that sneaks up on me in the finish¬Ö.  I might be in the minority of those that really don¬ít particularly care for this beer¬Ö. I really expected to like it more¬Ö. I just don¬ít like the way it all plays out.. too much in some spots and too little in others... it all falls apart for me somewhere??

(by way of trade from 1faststi)appearance was a headless semi murky reddish/brown.aroma was mostly earth,followed by cloves,brown sugar,and cinnamon.the flavor was an interesting mix for sure.black liquourice,root beer,chocolate,earth,brown sugar,and some hops all make up the flavor.interesting and good....

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2006 From Bottle

Poured light brown with ruby highlights, with a off white head. Aroma is floral. Taste is spicy and hoppy, with a nice sweet caramel aftertaste. Slight alcohol as it warms, but good, not offensive at all. I didn¬ít think I would like this one but I did. Great winter brew

This is a nice looking pour: reddish brown color with a one finger dirty white head. The mouthfeel is creamy with a very nice clean finish. The flavor has both hoppy & malty elements to it. I enjoyed this one.
Bottle. Nicely hoppy aroma. Black colour. Nice, creamy flavour, very complex, sweet, spicy, peppery.

12 oz bottle (2005) from Blue Max in Burnsville, MN (Dec 2005).  Dark translucent umber with lasting creamy-smooth tan cap....deliciously fragrant nose, woody and rough, with a myriad of hoppy-spicy notes, including pine and very sharp citrus, pungent barnyardy notes....a bit much, actually....body is quite sweet, almost cloyingly so, with an odd earthy-piney-resinous-spoiled raisin character that, while quite complex, doesn¬ít really work....the mouth is left with a sticky, gluey, sour feeling, cloying and almost cotton-candy like, with some sour wine near the finish.  Whoah.  Started out promisingly but at the end...didn¬ít like it, no sir.

Awesome amber color with a beige head that lasted the whole time.  Sweet aroma of caramel and hops.  Flavor is equally rich, sweet malt and hops bust through, with esteryness of a barley wine.  Mouthfeel is awesome, very coating and moderately carbonated.  Nice.

Rather nice mellow ale.
Quickly dissipating cream coloured head on a reddish brown clear liquid.
Very powerful fragrance of malts, flowery hops and a hint of cofee and chocolate. Huge complex yet agressive flavour of roasted malts, a nice sweetness combined with notes of spice (cinnamon, I believe).
Good one to keep you warm on a cold winter night.

Part of my 17 Beer Sampler at the Brew Kettle. Dark brown, white head, this tasted damn good, great malty flavor with spiness to it, very wintery, maybe some chocolate, lots of things going on coming together beautifully.

12oz bottle(vintage 2002). A three year old bottle!Make that four years old if I waited 2 more days. Dark red and hazy in color. No seeing through it. Off white head. Strong bready aroma, with a slight bourbon scent also. Hoppy warming flavor, soft sugars, much like nutra-sweet. Very good American Strong Ale. I would recommend this to others, and this means you fool!

Bottle, at home.
Dark red with beige head, almost diminishing, good lacings. Aroma moderate malty (bread, caramel, roasted), heavy hoppy (soft flowery). Flavor moderate sweet, heavy bitter, long duration. Medium body, oily, soft carbonated. Vintage 2005.

Pours a dark brown with a minimal amount of white wispy head.  Aroma is very earthy: oaks, smoke, floral, caramel and slight burbony scents.  Flavor is sweet, yet very spicey, like taco spicey.  Really not a fan of the flavor.  Overall, didnt live up to what i had hoped for.

2004 bottle courtesy of Brock_Landers. Dark brown pour with a decent sized head. Spicy aroma. Nice and smooth now thanks to the age on the bottle, I get a malty almost peanut flavor from it. Really nice. I¬íll be buying some to age next time I can find it.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 This bottled brew made in 2003 poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized mostly lasting light brown colored bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body contained unnoted carbonation, was dark and hazy with finely granulated sediments floating in the body and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of smoky caramel roasted malts chocolate and was very nice.  Its mouth feel is  tingly mild vinous bubbly with a  palate and a smooth aftertaste.  Its flavor contained vinous dark beer brown malts dark malts Irish red malty notes and was very tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber.  Aroma is dominated by chocolate and sweet malts.  Chocolate, spices, and carmalized sugar all come through in the taste.  Finishes with a small hop bitterness that lingers pretty well.  I must revisit this one before the Winter is over.

12 oz brown bottle purchased from Armanetti¬ís, Libertyville, IL. 8.1% ABV.  Clear dark amber ale having a small diminishing head.  Soft carbonation.  Earthy, spicy, and caramel aromas. Medium-to-full bodied that starts with spice, conifer (juniper?), wood, smoke,  caramel and light sweet malt flavors.  Finishes dry with lingering bitterness.  Interesting deeply spicy complex flavors which some may find overwhelming.  This is a very good warm and spicy drinkable winter brew.  Warming this beer to near room temperature is necessary for full flavor development.

2005 vintage:  Deep brown hue.  Sweet fruity nose, caramel, grain, hops.  Pale tan head, mostly diminishing leaving some lace.  Soft palate, toasty grain, caramel, cocoa, cherry, nutty, medium body, with nice hopped up finish.  Quite bitter, pungent hops, spicy and in your face.  Quite enjoyable I must say.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2013 10 oz. pour at the brewery followed by a pint at Illegal Pete¬ís. I was looking forward to revisiting this one. It¬ís near black with a tall light head. The aroma is a little different from the norm with hints at seaweed, rice, leather, fresh oak and chocolate. The palate is medium heavy and creamy. There is a sharp crisped rice cereal character with an almost smoky backdrop. Notes of earth, cacao nibs and slight dark fruits are in the flavor. Great winter beer.
Rich chocolate malts.  I healthy medium hop bitterness.  Thick surupy mouth feel with a low carbonation.  Perfect winter ale.  Has that hearty richness you need on a cold day.

Bottle.  Dark amber...seemed cloudy and hazey at first, but clarified fairly quickly.  Frothy white head disappeared   soon after pour.
Aroma is very interesting...at first you notice the fruity hops and a little spice...then you notice something distinctly sweet: and I can¬ít place exactly what it is.  It reminds of Christmas cookies or a sweet drink of sorts...or maybe something out of a scratch and sniff book...it¬ís peculiar and very interesting.
The tastse is great, too...initial hop bitterness melts into malty sweetness.  It¬ís not just well-balanced, the muliple facets of flavor flow into each other without boundary.
A great winter ale!!

An interesting aroma of mould and chocolate - a hint of hops. Nice head on pouring, but it does¬ínt last. Deep brown, chestnut colour. The chocolate is in the flavour as well, along with malt notes, and a strong hoppy bitterness.

Dark red colour. The head is off-white. Aroma of malt molasses and bitter chocolate. Malty and a little sweet flavor. Lots of chocolate and caramel aswell. Some bitter hops in the aftertaste. Very warming and nice beer.

this beer kicks a bit of ass! i had this before my main course at an indian restaurant in bloomington, il / muddy brown body; raisin, caramel, crisp, rich, smooth, and tasty... it¬ís actually deep. / i¬íll have to rate again for my memory is lost within my notes!
Slight caramel aroma.  Pours a dark red.  Great malty flavor balanced with great hops.  Some rich caramel, chocolate, vanilla, then crisp hops, with a great hop finish.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 In the bottle. Pours a rich dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Always one that I look forward to each year. Thick and loaded with heat, this is a real winter warmer. Serious amount of hops are absorbed into a thick and chewy malt monster that his the brakes just this side of barleywine country.
I thought this was outstanding.  Subtle bitter chocolate and dark fruit flavors.  Roast is very prevalent and some hops to give it a mild kick.  The brown color with a huge tan head is perfect.

Deep muddy brown with a tan head. Aroma is rich, malty, sweet, chocolate, wood, toasted bread, caramel, roast, and dirt giving it a earthiness. One of the more complex aromas I have had the privledge to enjoy. Texture is slightly chewy. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, heavily toasted, roast, even woody. There are some hops in the end, but the sweet malts balance it very well. No bitterness in this one. Decently carbonated. Bought one 12oz for $1.59 to try. I feel cheated I didn¬ít buy more of this gem.

2005 bottle. An attractive deep burgundy-amber color with a dense, frothy head. Nose was a bit subtle, but aromas of caramel, toasted malt, wood, chocolate and faint hops were present. Full, chewy mouthfeel with a smooth restrained carbonation level. Initial flavors of dark dried fruits, nuts, roasted malts and a pleasant musty earthiness prevail.  Alcohol warms things up nicely combined with a moderate hop bitterness to finish things off. Gotta enjoy this one in the cellar temp ranges of 55-60* to really get the full enjoyment. Another tasty offering from GD.  A super Winter Warmer.

Malty, earthy aroma of musty wood with notes of pine and sweet malts. Flavor starts sweet with tastes of raisins, caramel, sweet malts but gives way to notes of roasted malts, toast and earthy grains. The finish is all hops ¬ó bitter and lasting. Medium body that thickens creating a sensation of thin syrup. Medium carbonation. Overall, a good, multi-flavored winter ale.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2006 Bottle. This beer pours with a nice looking creamy head. It has a lot of chocolate in the aroma along with sweet malt. Tasting this beer is where it truly shows it character: roasted, smoky malt and a superb palate! I wasn¬ít impressed by the aroma, but when my tongue got a hold of this beer, we slowdanced ever so quickly, and now my glass is empty...why does fate have to be so cruel??? Re-rated this one and got a somewhat different result in aroma, taste and palate, but since it was at  a bar after some hoppy Mikkeller, I¬íll have to do a third rating, before I change this first one.
Mollassas with some chocolate aroma, deep red in color with a very light head.  A nice sweet taste followed by a caramel after-taste.  Highly enjoyable.

Bottle.  Thanks to SNOWTIGER. Pours a redish-amber color with a long lasting off white head with good lacing.  Aroma of malts and caramel finishes with a roastiness.  Flavor is strong with alcohol, also notes of caramel, molassas, and is sweet.  Medium to heavy mouthfeel finishes this well rounded, tasty, winter brew.

Pours to a dark mocha color. Very strong-tasting beer. Lots of roasty flavors, nice, strong finish - very good. Also, very strong alcohol wise (at least to me). Creamy, heavy, and very good. A nice change of pace.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2005 Pours with a frothy amber-tan colored head that is a finger and a half thick.  The beer is a deep amber color that shows a brilliantly clear deep ruby color when held up to the light.  The aroma is quite malty with notes of caramel and toffee up front moving to a dry lightly roasted note and a bit of burnt grain astringency.  The finish reminds me of toasty brown ale.  Perhaps there is a bit of cherry like fruit character as well, but this is fairly subdued.

The beer has a medium full heft to it, but does not really coat the mouth to much.  The beer is lightly sweet with notes of toffee and a light molasses.  The finish is a mix of toasted malt notes, a bit of coffee, and a roast grain character that also includes a hint of burnt grain astringency.
